projname: Henderson County Levee District #3 flood control project
projfund: Texas Water Development Fund II flood control account
map_meth: sketch maps and examination of engineering drawings
desc_loc: section of main levee along Wildcat Creek just above Trinity River confluence
ownerinfo:
Henderson County Levee District #3
Damon Douglas, Esquire, Official Correspondent
130 East Corsicana St.
Athens, TX 75751
informinfo:

Velvin & Weeks Consulting Engineers, Inc.
930 E. Corsicana St.
Athens, TX 75751
env_desc: man-made levee in Trinity River bottomland
time_desc: Consulting engineer stated that levees were built in 1926
cult_desc: levee and borrow pits (this segment only)
basis_size: extent of levee and adjacent borrow pit
artifact: No Data
circum: levee repair area visited during archeological survey of nearby borrow pit locations.  Levee was very carefully  drivable in 4x4 truck.  Trees cover most.
future: construction to repair levee to prevent failure
value: The site is a moderately well-preserved example of the numerous early 20th century earthen  flood control structures built in the Trinity River valley  before the onset of major flood control dams and reservoirs in the mid-20th century.  This segment is not unique and holds little research potential except as part of overall broader study of the development of flood control mechanisms in east central Texas during the 20th century.
disc_desc: This segment of levee being repaired is the portion of the main levee along Wildcat Creek  protecting 17,000 acre district from flooding during the 50-year flood event  by the Trinity River and tributaries Cedar Creek and Wildcat Creek.  It was built in the mid-1920s, but exact construction methods are unknown as of the current date.  Southern face fronting creek is now shear due to erosion.
attachmem:
1.  excerpt of USGS Roustabout Camp topo map (3196-444)
2.  site sketch map and rough profile.
3.  photos of area from adjacent borrow pit location

file_name: Manually plotted centroid by STAYLOR; Anderson_Archeological Site Form_thsa139_20251103_114901_9773919.csv
explain: Lithic debitage across an open landform
additional: Assisted by GEWMA summer intern Owen on second day
orgname: Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, Wildlife Div.
surf_tech: Intensive pedestrian survey along mulched fenceline ROW; collection from shovel tests; Shovel testing, 35 x 35 cm square, 1/4 in. mesh screen. 10 or 20 m intervals to delineate site boundary following initial positive test. 20 total, 11 positive
map_meth: GPS recording of shovel tests and site boundary
test_meth: Shovel testing, 35 x 35 cm square, 1/4 in. mesh screen. 10 or 20 m intervals to delineate site boundary following initial positive test. 20 total, 11 positive
records: digital map;digital photos; shovel test notes; shapefile; field notes
materials: Debitage and shatter from shovel tests; True
desc_loc: Along eastern boundary fenceline of Gus Engeling WMA, roughly 1.2 km (.75 miles) south of FM 2961; east of Catfish Creek basin and north of Box Creek basin, near confluence.
soil_desc: Darco, Kirvin, and Tenaha soils, sloping (DKF) and Kirvin-Sacul association, sloping (KNE)
env_desc: On southern slope (uppermost two benches) and top of ridge north of Box Creek and west of Catfish Creek; closest ridge to confluence. Mix of post and red oak, yaupon, occasional juniper, some vines and briar. A 25 foot corridor along the fenceline ROW was cleared and mulched in 2015; the mulch covers the ground surface except in limited disturbed areas. A few large old oaks were left in cleared corridor, and some younger trees are along/within the fenceline itself. A minor swale is along the northern boundary of the site. The landform extends for a good distance to the east, and a short distance to the west towards Catfish Creek, except at the very top of the hill, where the level ridgetop extends a couple hundred meters to the west.
time_desc: lithic debitage but no specific temporally diagnostic artifacts
basis: no temporally diagnostic artifacts, low density suggests single occupation but recovery throughout matrix complicates issue
cult_desc: No features, no obvious burned rock.
basis_size: shovel testing, property boundary, limits of APE
artifact: Lithic debitage. 16 flakes (14 chert, 1 petrified wood, 1 petrified palm), 1 quartzite cobble shatter (no clear evidence of burning).
circum: Limited to a narrow ROW along a property boundary. Extremely hot typical July weather. Roughly 17 person hours spent delineating site.
intact: 50% intact, clearly has experienced some disturbed deposits, erosion, displaced artifacts
landuse: Wildlife Management Area, along property boundary fence.
natural: Erosion, extensive bioturbation from trees, animals (particularly feral hogs and armadillos)
future: Vegetation clearing, fenceline replacement. Possibly maintenance as fire lane.
value: Moderately low. Rather low density site, main site area is sandy upland, possible concentration of artifacts at 40-80 cm but possibly vertically displaced. Has limited potential for intact features, datable organics, or evidence to yield significant new information about the prehistory of the area.
invest: Would want to survey to east and west of current boundaries prior to any impacts in those areas, no further investigations warranted within current boundaries. Will recommend hand cutting of vegetation within site boundaries, no more than shallow subsurface impacts beyond fence posts.
disc_desc: The site is situated on a prominent landform overlooking Box Creek  to the south, near its confluence with Catfish Creek to the west. The southern edge of the site is on the second side slope bench north of the creek basin, and this site continues up slope and onto the level ridge top, ending around a slight swale. The site likely extends to the east and west, where the landform continues and is more level. Artifacts were recovered from 0-100 cm in the various shovel tests, with many coming from 40-80 cmbs, but not to the extent that it can be called a buried component. The distribution of the artifacts on the landform and within the deposits is pretty consistent with a moderately disturbed sandy mantle site, where artifacts have been vertically displaced within loose sandy soils, and horizontally displaced (and sometimes buried) by erosion. Overall, the artifact density is low, with only 1 flake recovered from 7 of the positive tests, 2 flakes/shatter from 3 more, and one test with 4 flakes (on the main part of the landform). No tools, no temporally diagnostic artifacts, no pottery.
Concat_site_variables: lithic scatter. No Data. 19-Jul-16. July 19 and 20, 2016. Debitage and shatter from shovel tests; True. explain: Lithic debitage and burned rock across an open landform
orgname: Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, Wildlife Div.
surf_tech: Intensive pedestrian survey along mulched fenceline ROW; collection from shovel tests; Shovel testing, 35 x 35 cm square, 1/4 in. mesh screen. 10 or 20 m intervals to delineate site boundary following initial positive test. 6 total, 4 positive
map_meth: GPS recording of shovel tests and site boundary
test_meth: Shovel testing, 35 x 35 cm square, 1/4 in. mesh screen. 10 or 20 m intervals to delineate site boundary following initial positive test. 6 total, 4 positive
records: digital map; digital photos; shovel test notes; shapefile; field notes
materials: Arrow point, nutting stone, burned sandstone and debitage from shovel tests; True
desc_loc: Along boundary fenceline of Gus Engeling WMA, roughly 1.2 km (0.75 miles) south of FM 2961; east of Catfish Creek basin south of Box Creek basin, west of tributary and wetland area.
soil_desc: Darco, Kirvin, and Tenaha soils, sloping (DKF) and Nahatche and Pluck soils
env_desc: Near edge of north side of ridge that projects west into Catfish Creek, south of Box Creek; closest ridge to confluence. To the east is a tributary drainage that flows through a wetland. Mix of post and red oak, yaupon, occasional juniper, some vines and briar. A 25 foot corridor along the fenceline ROW was cleared and mulched in 2015; the mulch covers the ground surface except in limited disturbed areas. A few large old oaks were left in cleared corridor, and some younger trees are along/within the fenceline itself. The landform extends a short distance to the south and north, but has a sharp drop off to east.
time_desc: Untyped arrow point, probably an Alba
cult_desc: No features but burned sandstone suggests at least limited potential for a cooking feature.
basis_size: shovel testing, property boundary, limits of APE, landform
artifact: Arrow point, probably an Alba. Ferruginous sandstone nutting stone/possible mano. Burned sandstone chunk. 7 pieces of chert debitage.
circum: Limited to a narrow ROW along a property boundary. Temperate early fall afternoon both days. 5 person hours on site.
intact: 70% intact, has experienced some disturbed deposits and erosion.
landuse: Wildlife Management Area, along property boundary fence.
natural: Erosion, bioturbation from trees and animal
value: Moderate. Low artifact density but high artifact diversity, as well as presence of burned rock, indicates some potential for features, datable organics, and possibly some unique information might be present.
invest: Would want to survey to north and south of current boundaries prior to any impacts in those areas, no further investigations warranted within current boundaries. Recommend hand cutting of vegetation within site boundaries, no more than shallow subsurface impacts beyond fence posts.
disc_desc: The site appears to be a small open campsite on a somewhat prominent landform overlooking Box Creek  to the north, near its confluence with Catfish Creek to the west. The site likely extends to the north, where the landform continues, and possibly for a short distance to the south. Artifacts were recovered from 0-100 cm in 4 positive shovel tests, although all but 2 came from 0 to 60 cmbs. Most of the artifact assemblage came from two tests, with the other two positive tests each yielding a single flake. Nonetheless, this is an unusual site despite the small size and limited recovery, due to the variety of artifacts included.

additional: Archaeological and Architectural Survey of the Apex Bethel Energy Center 45-Acre Energy Production Site, Trinity River Pipeline, and Associated Infrastructure, Anderson County, Texas (CRM report)
surf_tech: Systematic pedestrian survey with shovel testing
records: analysis notes; digital map; digital photos; daily journal; paper map; photo logs; project report; shapefile; shovel test notes
materials: 1 earthenware fragment, 2 pieces (refit) historic ceramic (transferware), 1 green glass bowl rim fragment (Depression glass), 1 aqua glass bottle/jar body fragment with 'PAT' in 1 inch letters embossed, 1 wire nail; True
temphouse: WSA laboratory at the office in Round Rock, Texas
desc_loc: the site is at the original terminus of CR 2604, north from CR 2601. CR 2604 now appears to terminate at a property gate 400 feet WSW from the site.
drain_name: Saline Branch of the Trinity River
ownerinfo: Shirline, Anita, And Christine Glenn (address redacted) (phone redacted)
soil_desc: FuB- Lilbert loamy fine sand 0-3% slopes
env_desc: the site is located in a fallow field, now active cattle pasture with small clusters of old hardwood trees and a young hardwood forest just north of the site. The topography is a mostly flat area at the top of a gently rolling hill/upland. Away from the site the slope increases and downslopes east and south at about 5%.
cult_desc: House (~late 1940s built) with attached carport (55 ft east-west, 42 ft north-south), septic, and well and partly destroyed pumphouse. The well is north of the house and the septic west. There is also a three-post clothesline south (behind) the house. There are fences and fenceposts that might partly follow the historic fences and posts but they are recent replacements/upkeep. All historic features appear associated with the continuous occupation of the house from the late 1940s through mid-late 1990s.
basis_thk: archaeological material present in loamy lens (0-30 cmbs) above denser basal clay.
artifact: (in addition to collected material) Press and blow valve open mouth screw top clear glass jar with conjoined AG on base and no stippling/knurling; clear glass embossed Yoohoo! Bottle ca.1955; early 20th machine open top washing machine with attached wringer/mangler; 1940s/1950s stove and furniture; ceramic gas radiators; bottles and jars largely dating from post-1950 through modern era (1990s); calendar on wall 1994; late 1950s Ford F100 (with 1994 registration on license plate)
intact: site is in good condition/>75% intact
natural: plants and trees growing into structure, animals utilizing inside
artificial: reuse as cattle farm implement storage
value: The site is a 1940s-modern farmstead, not unique to the area, not unique in architecture, not associated with a person important to local, state, or federal history.
regist: site is not good example and not eligible Sec 106 Crit. A,B, C, D.
disc_desc: Site is a mid-century historic farmstead, likely constructed by Elijah and wife Panzy Glenn shortly after they acquired the property in 1946 and given to their children in 1998. the house is the main feature of the site. It is a side-gable one-story six-cell house with front gabled extension on the right (west) side of the house (when facing front of house). There is a two-bay carport attached to the left side (east) of the house. The house has many layers of cladding, from the inside out= wide wood clapboard, late 1940s/early 1950s Insulbrick, expanded wire mesh and concrete? holding on brick facade, intermittent stucco. The shingles have at least three layers, the underneath ones appear to be asbestos, the outer more modern asphalt. The front door and stoop is centered on the house; there is a large picture window to the east and a double hung window west. There is a door out the east side into the carport. There are three windows on the west side (two double hung wood sash and a smaller double hung bathroom in the center). There is a back door center of the south side of the house and double hung wood sash windows on either side. There are three double hung aluminum sash windows on the east side of the carport; there is a door and double hung aluminum (?) sash window on the south wall of the carport. Inside the house, the main room appears remodeled in the 1960s and re-carpeted in the 1970s (orange and yellow shag), and there is a piano and ceramic gas radiator in the living; the door to the carport is on the left as you enter, and there is an office left and rear of the living room. There are papers from the 1980s and 1990s on top of the mid-century furniture in the office as well as another ceramic gas radiator (there is a door to the kitchen through the office on the right as you enter). On the right of the living room is a short hallway. At the north end of the hallway (in the front extension) is a room, likely a bedroom, with late 20th C furniture. In the middle and west side of the hallway is the bathroom; the fixtures are ceramic and the gas hot water heater is inside; in the middle and east side of the hallway is a closet with clothes in it. At the south end of the hallway is a room (likely bedroom) with mid to late 20th C furniture and a calendar open to 1994. upon entering this room to the left is the small kitchen. The kitchen contains a counter and sink, melanine table, 1940s washing machine with wringer, mid-century deep freezer, late 1940s/early 1950s gas range and oven, a late 20th C refrigerator. The well is concrete and deep (covered with a sheet of metal, not attached), about 60 feet deep and almost dry (just a puddle in the clay at the bottom), and is west and adjacent to the remains of the pump and pumphouse (pump has screw type fuses). The septic is located almost immediately west of the house, is concrete and the lid is broken and partly on top. There is a three-pole clothesline south of the carport. Southeast of the carport is a pile of debris/trash that may be a collapsed storage shed; it contains papers, jars and bottles from 1940s-modern, a 1970s washing machine, misc. wheels and pulleys, boards, and shingles.

file_name: Manually plotted centroid by STAYLOR; Anderson_Archeological Site Form_thsa139_20251103_114901_9773919.csv
explain: subsurface lithic debitage, fire-cracked rock, and carbon.
additional: Mike Smith, Jay King, Chris Shelton, Cristian Cruz-Morales, J Philip Washington
surf_tech: Controlled survey within ROW; no collection; Shovel testing; 25 shovel tests (STs), 6 of which were positive, (3) 10 x 1m trenches
test_meth: Shovel testing; 25 shovel tests (STs), 6 of which were positive, (3) 10 x 1m trenches
records: digital map; digital photos; daily journal; photo logs; shovel test notes
desc_loc: From the intersection of FM 59 and FM 2961, proceed E on CR 2961 approximately 1 km. Crossing the fence south of the road, proceed south approximately 0.3 km.
water: Mitchell Branch Creek, 110 m to the east
ownerinfo: Atmos Energy Corp 5420 LBJ Freeway, Ste 1700, Dallas, TX 75240
env_desc: The site is located on a low rise above Mitchell Branch Creek, which lies roughly 110 m to the east. The site lies within a copse of various hardwoods, poison ivy, and greenbrier. Occasional small clearings are vegetated with low grass and high weeds, resulting in low ground surface visibility. Two parallel fencelines, running E-W, cross the site at its southern boundary.
time_desc: Lithic debitage, but no diagnostic artifacts
basis: No diagnostic artifacts or intact features.
cult_desc: No intact cultural features are associated with the time period of the site's occupation. Two modern fencelines lie at the site's southern margin, and a large push pile of fallen trees is present near the site's center. A two-track runs N-S along the site's western margin.
basis_size: Shovel testing, with double negatives at 10-m intervals at the ends of major axes, Negative trenches at site margins
basis_thk: Artifacts were found within 6 shovel tests, between 70 and 90 cmbs.
artifact: Four pieces of lithic debitage, 1 piece of fire-cracked rock, and 2 fragments of carbon. Debitage consisted of 1 chert secondary flake and 3 chert tertiary flakes (2 of which were heat-spalled); all were between 1 and 2 cm in length. The fire-cracked rock was of metaquartzite and measured 4 cm in diameter.
natural: Several trees have fallen, perhaps disturbing soils with root movement; cattle grazing; bioturbation by ants and rodents.
artificial: Two modern barbed wire fences, a two-track road, brush clearing; numerous felled trees and bushes have been pushed into a pile near the center of the site.
value: Shovel testing at the site suggested that it was a deeply buried campsite, possessing charcoal in association with burned rock. All artifacts were found at a relatively consistent level, between 70 and 90 cm below surface, which suggests the possibility of intact cultural deposits. However, within the pipeline project area, trenches were excavated along project centerline, revealing a surprising paucity of artifacts, and absence of any indications for subsurface features or in-tact stratigraphy
invest: Exploratory trenching by BGE archaeologists at TS01 within the project area has determined that it does not possess elements or features that would support a recommendation for NRHP eligibility, and it is unlikely that further investigations will yield any significant information. Therefore BGE recommends that no further work is necessary for site this site within the proposed project area.
disc_desc: The site, which lies on a low rise above Mitchell Branch Creek, was tested by a series of 25 shovel tests (STs), 6 of which proved positive for cultural materials. Four STs contained 1 piece of debitage, a fifth contained a fragment of fire-cracked rock and a small piece of carbon, and the sixth produced one larger piece of carbon; all artifacts were found within 70 to 90 cm below ground surface. Soils at the site are sands of the Tonkawa series, and extend downward beyond 100 cm in depth. The presence of the fire-cracked metaquartzite alongside carbon suggested that cooking features were present; this in turn suggests the probability that site TS 01 represents a campsite, perhaps short-term as indicated by the low number of observed artifacts. In order to determine if the site possessed any  vertical or horizontal depositional integrity, preserved organic material, or subsurface features, 3 trenches were subsequently excavated. Trench one was excavated along site TS01's southern boundary, where the landform slopes down to the floodplain of Mitchell Branch Creek. The trench yielded 2 secondary flakes in the backfill dirt removed from the interior of the site, however no evidence of subsurface features were observed. Trench two was excavated at site center, with positive site shovel tests to the north east and west of its location, and situated atop of the landform overlooking the Mitchell Branch Creek floodplain to the east. No cultural features or artifacts were observed within the trench backfill, floor or sidewalls. Trench three was excavated along the northern boundary of the site, situated atop the same landform west of the Mitchell Branch floodplain, with positive site shovel tests located to the south and east. No cultural features or artifacts were observed within the trench backfill, floor, or sidewalls. Exploratory trenching by BGE archaeologists at the site within the project area has determined that it does not possess elements or features that would support a recommendation for NRHP eligibility, and it is unlikely that further investigations will yield any significant information.
Concat_site_variables: occupation; prehistoric. No Data. 8/27/2014. 8/27/2014. No collection.; False. From the intersection of FM 59 and FM 2961, proceed E on CR 2961 approximately 1 km. file_name: Manually plotted centroid by STAYLOR; Anderson_Archeological Site Form_thsa139_20251103_114901_9773919.csv
explain: Chert debitage found within shovel tests.
additional: Mike Smith, Jay King, Chris Shelton, John Hogg, Clay Zdobylak
surf_tech: Controlled pedestrian survey; no collection.; 7 shovel tests
records: daily journal; digital map; digital photos; paper map; shovel test notes
desc_loc: From FM 59, proceed east on FM 2961 approximately 1 km. Proceed north of the road approximately 30 m.
water: Mitchell Branch Creek, 30 m to the east
ownerinfo: Atmos Energy Corp. 5420 LBJ Freeway, Ste 1700, Dallas, TX 75240
env_desc: The site is located on a low rise overlooking Mitchell Branch Creek to the east, which has been dammed in this area. It lies in open pasture between stands of hardwoods. High weeds contribute to low ground surface visibility. It is bisected by an E-W fenceline of barbed wire. It is about 100 m north of FM 2961. An abandoned house is immediately outside the ROW to the SW of the site, and a metal cattle shoot is located just to the south of the site. On the eastern margin of the ROW, the slope drops sharply down towards the dammed creek.
cult_desc: No prehistoric features were observed. Modern features include one barbed wire fence bisecting the site from E-W and a second running along the site's western margin. An abandoned house lies to the SW, and an iron cattle shoot is present just S/SE of the site.
basis_size: Shovel testing to north and south (3 positives out of 7 total shovel tests), ROW boundary to west, and steep drop-off to east
basis_thk: Prehistoric artifacts found between 20 and 60 cm below ground surface
artifact: 4 tertiary chert flakes from 3 shovel tests: 3 flakes between 50 and 60 cm below surface, 1 flake between 20 and 30 cm. Modern artifacts were present in two shovel tests: clear glass and iron fence staples were found between 10 and 80 cm below surface, and a modern grommet (uncorroded) was found between 80 and 90 cm.
natural: Erosion to the south, associated with a steep drop to an artificial lake. Animal grazing.
artificial: Two barbed wire fences, cleared pasture, cattle chute and ranching activity.
value: Minimal. No diagnostics, organics, or features associated with the prehistoric component of the site were observed. Prehistoric artifacts were found with and above modern debris, suggesting ground disturbance and/or significant movement of materials within the sandy soil.
disc_desc: The site is located above Mitchell Branch Creek, which has been dammed to the east. Lithic artifacts were encountered in shovel tests; however, modern glass, 3 rusted fence staples, and a metal grommet (uncorroded) were found within the shovel tests above, beside, and below the prehistoric artifacts. These modern artifacts likely relate to the abandoned house and cattle chute. Only 4 chert flakes were found within a 20 m by 20 m area, and no associated prehistoric features were encountered.

soil_desc: Houston Black-Houston association; Houston Black series; Houston Black clay, 1-3 percent slopes.
env_desc: The site is located in gently rolling upland hills that gives way to a plowed field to the south.  A drainage is located further south.  Hardwood trees were located on the site, as was a remnant hedgerow, and numerous onion plants.
cult_desc: Scatter consisted of a generalized low-density area of cultural materials, another area of burnt trash, a small mound of brick fragments, and a small brick feature.  The low density surface scatter was made up of numerous mineralized glass fragments, glass bottles, bricks and brick fragments, animal bone, and one partial stoneware dish.  Kitchen equipment, particularly a sink and stove constructed of enameled steel, were also observed.  The relatively high-density burned scatter consisted of 25 square meters of burned tin cans and other debris centered on an old water trough used for burning trash.  The brick mound measured approximately 10x10 m, and although irregular in height, it did not exceed 0.5 meters.  The curved brick feature measured 2.0 m in length and approximately 3 bricks wide.  The feature, which was probably a walkway or flower border, is uplifted along its centerline and not mortared together.
artifact: Three whole glass bottles were noted in the surface scatter.  The first bore the baked enamel inscription: Triple AAA (superimposed over "Your Favorite")/Root Beer/For a______________/Delicious Healthful/And Refreshing Drink/Contents 8.5 fluid Ozs./Bottled by Authority of/Triple AAA Co., Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. In the heel position, the embossed inscription "LG" (without a hyphen), the trademark of the Liberty Glass Company in Sapulpa, Oklahoma, is visible.  Other embossed letters around the perimeter of the base include 6-1/2 fl oz, and the number "593-1." In addition, the crudely embossed number "45" is located on the bottom near one edge, which is the manufacture date (Toulouse 1971:321).  According to Klamkin (1971:193) baked enamel lettering on glassware did not become commonplace until after the mid-1930s, which is consistent with the manufacture date.  The other bottles did not yield as much information.  Any enameled lettering has worn off, leaving only a few embossed notations on the bottles.  One bottle with a white residue in the interior bears the embossed inscription, "Easy Dip Well," on the shoulder.  On the base of the bottle is the inscription, "2 FL. OZ. NET," over a "B" with a circle around it.  Below the "B" is the number "10."  Although the encircled letter "B" was the trademark of both the J. T. Baker Chemical Company, of New York, New York, and the Brockway Machine Bottle Company, the J. T. Baker Chemical Company mark was typically found on the shoulder of the bottle.  The Brockway Machine Bottle Company opened in Olean, New York, in 1907 using a semiautomatic machine.  Within the same year, they moved their operation to Brockwayville, Pennsylvania.  The company adopted the encircled "B" trademark after 1925. The company later became the Brockway Glass Company in 1933 (Toulouse 1971:59-60). This particular bottle probably held white shoe polish.  The third bottle is a flat, rectangular bottle with side seams, and the rusted remains of a screw top lid.  The bottom of the bottle is embossed with an "O," an encircled "I," and the number "3."  Below these is the inscription "4 OZ."  The number "19" is the last inscription.  The encircled "I" was the trademark used by Owens Illinois Glass Company, of Toledo, Ohio, after 1954.  After its inception in 1929, it had as many as 20 plants in operation at the same time.  By the mid-1930s, however, only 12 remained open.  The company experienced a resurgence of business in the 1940s, which had again slowed during the 1950s.  After 1966, the company was known as Owens-Illinois Inc (Toulouse 1971:403).
circum: Shovel testing was limited by the extent of the current ROW.
intact: The portion of the site in the  ROW has been previously impacted by construction
future: A proposed road widening of US 380.
value: The platform foundation does not possess the characteristics necessary to contribute significantly to regional or local research. Shovel testing revealed a disturbed context and no artifacts.
invest: No further investigations at this site are recommended.
regist: This site is not considered potentially eligible for inclusion on the NRHP.
disc_desc: Shovel testing and surface survey revealed a site that measures 30 x 14 m (420 square m), surface but scatter was observed extending south of the proposed ROW.   The 1930 soil map indicates that structures were widely spaced in the vicinity of GMI 12.5. Two of the three bottles found of the surface of the site indicate manufacture and use dating from the 1940s and 1950s.  The shoe polish bottle was not made any earlier than 1925.  The USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle (Farmersville 1962) indicates that in 1962, at least three structures were present on the site.  The cultural deposits located during this survey probably reflect the remains of one or more of those structures. After demolition, the site appears to have been used for burning and dumping trash.  Most of the cultural materials at this site, however, are on the surface.  It is unclear, therefore, which materials are a result of the original occupation, and which are the result of later trash dumping.  As a result, this site is not recommended as potentially eligible for the NRHP.

surf_tech: Within the proposed ROW, inspected the surface in 5-m intervals.  Collected one dish possessing a maker's mark.

records: analysis notes, archival notes, daily journal, field catalog, map drawings, shovel test records
desc_loc: Located adjacent to the southern side of US 380, 0.30 km (1640.5 ft) west of CR 557.
ownerinfo:
Texas Department of Transportation
125 E. 11th St.
Austin, TX 78701-2483
soil_desc: Houston Black-Houston association; Houston Black series; Houston Black, 1-3 percent slopes.
env_desc: Rolling upland hills in grassy cover.
time_desc: Historic maps and artifact content of the site.
basis: Due to bulldozing during the demolition of the str
cult_desc: No features or intact structural remains were observed.
artifact:
The surface debris consisted of numerous bricks and brick fragments, some bearing the marking "PALMER;" other fragments bore a partial marking "CLO---."   Most bricks, however, bore no marking.  "Palmer" was the trademark used by Palmer Pressed Brick Company from 1902-1929 (Steinbomer n.d.).  This Ellis County, Texas, brickmaker was known as Smith, Blocker, and Love until 1922.  Palmer Pressed Brick Company merged with Standard Brick Company in 1928/29, to become the Barron Brick Company (Steinbomer n. d.).  The "CLO-" trademark probably represents a non-local brickmaker.  Other architectural items included a light fixture, sheet tin, nails, and lumber.  Domestic items observed on the surface but not collected included fragments of solarized glass and mineralized glass.  Three body sherds, two of them exhibiting a foot ring, of a dish bearing a maker's mark were collected from the surface.  "Golden Wheat/Made in the USA/22k Gold/Oven Proof," is the inscription on a decal on the bottom of the dish.  The wheat motif decal design is visible on the interior surface of all three sherds.  This pattern was produced by the Homer Laughlin China Company, the French Saxon China, and Scio Pottery for a 1960s grocery store promotion (Lehner 1988).  Other items that may have had agricultural uses included a cast iron eyebolt, a cast iron rim fragment of unidentified use, and barbed wire.

The shovel tests revealed a shallow surface component from 0-40 cm bs.  Six of the 9 shovel tests excavated were positive and revealed quantities of nondiagnostic glass fragments, nails, weathered brick fragments, barbed wire, and some small lumber fragments.
circum: Investigation was limited by the extent of the proposed ROW.  Visual observation indicates that the site extends beyond the boundary of the proposed ROW.
intact: The portion of the site investigated is not intact.
artificial: Site impacted when the structures were destroyed and bulldozed.  Water line forms the western boundary of the site.
invest: No further investigations are recommended for site GMI 11.1.
regist: The site is not considered potentially eligible for inclusion on the NRHP.
disc_desc: Shovel testing and surface survey revealed the disturbed and fragmented remains of structures depicted on historic maps.  The structures may have built as early as 1902, when the Palmer Pressed Brick Company began producing that trademarked series of bricks.  At least one of the four structures depicted by the USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle (Culleoka 1960, photorevised 1968, photoinspected 1973) was still being occupied as of 1968, when the map was photorevised.  This would be consistent with the approximate period of distribution of the "Golden Wheat" patterned dish.  Other artifacts demonstrate a non-diagnostic mixture of domestic, architectural, and possibly agricultural, uses.  Although six of the nine shovel tests excavated during these investigations yielded positive results, the distribution of artifacts is a result of the demolition process, and therefore, lacks the integrity that would enable researchers to distinguish separate structures.  Due to the non-diagnostic nature of most of the cultural material observed, however, little information can be determined from them regarding site specialization, function, diversity, or complexity, and therefore is not recommended as eligible for inclusion in the NRHP.

additional:

surf_tech: Within the ROW, inspeced the surface in 5-m intervals.
test_meth: Four shovel tests were placed in 5-m intervals along a single transect in the ROW.
records: analysis notes, archival notes, daily journal, feature record, lab inventory, shovel test records
desc_loc: The site is located 0.05 km west of the intersection of US 380 and the Gulf Colorado and Santa Fe Railroad.
water: An unnamed intermittent drainage 0.5 km to the west.
ownerinfo:
Texas Department of Transportation
125 E. 11th St.
Austin, Texas  78701-2483
soil_desc: Houston Black-Houston association; Houston Black series; Houston Black, 1-3 percent slopes.
env_desc: The site is located in gently rolling upland hills, now part of Farmersville, Collin County, Texas.  Woods composed of both evergreen and deciduous trees surround the site.
cult_desc: The shed is a board and batten structure with a shed roof, and measures 3.5 m long and 2.5 m wide.  The height from the ground to the bottom of the roof line is 2.0 m.  The planks are standard 12" x 1" boards, and the nails are round head 1.5".   One feature was noted.  It consisted of part of a circular brick feature, which was once standing, but now has fallen on its side.  The remnant, measuring 0.75 m long, was constructed of bricks mortared together three high. Cobbles have been arranged at the base of the bricks in a circular pattern.  Situated 15 m north-northeast of the shed, disturbances due to the placement of utilities and the construction of the railroad were apparent, and probably resulted in the destruction of the circular feature. The resulting mound was 1.5 m in diameter, and 0.5 m high.
artifact: A single base shard of stoneware was covered interiorly and exteriorly with a two-toned natural clay slip.  The exterior slip had mostly flaked off, leaving only remnant traces.  As stoneware of this type was made in Texas from 1885 to 1900, this shard was probably made in a local Denton County kiln.
circum: Thick brush and viney cover obscured the ground.  Shovel testing was limited by extent of the ROW.
intact: The shed is dilapidated.  Less than 20 percent of sediments remain intact.
artificial: Railroad and highway construction, as well as urban development.
future: A proposed road widening of US 380.
value: This site does not possess the characteristics necessary to contribute significantly to regional or local research. The shed and the associated well are located in the southwestern quadrant of the intersection of US 380 and the Gulf Colorado and Santa Fe Railroad.  The two shovel tests excavated near the circular feature and between the railroad and the shed revealed a disturbed context.
invest: No further investigations at this site are recommended.
regist: This site is not considered potentially eligible for inclusion on the NRHP.
disc_desc: A 1930 soil survey map indicates the presence of a structure at the shed location.  US Highway 380, however, had not been constructed at the time of the soil survey fieldwork, which probably took place in the mid- to late- 1920s.  The shed and circular feature were probably associated with one or more of the structures indicated on the map and demolished prior to or concurrently with the construction of the highway. Due to the non-diagnostic and sparse nature of the cultural material observed, however, little information can be determined from that regarding site specialization, function, diversity, or complexity, and therefore is not recommended as eligible for inclusion in the NRHP.
Concat_site_variables: Historic; historic. No Data. 11-Mar-03. 11-Mar-03. No Data. The site is located 0.05 km west of the intersection of US 380 and the Gulf Colorado and Santa Fe Railroad.. sitename: Green Roof House; Green Roof House
additional:
Skinner, S. Alan, Floyd D. Kent
1999     Cultural Resources Survey of the GOLF COURSE AT STONEBRIDGE RANCH, Collin, County Tx.  AR Consultants rpt. No. 99-2
recname: Floyd D. Kent, Lance K. Trask
records: maps/drawings, shovel test records, daily journal
desc_loc: 150 m west of Custer Road, 120 m north of County Road 115.  Travel west on CR115.  Stop at fence dividing cornfield from overgrown brushy acrage.  Walk 120m N. along fenceline.  Structure is 5m west of fence.  East of Rowlett Creek, do not go west across creek!
env_desc: Site is on flood plain east of Rowlett Creek.  Acrage is overgrown with hackberry, locust, bois d'arc, blood weed and other invasive plants.  Slope is less than 1 to 3% west.
cult_desc: 12X24 ft two room board & batten frame structure, wood block foundation, planed lumber, wire nails, stove chimney supported on wooden platform.  Composition shingles (green) over wood shingles.  Ceiling is ship-lap.  Composition "fake-birch" siding.  One door each room, windows each wall, each room.  Long axis of bldg is E/W, wired for electricity, single line insulators.  Note: during site recording a single strand of barbed wire had been used to run electricity into house!  Windows 3 panes across, 2 deep upper and lower.  External door locks on panel doors.; Sharcropper/Tenant shack.  No cistern or well, no old trash, no yard, fence, no outhouse.  These recorders noted this is one of the most sterile (as far as artifacts) structure areas seen in some time.
artifact: House, brick (PALMER) recent trash.  No obvious materials around house.  Fenders and headlamp of T model ford in fencerow some meters away.  Plastic vinyl siding, telephone poles nearby.
circum: clear cold day, dense brush and weeds.
landuse: abandoned 30+ years.  Hackberry growing through porch.
value: In spite of house being relatively intact the research value is minimal.  There are better preserved examples elsewhere.
invest: same as above; same as above
disc_desc: There is a cluster of houses within 300 m of each other.  Three, including this site, are believed to be nearly identical two room stove chimney houses (sometimes referred to as box and shelf).  None have cisterns, all are on blocks and all are board and batten.

surf_tech: Within the ROW, inspeced the surface in 5-m intervals.
test_meth: Four shovel tests were placed in 5-m intervals along a single transect in the proposed ROW.
records: archival notes, daily journal, feature record, shovel test records
desc_loc: This site is comprised of a concrete platform foundation on the southwestern corner of US 380 and CR 547.
water: An unnamed drainage of Brushy Creek is located 0.5 km away.
ownerinfo:
Texas Department of Transportation
125 E. 11th St.
Austin, Texas  78701-2483
soil_desc: Houston Black-Houston association; Houston Black series; Houston Black clay, 1-3 percent slopes.
surf_tex: sandy, silty clay with pebble inclusions
env_desc: The site is located in gently rolling upland hills, now part of Farmersville, Collin County, Texas.  The lot in which this foundation is located is planted in grass and mowed.
cult_desc: The foundation is irregularly shaped, measuring approximately 5.7 x 5.7 m.  Burned asphalt and linoleum remnants have adhered to portions of the foundation.  The foundation, however, is deviod of any other artifacts.  Door sills are not apparent.
artifact: None.
circum: Shovel testing was limited by the extent of the current ROW.
intact: The portion of the site in the  ROW has been previously impacted by construction
future: A proposed road widening of US 380.
value: The platform foundation does not possess the characteristics necessary to contribute significantly to regional or local research. Shovel testing revealed a disturbed context and no artifacts.
invest: No further investigations at this site are recommended.
regist: This site is not considered potentially eligible for inclusion on the NRHP.
disc_desc: At the time that the data was collected for the 1930 soil map, a local road that would be incorporated into US 380 extended eastward from Farmersville.  CR 547 had not yet been built.  Several structures are depicted along the future US 380 in the vicinity of the foundation site.  It is not definite, however, that any of the structures shown on the map is one whose foundation is located at GMI-12.4.  Beyond burned fragments of linoleum and asphalt, the site is devoid of artifacts.  Because this site cannot yield data beyond the presence of a structure, GMI-12.4 is not recommended as eligible for inclusion in the NRHP.

env_desc: The site straddles a low finger ridge, which forms the heart of a wide terrace above the floodplains common to both the Big Creek and Cedar Creek. The soils are very deep sands 130+ cm with a pale brown to yellow color. The vegetation consists of cedar, oak, greenbriar, some yucca, and a light scatter of grasses.; The site straddles a low, semi-circular finger ridge or toe-slope, which forms the heart of a wide terrace extending into the floodplain common to both Big Creek to the east and Cedar Creek to the southwest. The soils are very deep sands, 130 to below 160 cmbs, with a pale brown to yellow color. The vegetation consists of cedar, oak, greenbriar, some yucca, and a occasionally thick scatter of tall prairie grasses, featuring bahiagrass, in the open areas.
time_desc: Prehistoric lithic materials recovered from shovel tests.; Recovered from undisturbed tests several diagnostics:Late Preh.:Grog-TemperedCeramics; TransitionalArchaic:Sandy Paste Ware; Middle-Late Archaic:Williams Point.
basis: Indications of bimodal distribution of finds with
cult_desc: No cultural features are visible on the surface. The zone of the site at the west end produced more quartzite than chert debitage, and produced 3 of the 5 FCR. Further testing would be required to determine whether these statistical variances are significantly indicitave of a distinctive feature. A modern fence, marking a property boundary, runs NW-SE through the northeast edge of the site.; No cultural features nor any artifacts were found  visible on the surface. The zone of the site at the west end produced more quartzite than chert debitage and 3 of the 5 FCR  found during September 2003 survey, as originally recorded in site form.  Especially high densities were found in shovel tests at top of ridge running N-S, perpendular to proposed pipeline right-of-way.  Further testing is required to determine whether these statistical variances are significantly indicative of a distinctive feature.

value: Sufficiently abundant artifacts were recovered and sufficient areas of in-tact matrix were encountered to regard this site as holding potential for future research. Accordingly, it remains unknown whether it is eligible for inclusion in the NRHP or for listing as a SAL.; Sufficiently abundant artifacts were recovered, with diagnistics of three prehistoric periods, and sufficient areas of intact matrix were encountered to regard this site as holding potential for future research that might benefit understanding of past cultural activity in Texas. Accordingly, it remains unknown whether it is eligible for inclusion in the NRHP or for listing as a SAL.
invest: Testing should take place if adverse impacts of this site are anticipated.
disc_desc:
The site is situated on a wide, ridged terrrace rising out the floodplain between the Big Creek, extending to the northwest and Cedar Creek, to the northeast. The vegetation on the terrace dense in isolated points but not impenetrable. The pale yellow to pale brown, loose, loamy sand soils are deep, extending deeper than 130 cm. Twenty seven shovel tests were placed on the site, 17 of which were positive with prehistoric cultural resources. The eastern edge of the site was delineated by two negative tests situated along the centerline of the proposed Crider 1 Access Road (see attached site map). The East area consists of 9 positive tests, the Central area, four positive tests, and the West zone, four positive tests.  The middle tests of the East area are the densest, with three tests exceeding 10 artifacts each. Each of the Central and West tests contain less than 5 artifacts, except for the most westerly test, which contains 11. The two former areas feature approximately four times more chert debitage than quartzite and petrified wood debitage; however, the West Zone features quartzite as the raw material of choice for lithic manufacturing. Three of the five FCR's are located in the West. Vertically, there appears to be a bimodal distribution, with the upper mode being between 20 and 70 cmbs, and the lower mode situated between 90 and 160 cmbs. The statistical significance of these horizontal and vertical changes await future research.; The site is situated on a wide, terrace rising out the floodplain between Big Creek, receiving runoff to the west, and Cedar Creek, receiving runoff to the southeast. Approximately 60% of site area is mixed hardwood forest that occasionally has thick underbrush on the toe-slope but not impenetrable. The pale yellow to pale brown, loose, loamy sand soils are deep, extending between 130 to below 160 cmbs. During the September 2004 pipeline survey 21 shovel tests were placed within and along the periphery of the site, 14 of which were positive with prehistoric cultural resources.

The SE edge of the site was delineated by two consecutive negative tests situated along the centerline of the proposed Crider 1 Pipeline, with a third negative test situated 10 m S of the easternmost positive test in this centerline (see attached site map). The three positive tests in the SE Edge Area, in descending order of density, contained 7, 5, and 1 artifacts, respectively.

The SW edge of the site was delineated by two consecutive negative tests situated along the centerline of this same Pipeline, with a third negative test situated 10 m S of the westernmost positive test in this centerline (see attached site map). The two positive tests in the SW Edge Area, contained 1 artifact each.

The S edge of the site was delineated by one negative test located 20 m SE of the positive ST 64, containing 3 finds, one of which was the high quality black chert Williams projectile point found in ST 64, buried in undisturbed very fine white sand with clay peds 90-100 cmbs.

The upper toe-slope area situated between these edges consists of 8 STs, all positive. The three centrally located tests, situated just W of the N-S ridge, in descending order of density, contained 55, 28, and 24 artifacts, respectively, with the recovery of several diagnostic artifacts from this central cluster. Eleven grog-tempered sherds were found in ST 62, buried in undisturbed fine loamy sand 40-50 cmbs. ST 61 produced one quartzite scraper in undisturbed fine loamy sand 85-95 cmbs and one sandy-paste sherd in very loose white sand 120-140 cmbs. The  two SE-slope STs, situated just E of the N-S ridge, in descending order of density, contained 42 and 15 artifacts, respectively. The three SW-slope STs, situated mid-way down-slope from the ridge, in descending order of density, contained 21, 9, and 1 artifacts, respectively, with 1 sandy-paste sherd being recovered from ST 50, buried in undisturbed very loose white sand 125-135 cmbs. From the distribution of artifact totals per shovel test across the spine of the toe-slope, one notices highest density in the center, second highest density midway down the SE slope, and the lowest density mid-way down the SW slope.

From these data, one infers that the greatest amount of, and most varied, cultural activity occurred along the N-S ridge spine, forming the core of the site. However, within each of these three clusters, the internal varation is sufficiently great that the lowest number in the center is lower than the highest in the other two clusters, reflecting uneven distributions within the overall toe-slope. There appears no statistically significant difference in raw material percentages (i.e. chert-quartzite-petrified wood) in any of these clusters, although a slightly higher quartzite proportional presence is noticed in the SE-Slope Cluster. The three Edge Areas are of lower density  than any of the three toe-slope clusters, with the SE Edge Area having significantly greater artifact numbers than those found in the S and SW Edge Areas.

This site clearly holds a degree of importance in the three time periods for which diagnostic artifacts have been identified. The total of 213 artifacts retrieved in this September 2004 survey and more than 50 finds collected in the original September 2003 survey reflect heavy cultural presence over many years within each of those time frames, and possibly additional years for which no diagnostics have yet been found. The presence of 13 Ceramics and 21 fire-cracked rocks reflect a measure of permanence that the typical ephemeral hunting campsite or lithic chipping station -- both of which in central and eastern Texas are typically found as low-density lithic scatters -- does not contain.  The close proximity of this site to Big Creek, which appears to have been a steady source of water for several millennia, and its elevated nature so as to avoid frequent flooding, correspond with the typical habitation that is seasonally occupied by entire families of men, women, and children. This site holds the potential for producing significant research that would make important contributions to enhanced understanding of archaeology in Texas.
attachmem: GPS-generated site map, augmented by compass and pace method.

1 chert Plainview projectile point, basal and lateral fragment.
1 large granite-like cylindrical-slightly spherical-sherd-like fragment, exhibiting striations on edges of both faces, 1 quartzite stone with two concave faces at right angles, exhibiting polishing and wear, likely used for grinding foods.

42 Chert,  14 Quartzite, 1 Petrified Wood debitage.
2 Unidentified mammal bone

Two tools were identified as a possible quartzite hammerstone recovered from 50 to 60 cm below the ground surface and a utilized secondary chert flake or "expedient tool" recovered from 90 to 100 cm below ground surface.

Additional archaeological study of this site would enhance understanding of past cultural activity in Texas. The large amount of artifacts and spatial distribution makes site especially valuable for deriving greater understanding about prehistoric lifeways along Big Creek.  The site should be preserved from adverse impacts. It remains unknown whether it is eligible for inclusion in the NRHP or worthy for designation as a SAL.
invest: Additional archaeological testing recommended if further impacts are threatened.; Additional archaeological testing recommended.
disc_desc:
The presence of fire-cracked rock (n=7) indicates some degree of permanence to the occupation; however, the site likely represents a temporary hunting and collecting camp utilizing a ridge slope near a tributary. It is also possible that the site represents two distinct periods of occupation as a bimodal distribution for artifacts is indicated for a few shovel tests; however, further work would be required to support this supposition.; The site is situated in pastureland on the western slope of a broad finger ridge or toe-slope approximately 225 meters west of Big Creek where it is situated farthest to the east and 60 meters west of Big Creek at its closest approach to NE corner of site. Less than 20% of site area is mixed hardwood forest that occasionally has thick underbrush on the maximum slope, which approaches 7%. The pale yellow to pale brown sandy loam and loamy sand soils are deep, extending between 70 to 160 cmbs. During the September 2004 pipeline survey 23 shovel tests were placed within and along the periphery of the site, 17 of which were positive with prehistoric cultural resources.

The NW edge of the site was delineated by one negative test that, when combined with two nearby negative tests from the October 2003 survey, formed consecutive negative tests situated along the centerline of the proposed Crider 1 Pipeline (see attached site map), thereby delineating the NW edge of the site. The five positive tests in the upland terrace NW Edge Area, in descending order of density and also from S to N, produced 7, 6, 3, 2, and 1 artifacts, respectively, demonstrating that core of site is to S.

The NE edge of the site was delineated by two consecutive negative tests that are situated along the centerline of this same Pipeline (see attached site map), thereby delineating the NE limits of the site. The four positive tests in the maximum-slopes facing E toward Big Creek in the NE Edge Area, in descending order of density, produced 7, 7, 6, and 4 artifacts, respectively, featuring the Plainview Point basal-lateral fragment found in ST 44, in undisturbed mottled sand 85-95 cmbs.

The terrace and uppermost slope, constituting the middle of the site as traversed by the proposed Crider No. 1 pipeline, is situated between these edges consists of 10 STs, 8 being positive. A transect of six tests situated at 10-m intervals is located 30 m (100 ft) E  jof the NW Edge Area tests. The five positive of these six STs, in descending order of density and also from S to N, , contained 16, 15, 2, 1, and 1 artifacts, respectively, demonstrating that core of site is to S. This pattern is similar to that discovered for the NW Edge Area, reinforcing the interpretation that the central cultural activity area lies south of the proposed  pipeline and the north limits lie immediately north of the tested corridor. Furthermore, the especially abrupt decrease in artifact counts seems to correspond to a thinning of the sandy loam soils from more than 130 cm thick to less than 70 cm thick to the N, along the NE rim of the terrace as it begins sloping toward Big Creek.

A group of four SE-slope STs is situated just beyond the rim on increasing slopages. The three positive of these STs, in descending order of density, produced 3, 2, and 2 artifacts, respectively. The low density of artifacts throughout this upper slope combines with the low density of the rim of the terrace to produce a wide swath of uniformly light scatter separating two distinct zones of moderately high artifact density, one located just south of the proposed pipeline and the other located in the NE Edge Area, which contains the Plainview point fragment. One therefore infers that the greatest amount of, and most varied, cultural activity occurred in these distinct areas separated by more than 40 m of light buried scatter. There appears to be a somewhat higher percentage of cherts in the sloped area, i.e. that containing the Plainview Point, as raw material percentages (i.e. chert-quartzite-petrified wood) between these two high-density areas are compared. Higher numbers of artifacts from larger units would be necessary for statistically significant numbers to be attained to render this contrast as meaningful.

This site is of high significance, as a diagnostic , a Plainview basal-lateral point fragment, was found in an undisturbed context and has been dated the early part of the Late Paleoindian period. The total of 86 artifacts retrieved from 17 STs in this September 2004 survey and more than 20 finds collected from 14 positive STs in the original September 2003 survey reflect steady cultural presence over many years within at least one time frame, the Late Paleoindian, and possibly additional periods for which no diagnostics have yet been found. The presence of 18 fire-cracked rocks reflect a measure of permanence that the typical ephemeral hunting campsite or lithic chipping station -- both of which in central and eastern Texas are typically found as low-density lithic scatters -- does not contain these numbers.  The close proximity of this site to Big Creek, which appears to have been a steady source of water for several millennia, and its elevated nature so as to avoid frequent flooding, correspond with the typical habitation that is seasonally occupied by entire families of men, women, and children. This site holds the potential for producing significant research that would make important contributions to enhanced understanding of archaeology in Texas.
The presence of fire-cracked rock (n=7) indicates some degree of permanence to the occupation; however, the site likely represents a temporary hunting and collecting camp utilizing a ridge slope near a tributary. It is also possible that the site represents two distinct periods of occupation as a bimodal distribution for artifacts is indicated for a few shovel tests; however, further work would be required to support this supposition.

Further testing is required to determine whether these statistical variances are significantly indicative of a distinctive feature.. The presence of fire-cracked rock (n=7) indicates some degree of permanence to the occupation; however, the site likely represents a temporary hunting and collecting camp utilizing a ridge slope near a tributary. It is also possible that the site represents two distinct periods of occupation as a bimodal distribution for artifacts is indicated for a few shovel tests; however, further work would be required to support this supposition.; The site is situated in pastureland on the western slope of a broad finger ridge or toe-slope approximately 225 meters west of Big Creek where it is situated farthest to the east and 60 meters west of Big Creek at its closest approach to NE corner of site. Less than 20% of site area is mixed hardwood forest that occasionally has thick underbrush on the maximum slope, which approaches 7%. The pale yellow to pale brown sandy loam and loamy sand soils are deep, extending between 70 to 160 cmbs. During the September 2004 pipeline survey 23 shovel tests were placed within and along the periphery of the site, 17 of which were positive with prehistoric cultural resources.

The NW edge of the site was delineated by one negative test that, when combined with two nearby negative tests from the October 2003 survey, formed consecutive negative tests situated along the centerline of the proposed Crider 1 Pipeline (see attached site map), thereby delineating the NW edge of the site. The five positive tests in the upland terrace NW Edge Area, in descending order of density and also from S to N, produced 7, 6, 3, 2, and 1 artifacts, respectively, demonstrating that core of site is to S.

The NE edge of the site was delineated by two consecutive negative tests that are situated along the centerline of this same Pipeline (see attached site map), thereby delineating the NE limits of the site. The four positive tests in the maximum-slopes facing E toward Big Creek in the NE Edge Area, in descending order of density, produced 7, 7, 6, and 4 artifacts, respectively, featuring the Plainview Point basal-lateral fragment found in ST 44, in undisturbed mottled sand 85-95 cmbs.

The terrace and uppermost slope, constituting the middle of the site as traversed by the proposed Crider No. 1 pipeline, is situated between these edges consists of 10 STs, 8 being positive. A transect of six tests situated at 10-m intervals is located 30 m (100 ft) E  jof the NW Edge Area tests. The five positive of these six STs, in descending order of density and also from S to N, , contained 16, 15, 2, 1, and 1 artifacts, respectively, demonstrating that core of site is to S. This pattern is similar to that discovered for the NW Edge Area, reinforcing the interpretation that the central cultural activity area lies south of the proposed  pipeline and the north limits lie immediately north of the tested corridor. Furthermore, the especially abrupt decrease in artifact counts seems to correspond to a thinning of the sandy loam soils from more than 130 cm thick to less than 70 cm thick to the N, along the NE rim of the terrace as it begins sloping toward Big Creek.

A group of four SE-slope STs is situated just beyond the rim on increasing slopages. The three positive of these STs, in descending order of density, produced 3, 2, and 2 artifacts, respectively. The low density of artifacts throughout this upper slope combines with the low density of the rim of the terrace to produce a wide swath of uniformly light scatter separating two distinct zones of moderately high artifact density, one located just south of the proposed pipeline and the other located in the NE Edge Area, which contains the Plainview point fragment. One therefore infers that the greatest amount of, and most varied, cultural activity occurred in these distinct areas separated by more than 40 m of light buried scatter. There appears to be a somewhat higher percentage of cherts in the sloped area, i.e. that containing the Plainview Point, as raw material percentages (i.e. chert-quartzite-petrified wood) between these two high-density areas are compared. Higher numbers of artifacts from larger units would be necessary for statistically significant numbers to be attained to render this contrast as meaningful.

This site is of high significance, as a diagnostic , a Plainview basal-lateral point fragment, was found in an undisturbed context and has been dated the early part of the Late Paleoindian period. The total of 86 artifacts retrieved from 17 STs in this September 2004 survey and more than 20 finds collected from 14 positive STs in the original September 2003 survey reflect steady cultural presence over many years within at least one time frame, the Late Paleoindian, and possibly additional periods for which no diagnostics have yet been found. The presence of 18 fire-cracked rocks reflect a measure of permanence that the typical ephemeral hunting campsite or lithic chipping station -- both of which in central and eastern Texas are typically found as low-density lithic scatters -- does not contain these numbers.  The close proximity of this site to Big Creek, which appears to have been a steady source of water for several millennia, and its elevated nature so as to avoid frequent flooding, correspond with the typical habitation that is seasonally occupied by entire families of men, women, and children. This site holds the potential for producing significant research that would make important contributions to enhanced understanding of archaeology in Texas.
The presence of fire-cracked rock (n=7) indicates some degree of permanence to the occupation; however, the site likely represents a temporary hunting and collecting camp utilizing a ridge slope near a tributary. It is also possible that the site represents two distinct periods of occupation as a bimodal distribution for artifacts is indicated for a few shovel tests; however, further work would be required to support this supposition.. Preliminary GPR has indicated 24 unmarked graves in the southeast corner of the 25 acre tract of land.

desc_loc: Site is located within Airport Road (initially identified during survey for road construction) immediately south of Enloe Road; Site is recorded within and east of S Airport Drive, approximately 13.5 m south of Enloe Road.; The site is immediately south of Enloe Road and approximately 100 m east of the intersection of Enloe and Anthony roads

env_desc: Natural landscape position would be immediately adjacent to the unnamed drainage. However, this has been heavily altered by the construction of Airport Drive; The site is located near the north edge of a much larger upland area.  Extensive iris and jonquil beds were noted in the northeast portion of the site, while several large pecan trees were found along Enloe Road.  A line of smaller hackberry trees runs perpendicular to Enloe Road; evidence of a demolished chain link fence was noted along this tree line.; Within the floodplain and terrace edge north of an unnamed tributary of the East Fork Trinity River. Majority of site has been destroyed for the construction of the four lane (with approx. 10 m wide grass medium) Airport Road. The remaining eastern half of the site has been heavily disturbed by the construction of the road, but remains a tall grass field with sparse mature hardwoods.
time_desc: Artifacts observed; Pervious site records; Previous investigations
basis: Artifacts observed; Pervious site records only noted artifacts from one time period; Previous Investigations
cult_desc: GMI reported the site to consist of eight features and a low density surface scatter of various glass types, ceramics, and bricks. The features included concrete tanks, pads, walls, a manhole, pipe, brick-lined well, a washer, and concentration of bricks (THC 2016). SWCA found no remaining features during their 2016 survey.; Previous site recorders in 2005 noted eight features including concrete tanks, pads, walls, maintenance hole, pipe, brick-lined well, a washer, and brick concentration. Previous site recorders in 2016 noted the site completely destroyed by road construction. The current site visit recorded no cultural features.; Several features were observed at the site.  Feature 1 consisted of a manhole labeled "Water Meter" adjacent to a large galvanized pipe about 2 inches in diameter and extending an estimated 4 ft above ground surface.  Feature 2 consists of a much smaller pipe (ca. 3/4 in) protruding at an angle from the ground.  There was an odd, unidentified fitting at the free end of the pipe.  It is speculated that this is a gas line.  Feature 3 is a concrete tank (presumably a watering trough) approximately 1.5-x-1.5 in size and 1.2 m tall.  The top of the feature is at an angle, with the highest point found on the west side.  Feature 4 is a small concentration of bricks that appear to be fitted together.  It is about 40-x-40 cm in size and does not extend above ground surface.  Feature 4 is thought to represent the remains of a brick pier.  Feature 5 consists of two parallel, partial concrete walls about 2 m apart.  Parts of the concrete walls have been pushed into the interior space, which appears to be a rubble-filled depression.  A large roll of chain link fence was also noted in the interior.  Feature 5 may represent a razed foundation or perhaps a filled-in storm cellar.  Feature 6 was assigned to an abandoned washer noted on the surface.  Feature 7 is an old, brick-lined well that has been largely filled and covered by concrete slabs.  A small part of the brick lining was visible under one of the concrete slabs.  A 3/4" galvanized pipe was noted along the north edge of the well that extends approximately 1 ft above surface.  This pipe was probably used to fill the adjacent water trough (Feature 3).   Feature 8 consists of concrete pad associated with a modern water line that was found along the drainage south of the site.  The pad is approximately 60 cm square and has been so badly undercut by erosion that it can move on the underlying pipe.  In addition, unnumbered features include a gravel-covered rise beginning at the gate along Enloe Road that is thought to be the driveway to the site and a treeline in the eastern part of the site that appears to follow a demolished fence line.
basis_size: Previous site records; Site was not relocated-has been destroyed; Surface scatter, features
artifact:
A low density surface scatter was observed at the site that included: salt-glazed stoneware; manganese, brown, clear, aqua, and green bottle glass; window glass; metal fragments; machine- and hand-made brick; part of a chromed car bumper (probably '30s or '40s); pink and gray granite fragments; extensive limestone gravels; a zinc fruit jar cap with Genuine Boyd's liner; valve marked fruit jar base; sewer pipe; ivory tinted whiteware with maker's mark "Buffalo by Oneida/9058" with a picture of a buffalo depicted in black above the inscription; white porcelain insulators; porcelain vessel fragments; an ironstone fragment with a light blue transfer printed decoration, probably from a deep, ocatgonally shaped vessel; a cut nail; and bakelite.

Shovel testing was much less productive, with only two pieces of clear bottle glass, a piece of gray granite, a brass shotgun shell, a wire nail, and a piece of late ironstone being found, primarily in the upper 10 cm.  These materials were identified in the field and were not collected.; GMI reported the site to consist of eight features and a low density surface scatter of various glass types, ceramics, and bricks. The features included concrete tanks, pads, walls, a manhole, pipe, brick-lined well, a washer, and concentration of bricks (THC 2016). SWCA found no remaining features or artifact scatters during their 2016 survey.; No materials observed
circum: Destruction from Airport Rd construction; tall grasses; Overcast, moderate temperatures, covered with short grasses, moderate (est. 30%) ground surface visibility; Road is constructed in site
intact: 0% of site remaining intact; Little to none - site has been destroyed; Poor; site was demolished by bulldozing
landuse: Cattle pasture; Remaining portion of site is abandoned; Roadway
artificial: Road construction and associated drainage landscaping, underground utility installation; Site was demolished through bulldozing; traffic
future: Additional proposed road construction; The future Airport Road will be constructed through the site area; water pipeline
value: Although the presence of a cut nail and a octagonal ironstone vessel fragment indicate that the site was first occupied in the mid to late nineteenth century, it was not abandoned until some time after 1969.  This, combined with the relatively shallow deposits noted, suggests that any early deposits are thoroughly mixed with more recent materials.  In addition, the site appears to have been razed by bulldozing.  These factors are thought to give site MG1 little remaining research potential; consequently, it is recommended as ineligible for inclusion on the NRHP or for nomination as a SAL.; Given the lack of integrity of the deposits, the lack of intact cultural material, and the current investigation within the proposed right-of-way, it is SWCA?s opinion that the site will not aid in better understanding of the local or regional history of the area.
invest: No further work; SWCA recommends the remainder of the site as NOT ELIGBLE for inclusion in the NRHP and no further work is necessary.
regist: Ineligible 2/7/2005 and 12/1/2016; Site has been destroyed
disc_desc: Based on the artifacts observed at site MG-1, it was first occupied in the mid- to late nineteenth century.  A structure is illustrated in this area in the USGS McKinney East quadrangle (1960, photorevised 1968, photoinspected 1973).  In addition, two buildings are visible on the aerial photos published with the Soil Survey of Collin County, Texas (Hanson and Wheeler 1969).  The smaller building nearer the road probably represents the house, while the larger building visible close to the drainage south of the site is probably a barn.  The site appears to be bulldozed based on the heavily undulating ground surface noted in the west part of the site, the razing noted at Feature 5, and the highly mottled soils noted in Shovel Tests S2 and M4.; Previous (2016) surveyors noted no remaining cultural materials or features. Current investigations recorded not cultural materials or features.; Site 41COL168 is a previously recorded historic homestead located on Airport Road in eastern McKinney, Texas. The site was initially recorded by Geo-Marine, Inc. (GMI) in 2005 during survey of the then proposed Airport Road for the City of McKinney (THC 2016). GMI reported the site to consist of eight features and a low density surface scatter of various glass types, ceramics, and bricks. The features included concrete tanks, pads, walls, a manhole, pipe, brick-lined well, a washer, and concentration of bricks (THC 2016). During GMI?s 2005 investigation the site had already been heavily impacted by bulldozing and land clearing. They recommended site 41COL168 as NOT ELIGIBLE, and Airport Road has since been built through the majority of the site.    SWCA?s 2016 investigation of site 41COL168 was focused on the eastern portion of the site now located on the side of Airport Road. The site is located upslope and north of an intermittent drainage and the portion remaining consists of short grass vegetation with sparse mature hardwoods. The projects proposed centerline parallels with the edge of Airport Road and consists of the disturbed roadside berm. Pedestrian survey of site 41COL168 identified no remaining features or scatters of cultural material.   A total of six negative shovel tests were excavated to test the site for buried cultural material or features (AE6 to AE8, and PN5 to PN7). All shovel tests were negative for cultural material and heavily disturbed. A typical shovel test consisted of black clay loam (10YR2/1) with termination occurring from 30 to 40 cmbs due to firm clay. No cultural features or material was identified within the excavated shovel tests.  Site 41COL168 is an historic homestead that likely dates to the early to late twentieth century. Given the lack of integrity of the deposits, the lack of intact cultural material, and the current investigation within the proposed right-of-way, it is SWCA?s opinion that the site will not aid in better understanding of the local or regional history of the area. SWCA recommends the remainder of the site as NOT ELIGBLE for inclusion in the NRHP and no further work is necessary.

1.  Copy of the topo map showing the site location
2.  Plan map of the site; shapefile

explain: No Data; Historic materials and features present
records: daily journal, map drawings, digital prints, digital print log
desc_loc: The site is located approximately 540 m west of Robinson Road and 700 m south of Mayfield Road in Grand Prairie, TX.  It is located inside a stand of hardwood trees a cultivated field.  The site is approximately midway between Mayfield Road to the north and Fish Creek to the south.
water: Fish Creek, 950 m to the south
env_desc: The site occurs in a cultivated field within a thin stand of small to medium-size hardwood trees.  Ground vegetation consists of a thin covering of grass and scrub.  Ground surface is level and the site is situated on a large terrace that overlooks Fish Creek to the south.  The site is approximately 950 m north of the creek.
time_desc: Historic materials (corrugated metal, wire nails, machine-made bricks) and features (well) present
cult_desc: Remnants of a wood and metal structure occur inside a thin scatter of trees in a cultivated field.  The major portion consists of a square 3 m x 3 m wooden frame covered with sheets of corrugated metal and fastened with wire nails.  A scatter of boards and sheets of metal extends approximately 5 m north of this segment.  A possible well is located approximately 60 m northeast of the structural remains at the northern edge of the treeline.  This feature consists of a round concrete base approximately 30 cm in diameter with a smaller hole bored into the concrete.  Four iron corner posts spaced roughly 2 m apart form a square around the concrete base.
basis_size: Estimation of distribution of surface materials
artifact: Remants of wood and corrugated metal structure, machine-made bricks with mortar, wooden boards with wire nails, metal cans
circum: The ground was heavily saturated with water from recent rains; therefore, no shovel tests were excavated.
landuse: Vacant wooded area within cultivated field
value: Research value is limited due to the recentness and condition of the site,
disc_desc: The site consists of the remnants of a 3 m x 3 m segment of a corrugated metal and wood structure, the possible remains of a well, and small amounts of refuse and architectural debris.  The structure likely repesents an outbuilding and no evidence of a domestic structure (e.g., foundation or chimney) was identified.  Two structures, including one that is abandoned, appear on the topographic map of the area where the remnants of the outbuilding were identified.  Their presence on the 1959 map and the materials identified (wire nails, machine-made bricks), suggest that the site post-dates 1900.  The recentness of the site and type and condition of the materials present indicate limited research potential. The site is approximately 650 m north of 41DL353, a scatter of historic architectural debris and may be related.
attachmem:
Copy of site plotted on 7.5' USGS topographic map
Sketch map of site

Burleson Clay, 0 to 1 percent slopes. The site occurs in a cultivated field within a thin stand of small to medium-size hardwood trees.  Ground vegetation consists of a thin covering of grass and scrub.  Ground surface is level and the site is situated on a large terrace that overlooks Fish Creek to the south. This feature consists of a round concrete base approximately 30 cm in diameter with a smaller hole bored into the concrete.  Four iron corner posts spaced roughly 2 m apart form a square around the concrete base.. desc_loc: This is a small lake era trash deposit in a low area along an abandoned road bed.  The site area is located on a gentle slope about 300 feet downslope to the west of an old farmstead (20th century) and earlier style artifacts in the trash deposit may be from the old homestead.
