env_desc: uplands slope, in old abandoned road swale, in dense woods
cult_desc: surface trash in low area along abandoned road bed
artifact: 1 blue marbled enamal tinware pan, galvanized bucket, misc. machine rolled can fragments, clear and aqua glass cola bottles, brown beer bottles (misc. dates from 1940 to 1970), aqua window glass, misc scrap tin and wire nails.
future: none, but next to a proposed new fenceline on the USCOE property boundary
regist: may or may not be actually old enough to consider as an archeological resource
disc_desc: This trash was placed in the swale of an abandoned road bed about 300 feet down slope from a twentieth century homestead.  It is presumed that the road was one of many closed by the Corps of Engineers when then Lake Texoma was built (opened to the public in 1943).  Earlier style artifacts and domestic trash (window pane glass, enamaled tinware, etc.) suggests the trash may have come from a homestead a short distance upslope (as secondary deposits).

desc_loc: Small and very disturbed lithic scatter located on a bech terrace facing the Red River Valley to the northeast.  The terrace is about a third of the way upslope on the valley wall bluff line.  A lease road in the Handy Oilfield runs paralell along the bluff top above the site.  A recently cleared pathway extends along the USCOE fenceline through the site area.  The bench terrace covers about 10 X 20 meters and has been mostly impacted by the cleared pathway.  A light scatter of fire cracked quartzite rocks, blank chert flakes and decortication flakes of local silicifies phosphate were found on the terrace (artifact density is roughly 1 artifact per 3 meters).

disc_desc: This is a temporary encampment on a bench terrace on the valley wall of the Red River Valley.  Boiling stones and flakes preclude identifying the type of encampment (or purpose for camping), but the site is typical of area forager camps.  A lane 30 feet wide has recently been cleared across the site for construction of a new fence line and the majority of the site has been disturbed.  A lack of cultural temporal material and shalloow/disturbed surface soils preclude archeological value to the location beyond this recording.

explain: No Data; Two loci of limestone rock piles thought to be associated with lime production.
projname: Archaeological Survey of the Proposed Jacksboro Landfill Site, Jack County, Tex
desc_loc: From the intersection of FM 2210 and SH 199 go south along 184 compass bearing for 2.667 Km/1.657 mi to two eroded hillsides overlooking Jasper Creek. Two loci, consisting of piles of limestone rock, are scattered along the slopes.
env_desc: Site is on eroded hillside. Mesquite and prickly pear cacti are abundant. Severe erosion present in and around the site area.
time_desc: Thought to be part of lime production, but no diagnostics present to date when quarrying began.
basis: Probably associated with the first stage of lime p
cult_desc: Two loci are present within site. Loci I or Field I consists of 19 piles of rock on the slope of a southwest facing hill. Loci II or Field II consists of 25 piles of rock on a slope south of Loci I. Piles of rock range from 0.25 to 1 m in height.
artifact: piles of limestone rock, some broken by sledge-hammer.
future: Within the foodprint of the Jacksboro Landfill.
regist: Site is not eligible for any of the four registration details
disc_desc: Based on data from the internet and discussion at TEXARCH-L this is a site that is the beginning of lime production. Apparently specific types of limestone was preferred, such as high and dry, very compact, good consistiency. It was then transported to a lime kiln(s) where it was reduced to powder. The advent of the railroad bringing in portland cement made production of lime, via this method, not very cost effective. There are no artifacts, or any other objects for that matter, associated with this site. Indeed, we can only infer that the rocks are for lime production. No lime kilns are present in the immediate area and the nearest town, Gibtown to the south, does not have any remnants of lime production.
attachmem: copy of GPS reading of each rock pile (NAD 83), copy of USGS map

disc_desc: Site is currently broken down as a complex consisting of 5 archiac (middle to late) concentrations and 1 historic area.  There is a spring which flows year round rocked some claim by Native Americans, others say settlers did this.  There is an extensive midden deposite, an area which may produce a heart field, several other areas where subsurface hearths are thought to be.  Most of this site has been looted for a long time and in some areas open pits still exist (although heavily eroded).  Some human remains have been found as well thought to be eroding out of soils within the midden deposit.  (see attached report).

desc_loc: Go south 0.75 miles along FM934 from Blanton, TX. Turn west 0.1 miles to a sharp bend in CR1446; the site is on the inside of the bend.
ownerinfo: William M. Lourcey Jr. P.O. Box 470279 Fort Worth, TX. 76147
env_desc: The site is located on a side slope of an upland projection that overlooks a intermitant tributary of Aquilla Creek.The area supports a cover of pasture grasses with dense clumps of oak and privet.
cult_desc: The centerline of the pipeline crosses the backyard of this housesite. The yard, which is ca. 60 x 60 m, is defined by a barbed wire fence on the north and west. A fenced lane leads off the northwest corner of the yard to a corrigated tin equipment shed and the back of the asbestos sided, shingle roofed house. There is also a small wood frame shed at the southeast corner of the yard near a gate that opens onto CR1446. A porceline sink sits near the northeast corner of this shed. Various other pieces of equipment are scattered across the yard including a trailer, a field disc, a chisel plow, galvenized tin sheets (probably off the roof of the shed) and a vehical fender.
basis_top: Surface features and artifact scatter in yard
artifact: Farm machinery, galvenized tin sheeting, glass from a vehical headlight or windsheild. All of these artifacts were within the yard behind the house.
circum: Hot and sunny, 105 F, soils extreemely hard and dry
natural: Erosion along a small gully that crosses the southwest corner f the yard
value: Limited do to the sites recent age
disc_desc: Only the backyard will be affected by pipeline construction. The house and equipement shed should remain intact as they are out of the right-of-way. Because of their distance from the pipeline the area around the house and shed was not shovel tested and structure demetions were not mapped as we did not have permission to survey beyond the right-of-way.

The site is located on a side slope of an upland projection that overlooks a intermitant tributary of Aquilla Creek.The area supports a cover of pasture grasses with dense clumps of oak and privet.. Structures present at the site.. The centerline of the pipeline crosses the backyard of this housesite. The yard, which is ca. 60 x 60 m, is defined by a barbed wire fence on the north and west. A fenced lane leads off the northwest corner of the yard to a corrigated tin equipment shed and the back of the asbestos sided, shingle roofed house. There is also a small wood frame shed at the southeast corner of the yard near a gate that opens onto CR1446. A porceline sink sits near the northeast corner of this shed. Various other pieces of equipment are scattered across the yard including a trailer, a field disc, a chisel plow, galvenized tin sheets (probably off the roof of the shed) and a vehical fender.. Only the backyard will be affected by pipeline construction. The house and equipement shed should remain intact as they are out of the right-of-way. Because of their distance from the pipeline the area around the house and shed was not shovel tested and structure demetions were not mapped as we did not have permission to survey beyond the right-of-way.. desc_loc: Proceed from the west side of the cemetery at Blanton, Tx.  0.85 miles northwest. The site is situated on the westside an old county road that is now used only as a pasture road.
env_desc: The site is located on an upland projection overlooking the headwaters of an intermittant tributary of Aquilla Creek. Pasture surrounds the house, while pecan, mesquite, oak, and catalpa trees occur near the remains of the structure.
cult_desc: The house and any out buildings that were associated with it have been removed. However, the there is the remains of  a few intact sandstone footers an other sandstone rubble in an overgrown weedy rise that is 30 x 23 m across. A t the northwest corner of the rise there is a sandstone block lined well that is trash filled. A driveway is present on the north side of the rise and a artifact scatter occurs along the southside of the rise.
basis_thk: Landowner would not permit shovel testing
artifact: Artifacts that occur in the surface scatter on the southside of the weed covered rise include window glass, solarized glass, cut glass with a floral pattern, a cup and saucer fragment with decal print that is a red and green rose pattern.
circum: Hot and sunny with a high of 105 F, soil extremely dry
landuse: Pasture with the site area used to stockpile hay rolls
value: Minimal due to its probable recent age
disc_desc: This site is the remains of a residential structure that once faced the old county road that passes within 10 m to the east. Pecan trees frame what was once the  front of the house. The pipeline will clip the front part of the foundation remains.

explain: No Data; This is the site of the Abernathy House, built at some time during the nineteenth century, as evidenced by the cut nail noted here.  According to the Airhart family, this site also served as a blacksmith's shop and later, as a furniture maker's shop, both in the first half of the twentieth century.  The house is said to have been abandoned before the 1940's, and collapsed sometime during the 1940's.   A notable natural feature here is the spring, located about 75 meters northwest of the Abernathy house site.  Normally, this spring is said to flow very well, and keep a small earthen tank (less than 1/8 acre) full.  During the drought of 2000, the spring was reduced to a seep, but still kept the small dug well adjacent to it completely full.  During the 1940's the Airhart family built the present house and outbuildings here.
sitename: No Data; Abernathy House site/Spring site
additional: "Three Historic Period Archaeological Sites in Northeastern Collin County, Texas.  A Preliminary Examination."    Donald Allan Dorward and Jenifer Jenike,   Archaeology & Preservation, Dallas, Texas.  Report submitted to Dixon Airhart Glaze.   September 12, 2000.
surf_tech: Controlled survey:  Full coverage of house location and spring area; perimeter walk-about.
test_meth: Limited shovel testing done only to determine general depth of deposits.
desc_loc: About 3/4 mile south of FM 545 on FM 1827, 75 meters west of the road (1827), inside the gate entrance.  Rows of bois d'arc trees lining the edge of the abandoned 22 Turns Road mark the east edge of the site.
soil_desc: Houston black clay, Altoga silty clay in the Houston Black-Austin Association
env_desc: The nineteenth century  house was sited about 75 meters north east of the spring.  The old 22 Turns Road passed immediately east of this house site.
cult_desc: No features relating to the nineteenth century occupation were recorded.  However, a shallow well and a small earthen tank were associated with the spring; these probably date to the 1940's.  The Airhart house and outbuildings dating to the 1940's are still standing.
basis_size: Brunton and tape, aerial photo, topo map
artifact: Historic Period domestic and farm-related artifacts typical of late nineteenth and early twentieth century farmstead  sites:  Cut nails, wire, bottle glass(clear, manganese solarized) found on the surface at nineteenth century house site.  Wire, wire nails, bottle glass and stiff mud (machine made) brick fragments were found in the vicinity of the spring.
circum: Visibility was good to excellent over much of the farm yard, but poor around the spring.  Weather clear and extrmely hot on all visits to the site.
landuse: Agricultural: farm yard, house and outbuildings.
natural: No significant natural impact on the site observed.
value: The work here was not designed to evaluate the potential of the site, simply to locate and record it.  Further work is recommended if the site is to be impacted in the future.
invest: Regional and project-specific work is recommended.
disc_desc: The site is the former location of the Abernathy farmstead, which probably was occupied from about 1880-1935.  The key natural feature here is the spring, which is about 75m to the west.  The Abernathy house is reported to have collapsed in the 1940's, and the site appears to be relatively undisturbed.   Between this house site and the spring was built the Airhart house along with livestock pens and outbuildings in the 1940's.  A well which is 2 meters deep and .75 meters in diameter is lined with stiff-mud common bricks marked "FERRIS."  This well is kept full by the spring which flows out of the ground less than 10 feet away.
attachmem: 7.5' USGS topo map with site plotted.

explain: No Data; Abandoned roadway; unpaved.  This old road was a main route between Chambliss and Altoga around 1900 and during the early part of the twentieth century.  Portions of FM 1827 follow old sections of this road.
additional: "Three Historic Period Archaeological Sites in Northeastern Collin County, Texas.  A Preliminary Examination."    Donald Allan Dorward and Jenifer Jenike,   Archaeology & Preservation, Dallas, Texas.  Report submitted to Dixon Airhart Glaze.   September 12, 2000.
surf_tech: Controlled survey:  All visible sections of the roadway were walked and photographed.  Bois d'arc trees line the edges of this road in several locations.
desc_loc: About 3/4 mile south of FM 545 on FM 1827, 65 meters west of the road (1827), inside the gate entrance.  Rows of bois d'arc trees lining the edge of the abandoned 22 Turns Road.  The visible road bed is about 10 meters wide, and about .9 km (9/16 mi.) long on the Airhart place.  The road is visible in several other spots toward Altoga, but these were outside of the project area.
soil_desc: Houston black clay, Altoga silty clay in the Houston Black-Austin Association
env_desc: The old road passes about 75 meters east of the spring.  It generally follows local topography at an elevation of 550-570 feet until it gains altitude on a ridge east of FM 1827.
cult_desc: No features, other than the roadbed itself and the bois d'arcs lining it  were recorded.
basis_size: Brunton and tape, aerial photo, topo map
artifact: No artifacts which could be definitively tied to the road were located.
circum: Visibility was  fair in the roadway, but no artifacts which could be tied to the road were located.  Weather clear and extremely hot on all visits to the site.
natural: No significant natural impact on the site observed.
value: The work here was not designed to evaluate the potential of the site, simply to locate and record it.  Further work is recommended if the site is to be impacted in the future.
invest: Regional and project-specific work is recommended.
disc_desc: This is an abandoned road way, which was once one of the main links between Chambliss and Altoga.  It was never paved.  The road is lined with very large bois d'arcs, which may have been planted as hedgerow in the early twentieth century.  The center of the roadbed is up to 50 cm deeper than its edges in places.  This road passed by the old Abernathy House site and the Wallis House site.
attachmem: 7.5' USGS topo map with site plotted.

explain: No Data; The site if the Wallis Home (1890-1945), occuppied by the Wallis family (1897-1945).  The house was destroyed by fire in 1945.  The site is now a field, and about 80% of the area once covered by the farmstead is plowed.
additional: "Three Historic Period Archaeological Sites in Northeastern Collin County, Texas.  A Preliminary Examination."    Donald Allan Dorward and Jenifer Jenike,   Archaeology & Preservation, Dallas, Texas.  Report submitted to Dixon Airhart Glaze.   September 12, 2000.
surf_tech: Controlled survey: 5 meter transects, perimeter walk-about.
test_meth: Limited shovel testing done only to determine general depth of deposits and to determine depth of plow zone.
desc_loc: About 1/2 mile south of FM 545 on FM 1827, 15 meters east of the road (1827), just south of field gate entrance.  Two large eastern red cedar trees mark the site of the front of the house.
soil_desc: Houston black clay, Altoga silty clay in the Houston Black-Austin Association
env_desc: The house was sited on a ridge overlooking Sister Grove Creek, which is about 600 meters to the east.  The elevation of this site is approximately 50 feet above the creek.  The site is essentially level.  The old 22 Turns Road passed immediately in front (east) of the house.
basis: Informant's family occupied the site from 1897-1945.
cult_desc: No features relating to this occupation were recorded.  However, a deep well and a cistern were on the site, according to informants.  A heavy concentration of artifacts along a treeline (former fenceline) may be the remnants of a trash midden.  About 80% of the site is plowed at this time.
artifact: Historic Period domestic and farm-related artifacts typical of late nineteenth and early twentieth century farmstead  sites:  Cut nails, wire, bottle glass(clear, manganese solarized, brown), snuff bottle fragments, white milk glass, panel bottle fragments, ribbed tumbler (clear), whiteware, stoneware, window glass, ceramic doorknob, cast iron stove eye, porcelain tableware, plowshare, bolts, can fragments.  The artifacts are fairly evenly distributed over most of the site (which has been plowed over 80% of the surface), with somewhat higher concentrations near the back of the house location and along a former fenceline (now a tree line).
circum: Visibility was excellent in the plowed area, no living plants here, some stubble from spring crop.  Weather clear and extrmely hot on all visits to the site.
landuse: Agricultural:  Plowed field over 80%, remaining 20% under trees, not plowed.
natural: No significant natural impact on the site observed.
value: The work here was not designed to evaluate the potential of the site, simply to locate and record it.  Further work is recommended if the site is to be impacted in the future.
invest: Regional and project-specific work is recommended.
disc_desc: The site is the former location of the Wallis farmstead, which was occuppied from about 1890-1945.  The Wallis family lived here from 1897 to 1945, when the house was destroyed by fire.  No standing structures remain on the site. The site is 200' E-W and 300' N-S.  A deep well and a cistern which provided water for the house are known to have existed here, but were filled in for safety reasons.  Brick fragments, which may be from the cistern were located here.  A heavier concentration of artifacts along a N-S treeline may indicate the presence of a trash midden.   Approximately 80% of the site has been plowed.  The plow zone ranges from about 10-15 cm here, as shown in shovel tests.
attachmem: 7.5' USGS topo map with site plotted.

explain: No Data; This site was recognized as a difuse surface scatter of burned rock and lithic debitage over a 7200 square meter area. Shovel tests and trenching showed that the material extended to only 25 cm below the surface. No diagnostic materials recovered.
test_meth: Six, 30 x 30 cm, shovel tests were excavated to a depth of 40 cm. Materials recovered were not collected. Also, one backhoe trench 2 m deep by 5 m long.
records: Daily Journal, Maps/Drawings, Slides, Slide Logs, Prints, Print Log, Shovel Test Records, Slide Logs, Stratigraphic Profiles
desc_loc: Go north from the junction of SH174 and FM916 east at Rio Vista, Tx. to FM916 west. Proceed along FM916 west for one mile, from this point walk SSE for 0.2 miles crossing an intermittant stream. The site is just across the stream in a fenced pasture.
ownerinfo: Dudley Family Partners,L.T.D.  10737 Sprangler Rd.  Dallas, Tx. 75220
env_desc: The site sits on two small, 50 cm high, rises in the bottomlands of the Nolan River. Though the site is in pasture the Nolan River to the west and the intermitant drainage to the north support hardwood forest.
cult_desc: No cultural features were encountered. However, the presence of burned rock suggests that rock features may once have been present.
basis_size: The extent of the surface scatter
artifact:
Burned rocks ranging in size from pea to fist sized pebbles
chert flakes
circum: Hot and sunny ca. 100-103 F, in 1998 soil was rock hard from 20 days of no rain and temperatures in the 100s.
landuse: Pature and right of way for a water pipeline
value: Limited do to the suricial nature of the site and its extensive disturbance.
disc_desc: Though six shovel tests were excavated only three (No. 7, 9, and 10) produced artifacts. Two chert flakes were recovered from ST 7 while burned rock was noted in ST 9 and 10. The site apparently does not extend into the woods north of the pasture as STs 11 and 12 placed across the fence and n the woods were negitive. A single backhoe trench (No. 1) was placed on the site in 1999 as part of exploration for deeply buried sites on the floodplain and first terrace of the Nolan River along the water pipeline right of  way. This trench comfrmed the near surficial nature of the site as only a couple of burned rock were noted in the upper 40 cm during the excavation of the trench.
attachmem: Site map and USGS Quad section with site location

explain: No Data; A subsurface scatter of historic materials.
projname: Jack County Power Plant Project and Associated Pipeline and Compressor Station
test_meth: A total of nineteen shovel tests excavated to delineate site boudnaries, 16 within boundaries of which 7 were positive.
records: map drawings, print log, prints, shovel test records
desc_loc: Site is located in the Willow Point Community.
water: Hunt Creek (300 m northwest) and a tributary of Hunt Creek (100 m east)
env_desc: Site CRS#1 lies along the edge of a low hill within a pastureland and a plowed field. Vegetation in the southern portion of the site consists of pasture grass and a few unidentified fruit trees; in the northern portion, low sparse grasses occupy the plowed field.
time_desc: Evidence of historic artifacts obeserved in shovel tests.
basis: Evidence of only historic artifacts observed.
cult_desc: A clay-lined well (approximately 1 m in diameter) lies near the center of the site covered by sandstone blocks, apparently hand cut to line the surface of the well.  Slightly to the south of the well is a shallow oval-shaped depression (5 m by 3 m), now filled with water and frequented by cattle.  At the depression's eastern edge is a built corner of squared hand-cut sandstone blocks, which appear to be all that remains of a once-standing structure.  Several additional sandstone blocks are located along the northern side of the depression, but it is not apparent whether their current placement is primary or secondary.
site_size: 250 m southwest-northeast and 15 m wide due to ROW constratints
basis_size: Based on positive shovel tests and ROW constraints.
basis_thk: Depth of artifacts observed in positive shovel tests.
artifact: Artifacts observed at the site included 6 fragments of brown glass, 3 fragments of clear glass, 1 cork top clear glass bottle neck, 2 fragments of frosted clear glass, 1 unidentified glass fragment, 2 joining fragments of brown-glazed ceramic, and 4 wrought square top nails.
circum: Warm sunny day in open field.
future: Construction for gas and water lines.
disc_desc:
Site CRS#1 is a historic site located within both pastureland and a plowed field near the community of Willow Point in Wise County.  The soil at the site is mapped as belonging to the Truce series, a brown fine sandy loam overlying red brown clay.  Vegetation in the southern portion of the site consists of pasture grass and a few unidentified fruit trees; in the northern portion, low sparse grasses occupy the plowed field.  The ground surface visibility in the pasture was estimated to be 10 to 30 percent, while that in the plowed field was considerably higher, between 60 to 90 percent.
The site was located by shovel testing, and its boundaries based on the distribution of positive shovel tests within the project ROW .  The site extends approximately 250 m from the southwest to the northeast and, due to ROW constraints, could only be determined to be 15 m wide.  A clay-lined well (approximately 1 m in diameter) lies near the center of the site covered by sandstone blocks, apparently hand cut to line the surface of the well.  Slightly to the south of the well is a shallow oval-shaped depression (5 m by 3 m), now filled with water and frequented by cattle.  At the depression's eastern edge is a built corner of squared hand-cut sandstone blocks, which appear to be all that remains of a once-standing structure.  Several additional sandstone blocks are located along the northern side of the depression, but it is not apparent whether their current placement is primary or secondary.
Shovel testing revealed soils consistent with those mapped in the area: brown to red brown fine sand over red sandy clay.  To define the site, a total of 19 shovel tests were excavated, at intervals between 10 to 30 m; of these, six proved culturally positive (ST #1, 3, 6, 11, 12, 13, and 17).  Artifacts observed at the site included 6 fragments of brown glass, 3 fragments of clear glass, 1 cork top clear glass bottle neck, 2 fragments of frosted clear glass, 1 unidentified glass fragment, 2 joining fragments of brown-glazed ceramic, and 4 wrought square top nails.  All were found within the first 10 cm of soil.  The majority of artifacts were located within the pasturage of the southern portion of the site.
Site CRS #1 consists of a clay-lined well, the built corner of a probable structural foundation, and a scatter of historic material within the first 10 cm of soil.  The site lies within pasturage and a plowed field, separated by a modern fence line and associated with two modern barns located nearby.  Impacts to the site area include wind and water erosion, plowing, and the activities of livestock.  The items found at the site are likely the remains of a historic homestead, and very possibly associated with the original Willow Point community.  The lack of other structures makes it likely that further investigation would produce little new information for our knowledge of the area.

desc_loc: at end of County Road 2221, approximately 1.1 mile east of town of Aquilla
env_desc: recently planted, clean-tilled cropland field with cotton plants just emerging; upland with gentle to moderate slope that drops off steeply to adjacent hillside that flanks Aquilla Creek
time_desc: no temporally diagnostic lithic artifacts observed; historic artifacts likely assocated with late 19th to early 20th century farmstead
basis: prehistoric lithic artifacts present in the form o
basis_size: visible extent of artifact scatter was paced out
top: artifact scatter is at surface and mixed in plowzone
basis_top: observation of freshly cut gully through edge of site
thickness: could be from surface to depth of plowing
artifact: percussion flakes of chert material (n=8) mostly less than 4cm length; unaltered quartzite cobbles also present; plow damage is apparent;  broken glass from bottles in clear, green, and purple shades; metal fragments and nails; crockery fragments; all cultural materials are evenly distributed across site
circum: clear, cold morning; near 100 percent surface visibility (clean tilled cotton field) with relatively smooth surface
intact: none of the site is intact
natural: shrink-swell properties of soil (mixing); sheet and rill erosion; gully erosion
future: construction of grassed waterway and continued cultivation
value: no important information could be gained from further study
invest: none other than this site record
disc_desc: This is an upland scatter of lithic and historic artifacts evenly distributed by cultivation across an upland surface; no intact aspect of the site remains as disturbances have moved cultural materials from primary context; a farmstead was once located here but the house has been destroyed or moved away long ago; the field has been in cultivation for decades; the area may have been occupied during central Texas prehistory for brief visits as food resources associated with the Aquilla Creek valley were exploited
attachmem: USGS topo map, aerial photo with site location and APE

records: computer disks, map drawings, shovel test records, print log, prints
desc_loc: The site is located on a hill approximately 1 mile west of US Highway 75 on CR286.
soil_desc: Collin County Soil Survey, Huston Black Clay
env_desc: The site is located on a gently sloping hillside of compact black clay. The vegetation is pasture grass, but a pumpkin garden was planted near the hill top by the landowner.
artifact:
Clear, brown, amethyst, and solarized glass
undecorated white ware, and crockery
rusted metal bits
circum: clear warm sunny day with only low vegetation
disc_desc: The site is a historic homestead  located on a hill top. The site consists of a brick-lined cistern and a surface scatter of historic materials. The cistern is only present as a hole in the ground all above surface features have been removed. As stated above the cistern is brick-lined but I was unable to closely examine the brick( the bricks were a tan color). The inside of the cistern appeared to be bell shaped. The surface scatter consisted of assorted glass, pottery, and metal bits. The frequency of the scatter was approximatly one artifact every five meters square. A total of seven shovel tests were attempted on the site, the soil was a compact black clay, none were culturally positive. One of the tests was forced to examine the extent of the clay and was halted at 60 cmbgs (only black clay was found, no other soils).

explain: No Data; historic surface scatter/lithic procurement site
records: computer disks, map drawings, shovel test records, print log, prints
desc_loc: The site is in a corn field 1.65 km east of State Highway 5 and .5 km south of county road 421.
soil_desc: Collin County Soil Survey, Burleson Dark Grey Clay
env_desc: The site is located in a mostly flat corn field, at the time of the survey the field was plowed and clear of vegetation.
artifact:
Historic: (clear, milk, amethyst, and yellow) glass,undecorated white ware, crockery,rusted metal bits, several brick fragments

Prehistoric:tested cobbles, and primary flakes
circum: clear warm sunny day in a plowed field
disc_desc:
The site is located in a corn field that was plowed under, no vegetation was growing at the time of the survey. The prehistoric aspect of the site is defined by a long scatter of quartz cobbles(ogallala) in a 198m strip running somewhat parallel with a fenceline. Mixed with these cobbles are several tested cobbles and primary debitage. The density of the artifacts was quite low perhaps one culturally altered stone every 10m square.

The historic component rested in the center of the prehistoric site and appeared to be more concentrated near a break in the fenceline, where there may have been a gate at one time. The density of the artifacts was approximatly 10-15 per square meter, the artifacts abruptly vanished at the edge of the site boundries. No structures were located in the area.

A total of eight shovel tests were placed in the site and right-of-way all were culturally negative. Two of the shovel tests were forced to 60 cmbgs, though the compact clay to explore the extent of the clay deposit.

records: computer disks, map drawings, shovel test records, print log, prints
desc_loc: The site is located in a pasture .6km north of highway 121 and 4.7 km east of US Highway 5 just east of an unnamed lake.
drainage: an unnamed branch of Sister Grove Creek
soil_desc: Collin County Soil Survey, Huston Black Clay
env_desc: The site is located in a mostly flat pasture land with little vegetation other than low grasses.
artifact:
Rusting metal
Window glass, blue glass
Whiteware
Crockery
circum: clear warm sunny day in an open pasture
disc_desc:
This historic site is located is a cattle pasture on a hill gently rising to the north. The 1961 ANNA, TEX. topograpic map shows a house at this location as well as the road marked on the compass and pace map. The site is composed of a surface scatter, eight wooden posts, and a depression in the soil. the scatter consists of historic farmstead items glass, whiteware, crockery, and unidentified metal. The artifacts are at a frequency of approximatly 1 every meter square. The posts were placed in a square pattern and were exposed above ground approximatly one foot and had a diameter of one foot as well. The depression was a oblong shape covering an area of approximately 4x5m and had a depth of 50-70 cm. It is unknown if it was associated with a well.

A total of four shovel tests were placed in the site and right-of-way all were culturally negative. One of the shovel tests were forced to 60 cmbgs, though the compact clay to explore the extent of the clay deposit.

desc_loc: Located on the northwest side of Burgess Creed, northwest of where Airport Road crosses the creek.  The well is on the north side of Airport Road and about 380 meters west and slightly northwest of the bridge over Burgess Creek.
soil_desc:
Windthorst fine sandy loam, 1% to 5% slopes, eroded, and Frio clay loam.
Soil Survey of Parker County, Texas, Map 44.
env_desc: This is a Upland Edge location near where an old farmhouse once stood.  Historic ceramics and glass can be found in the area.  The well and farmhouse were well above the flood plain of Burgess Creek.

future: The well may be destroyed or filled in for child safety.
invest: Try to get the developer to fence the area around the well and perhaps place a heavy screen cover over the top to protect it.  Unfortunately, the developer destroyed the site before he could be contacted.
disc_desc: The well is located on the side of a gentle slope in an area that is being developed for new home construction.  The area around the well has been heavily disturbed by land clearing.

sitename: No Data; Cinder Block Well site
desc_loc: Located north of the main access road to the Lantana field office and 88m east of FM 407.
env_desc: Located on small outcrop of sandstone overlooking the drainage for Loving Branch.
cult_desc: This site is a hand-dug well that had a later addition of cinderblock added at the opening. Excavated to a depth of 4.2m with dry-laid native sandstone lining it's interior, there was water at the bottom during this survey. Prior to the addition of the blocks the opening measured 70 x 60cm. Recent mechanical clearing has removed any indications of past occupation, although it is more probable the land was cleared around the same time the other wells had their surrounding land cleared.
artifact: 1 sherd of undecorated whiteware.

desc_loc: Consisting of a root/storm cellar, is northeast of the West Pond and just southwest of the Lantana field office.
env_desc: Site is on a resistant sandstone bedrock outcrop overlooking Loving Branch drainage.
time_desc: Cellar is constructed of form-poured concrete
cult_desc: The cellar is constructed of form-poured concrete and has a half circle shape. The outside measures approximately 4.8m in length and 1.06m across the exposed top with portions of either side still buried, as evidenced by the interior measurements. There are five concrete steps leading down into the interior. The inside measurements, taken from the doorway facing in, are 2.1m from left to right and 2.2m from front to back. Inside height is 2.4m at the top of the curve. From the floor to the beginning of the curved ceiling is 1.8m. The door has a hand built iron frame with a sheet metal covering it. The sheet metal appears to be a later addition. Exposed bedrock around the area of the cellar would indicate extensive excavation took place prior to setting the form and pouring the concrete. Intensive survey around the cellar failed to locate any features. Interestingly, no well was found and it is unlikely that Cinder Block Well site is associated with this because of the drainage between the two. However, it is obvious that the cellar is associated with a dwelling, since these are note solitary features. Yet, no evidence of past occupation was noted.
artifact: small unidentifable bits of metal.
disc_desc: No Data
attachmem:
7.5' USGS topo with site plotted
sketch map

explain: No Data; Historic family cemetery (earliest grave is 1860, last marked grave is 1879)

records: daily journal, prints, slides, print log, slide logs, map drawings
desc_loc: Located approx. 1000 meters east of the confluence of Indian Creek and Eagle Mtn. Lake Reservoir, as well as Ft. Worth/dido Road.  On quad map as "graves".
water: Indian Creek - intermittant drainage, 150 meters south
env_desc: No Data
cult_desc: Five formal, commercial tomstones and 5 commercial footstones, in addition to another dressed marble tablet fragment. Stone 1: James D. Jefferson (born 8/28/1828; died 5/3/1879).  Stone 2 Mary Ann Jefferson (born 1/29/1866; died 8/30/1869). Stone 3: Minerva D. Jefferson (born 4/13/1868; died 6/2/1877). Stone 4: Isi... ... son (born 10/27/1860; aged 38 years).  Stone 5: Henry Jefferson (died 10/4/1875; aged 73 years, 11 months, 11 days).
site_size: current fenced in boundaries are 5 by 8 meters
artifact: nothing observed save 5 tombstones, 5 footstones, 1 additional tombstone fragment, and the wood fence placed around the site in the early 1980s.
circum: very hot, arid conditions, with minimal vegetation
intact: unk, but enclosed space likely encompasses most burials.
landuse: Texas National Guard base, with some heavy earth moving training conducted on site in immediate vicinity of cemetery.
natural: Some weathering of tombstones, especially stone #5, since it is lying horizontal on the ground.
artificial: some heavy earth moving equipment training conducted adjacent to site
future: some heavy earth moving equipment training conducted in immediate area
value: If it is ever neccessary to relocate graves, bioarchaeological excavation and anlaysis should be conducted.  Very few graves from this period have been scientifically exhumed in the state.
invest: If it is ever neccessary to relocate graves, bioarchaeological excavation and anlaysis should be considered.  Very few graves from this period have been scientifically exhumed in Texas.
disc_desc: Note: some of the stones have bene moved and relocated to their current positions.  The most intact or in situ stone is stone # 5 (Henry Jefferson). Some graves or portions of graves may lie outside current fenced in boundaries. (A modern fence encloses the stones.)

basis_size: extent of artifact scatter, up to disturbances
thickness: unk (but likely surficial, due to exposed limestone bedrock)
artifact: cut/wire nails, whiteware sherds, solarized bottle glass, commercial and handmade brick, wire, etc.
circum: very hot, arid conditions, with minimal vegetation
intact: approximately 60% of total site is estimated to be intact
landuse: Texas National Guard base, with some heavy earth moving training conducted on site in immediate vicinity of cemetery.
natural: some erosion is likely, especially to the north.
artificial: Extensive heavy earth moving equipment training conducted immediately adjacent to site
value: minimal; immediate site area is on very shallow sediments or bedrock; greater site area has been severely impacted on all 4 sides.
invest: avoid further impacts if possible.  Otherwise possibly minimal testing or surface collections.
regist: likely ineligible for National Register or other protections.
disc_desc: Beyond the immediate foundation boundaries, site scatter is slight and diffuse.  Much of the extended yard areas of the site are gone, obliterated by heavy earth moving activities on all 4 sides.

type_site: No Data; shell midden; possible hearthfield; shell midden; possible village
explain: No Data; Material was observed and collected from deep contexts within three backhoe trenches, and from the backdirt of other trenches excavated and backfilled in previous months.  The material consisted of burned earth features, bone, and shell, and was quite widespread.
surf_tech: Non-controlled; examined numerous old trenches, and identified four with ecofacts within the backdirt.
records: daily journal, field catalog, lab inventory, map drawings, print log, prints, slide logs, slides, stratigraphic profiles
desc_loc:
The site is located in a broad open field south of the SH 121 bypass, between Timber Creek on the west and a forested area on the east.  Cultural material was observed in the backdirt of four older backhoe trenches excavated in this part of the project area; later, material was collected from contexts 100-185 cm bs in three of seven new trenches excavated in the area.  These finds describe a long, arc-shaped site boundary that extends several hundred meters north-south.  The entire extent of the site is uncertain, but is estimated here for both the center UTM point and the perimeter UTM points, which are listed below.

a. E691210, N3653330; b. E691390, N3653185; c. E691320, N3653010; d. E691110, N3653120
water: Elm Fork of the Trinity is located about 300 m NE; Timber Creek 150 m SW
ownerinfo:
Huffines Communities, Inc.
822 Douglas Avenue, Suite 660
Dallas, TX 75772
(214) 750-1800
env_desc: The site is located on a tree farm in a large, open field south of the new SH 121 bypass south of Lewisville.   A scrubby hardwood forest is located about 100 m to the east of the positive trenches, and it seems likely that the site extends into this forest.  The Elm Fork of the Trinity River lies about 300 m to the northeast, Timber Creek about 150 m to the southwest.  It seems likely that this site was located in a small, open grassland in pre-Contact times.
cult_desc: Aside from the material observed on the surface, three features were found at varying depths in three backhoe trenches: BHT 27-29.  A burned earth feature containing charcoal, burned clay, ash, mussel shell, and deer bone was observed at about 100-110 cm bs in BHT 27.  BHT 28 yielded a concentration of large bone, probably bison, from a context 170-185 cm bs (the analysis of the material is not complete).  Finally, an oval burned earth feature was recorded from 170-185 bs in BHT 29; it included charcoal and burned clay, but no obvious cultural materials; however, it is believed to represent the remains of a hearth.
basis_size: Extent of subsurface features and surface finds
top: 100 cm for upper component; 170 for lower
artifact: Surface collections consist primarily of mussel shell, with small amounts of unidentified mammal bone.  As for the trenches, intact and broken mussel shells were noted and collected, as were deer bones, bovid bones that appear to be bison, and charcoal.  Burned earth and ash were observed but not collected.  At least three features were observed, one each in BHTs 27-29. No lithics or other cultural materials were identified.
circum: Features observed deep below the surface in backhoe trenches; inability (for safety reasons) to get close looks at the features; cloud cover, impending rain
future: Possible soil quarrying; housing development activities; bioturbation
value: Good to excellent. This site is extensive and is deeply buried, and appears to be in good to excellent condition.  Any impacts to the cultural deposits seem minimal.  Furthermore, preservation seems to be good, as indicated by the condition of the bone and shell recovered from depths of almost two meters.  The site's apparent richness of features (as indicated by the fact that new three trenches hit features, and material was found in the backdirt of several old trenches) suggests that it can provide a great deal of new information about the lifeways of Archaic Texas, particularly in regards to subsistence.  Further, serious investigations here would most likely yield artifact assemblages clarifying the origins of the site, as would the collection of radiometric dating samples.
invest: Ideally, this site should be subjected to Phase II testing in order to better clarify its age and origin, and to collect futther information about the occupations.  If the area is to be borrowed, as planned, the portion of the site within the borrow pit should be mitigated.  However, it is realized that the large size of the site, and its deeply buried nature, would raise the cost of Phase II/III investigations here to a prohibitive level.  Therefore, the most cost-effective measure would be simple avoidance.  If the entire eastern half of the proposed borrow pit was abandoned, the site would most likely be avoided.  If it is deemed preferable to reconfigure the borrow pit to avoid the site, and to add other untested areas, those areas should be tested first, prior to borrowing.
regist: The site is deeply buried and very extensive; its eligibility remains uncertain.
disc_desc: This site appears to exceed 100,000 square meters in size.  The site lies partially within an open field scheduled for use as a borrow pit, and prior to our efforts had been subject to numerous backhoe excavations (probably in an attempt to determine whether the soils were good fill material).  During initial surface investigations, cultural material, consisting of shell, bone, and charcoal, were observed in the backdirt of four old trenches located within the eastern third of the borrow pit.  Later, seven additional backhoe trenches were excavated in systematic fashion across the proposed borrow pit; of these, several were excavated next to three of the four positive trenches that occurred within the borrow pit.  Only the one excavated in the vicinity of previous trenches 9 and 10 yielded cultural material.  The three new positive trenches, BHT 27-29, were the last three excavated during the project, and each contained a feature (see previous sections for more details).  It appears that this is an extensive resource extraction or food preparation site, and may well represent the remains of a prehistoric village.  Unfortunately, no diagnostic tools were identified, and no radiocarbon samples were collected, so the site's age remains uncertain.  However, it is buried within what appears to be the West Fork paleosol, which dates in its upper levels to approximately 900-1000 YBP, so the site probably originates in the Archaic period.
attachmem:
Plan view map
Quadrangle map excerpt

desc_loc:
Site is located in plowed field approximately 0.55 km north of the Cooke-Denton county line  and 1.5 km west of the Cooke-Grayson county line; 1.52 mi SE of Ilse du Bois Creek/ Indian Creek confluence and 1.52 km SW of Buck Creek/ Pierce Spring confluence

UTM 14  N 3699730/ E 689740
soil_desc: Sandy tan soil; Konsil loamy fine sand - depth unknown
env_desc: Shoreline
site_size: 200 m (N-S) by 170 m (E-W)  equals about 2.32 hectare
artifact: Fragment of chert side-scraper, portion of end-scraper, and complete Elam point; Quartzite Yarbrough Point, point base, flakes, cores
circum: Visibility 70 percent; two lithic concentrations on surface; lacks depth; shovel tests sterile
invest: Auger/ test pitting; Surface collection of artifacts for comparison to those from other sites is recommended as a form of testing to determine National Register eligibility
disc_desc:
Site consists of a large scatter of chert and quartzite flakes (50 percent - 50 percent).  There were 2 projectile point bases (proximal fragments), probably late archaic and 2 biface fragments and a core flake; Site visited 11/23/85 (crew); 11/21/85 (crew with Prikryl); 12/09/85 (Ferring and Scott)
Citations of source material:  1,3

Co11 was relocated by Kooren and Mehalchick on 10/23/85.  Two concentrations were located on the east and west site edges respectively.  The eastern concentration contained quartzite flakes, a quartzite biface fragment, adn a quartzite core.  The western concentration (concentration  #2) contained flakes (70 percent quartzite, 30 percent chert, and a handful of primary flakes), a quartzite core, a quartzite point base, and a quartzite point.  The soil profile consisted of a 10 to 15 cm plow zone, a 5 tp 7 cm sandy loam, and a reddish brown sandy clay below the loam.  Sandstone is visible all across the site, particularly on the eastern half
A new site tag was placed on a fence post, the site was flagged, adn a rebar was buried for future relocation.
CO11 was revisited 11/21/85 by PRikryl, Kooren, and Mehalchick.  Prikryl noted that CO11 resembled "blow sand" sites that are usually lacking cultural stratigraphy but expose much surface material
Three shovel tests were dug west of the plowed field in a wooded area.  All tests were sterile, however, did consist of a sandy loam from surface to 50 cm (average thickness)
No further work is recommended due to lack of cultural material below surface and the sandy matrix of the site
Ferring, Scott, Kooren, and Mehalchick revisited CO11 on 12/09/85.  Ferring and Scott concurred that no further work be done.
Concat_site_variables:

env_desc: The site is situated on the floodplain of the Elm Fork of the Trinity.  It lies on the boundary between the Grand Prairie and Eastern Cross Timbers geographic provinces.  Woodbine sandstone and upland post oak woodlands are present E of the floodplain on higher terraces.
cult_desc: 2 hearths and 1 human burial are exposed in the cut bank.  The hearths are within a gray clay buried A-horizon.  The burial lies just beneath the buried A-horizon in a tan brown silty clay.
site_size: Construction activities have destroyed parts of the site.
basis_thk: Inspection of cut bank.  Depth of deposit below ground surface increases northward.
artifact: Burned limestone rocks, chert and quartzite flakes, bones (including one human burial), and musel shells.; Chert dart point, Late Archaic; fire-cracked rock.
circum: Construction of highway bridge is in progress.
natural: Sloughing on river channel cut bank.
artificial: Construction activities for the erection of an elevated bridge for highway FM 3002.; Disturbance by construction of FM 3002, bulldozing, vandalism.
future: Ongoing bridge construction work could destroy much of the remaining part of the site.; Road relocation
invest: Testing is needed to determine National Register eligibility.  It should include excavation of backhoe trenches and hand-dug pits.; The site should be protected from any additional road construction activities.  The burial that is eroding out of the cut bank should be excavated, since it will eventually erode out entirely.  Other areas of the site should be tested.  In particular the two hearths showing in the cut bank should be uncovered to determine if charcoal samples can be found.  The testing should also attempt to determine the horizontal limits of the site.  A burned rock found in the dark gray buried A-horizon about 40 meters N of the main part of the site may indicate that the site extends N of the construction area.
sal: False; False; False; False; False; TRUE

desc_loc: On high point of Rock Bluff on south side of Red River about 1.5 miles northwest of Bulcher community.  The major part of the site appears to be above the 810 contour line on USGS.
env_desc: Site is on bluff top and extends to first terrace above river. Fairly steep slope to north; flat to south.  Numerous trails cut into site by motorcycles.  Some use by overnight campers.  Location is between two drainages- Cottonwood Hollow to west and Mountain Creek east.  Some use of upper elev. as grain fields.
time_desc: Prehistoric, probably Archaic to late prehistoric
basis: No test excav. no diagnostic artifacts

artifact: Flakes, cores, broken biface (stage I) No diagnostics
natural: Erosion brought on by motorcycles.  River is moving south at this point also.  Some wind erosion.
future: Possible location for future FM road and bridge over Red River.
invest: Thorough testing and possible excavation if site to be in R.O.W of proposed Farm to Market road.

desc_loc: From the town of Sivell's Bend, drive N 2.5 miles to the edge of the high terrace overlooking the Red River floodplain.  The road turn 90 degrees to the E at this point.  The site follows the terrace edge, starting about 200 meters SW of this point, immediately across an intermittent stream.  The site extends along the terrace edge for nearly 1.2 kilometers.; Take road through Sivell's Bend until [you] hit a dirt road, pass school on the left, continue down and around hill on left till you are on 1st terrace at foot [of hill?].  Turn left across cattle gap; row of trees on right.  Turn through first gate on right and go through 2nd gate to edge of terrace.  [Also using Cooke County road map.]
water: 20 meters to E; 100 meters to W; 3 known springs at foot of terrace
ownerinfo: At least 2 owners.  East Half:  Thurman Ward(?); West Half:  (?) Martin; Leo Havercamp, Muenster. (friendly--running for office)
informinfo: Cecil Ward, cattle auctioneer at Gainesville; his brother lives in Sivell's Bend.  He and his brother were raised in farm in question.
visible: 0-10 percent on most areas of site; 100 percent in plowed field.
env_desc: Plowed.  In pasture at moment.  About 5-7 acres along edge of terrace.  Three known springs at foot of terrace.; Site is situated along the edge of a terrace about 50 feet above the Red River floodplain.  The river abutted up against this terrace at the same point in the past, but not necessarily when the site was occupied.  S of the alluvial terrace are hills rising another 150 feet in elevation, forming a series of "breaks" dissected by small streams.
cult_desc: 4 or 5 possible houses have been observed by Thurman Ward as dark circular stains when the eastern field was plowed.  He reports circular charcoal stains, 20-30 centimeters in diameter, arranged in a circular pattern with a 3-meter diameter.  The rise at the far eastern end of the site (about 80 meters NW of the possible house patterns) contains the remains of a structure.  Mr. Ward "excavated" the center of this rise and left the excavation open.  We profiled the walls and noted a burned prepared clay house floor and a hearth.  A charred acorn was found in the wall beneath the floor, and there were other lenses of clay, suggesting rebuilding episodes.  Burial reported at W end of site.
site_size: Shovel tests and surface examination - and informant.
artifact: Chert and quartzite flakes and tested cobbles, some burned cobbles observed in plowed field, ceramic sherds, charcoal and other charred plant material.
landuse: 1/3 of site is in old field; 1/3 of site id plowed; 1/3 of site is in Coastal Bermuda.
natural: Erosion along the slope of the terrace down toward the floodplain.
future: The site will probably continue to be used as pasture and plowed for crops.  Thurman Ward may get back out there with his shovel.  Otherwise, little impact.
invest: This site should be tested to obtain enough information to determine exactly what components are present, and if other intact features are present.  This information could be used to write a National Register nomination for the site.  It is clearly eligible for inclusion on the National Register.

env_desc: Site occupies the ridge of an alluvial terrace made up of fine orange sand of undetermined depth. artifact: Arrow point types: Washita, Bonham, Scallorn, Fresno, Toyah. Pottery: Nocona Plain- pipe fragments. invest: I plan to do more subsequent exploratory excavations at different areas of the site.  I recommend that the remaining 98 percent of the site remain undisturbed for future investigations.

projfund: Texas Historical Commission, Archeological Planning and Review
orgname: Jerry Humphries of SMU, leading several amateurs (including Ona B. Reed).
desc_loc: The site lies approximately 1.2 miles NNE of the town of Illinois Bend. The roads, expecially farm roads, have changed since the 1968 quad was mapped, so it is difficult to give accurate directions.  We were taken to the site by Ona B. Reed; she could give directions. Thurman Ward also; knows where the site is.
visible: Fair to Poor - 50 percent visibility, but dry, dusty conditions.
env_desc: Site is situated on a high terrace overlooking the Red River flodplain about 110 feet below.  An intermittent stream, deeply entrenched with cut banks 12-20 feet deep, cuts into the southern edge of the site and then curves around to the E and NE.
cult_desc: No features were observed during 1989 visit, but Ona B. Reed noted an oval area S of the main rise that was stained, a possible midden or house area.  She also noted a bone concentration between the main rise and the stained area.
artifact: 1969 crew collected metate fragments, arrow points, sherds, hammerstones, dart points, 3 scrapers, a knife, and bone fragments.  We saw no pottery and few artifacts during the 1989 visit.
circum: Dry, dusty field with low winter wheat.
landuse: Plum thickets to E and W of site.  Site planted in winter wheat.
invest: Monitor site; revisit when conditions are better.

projfund: Texas Historical Commission; Archeological Planning and Review
additional: Amateur archeologist, who has been potting the site.
desc_loc: From Marysville, head N 3 miles to fork.  Turn E and follow road as it curves around to N, up beyond landing strip and on down to the base of the slope at the junction of the Red River floodplain and the bluffs.  Follow the base of the slope W about 100 meters to a plowed field.  Site is in this field and across creek (artificial channel cut through site).
ownerinfo: E half of site, Don Monroe.  W half of site, Melvin Trammel
visible: 100 percent in plowed fields; 0 percent in forest.
env_desc: Site is situated on an alluvial terrace of the Red River along Blue Hollow, a permanent tributary.  Blue Hollow was diverted in the 1920's, such that it now cuts through the site.  The southern boundary of the site was not clearly determined.  It is in the forest, presumably along the base of the hillslope.
cult_desc: A very dark midden is clearly visible in the creek bank extending down 20-30 centimeters below surface.  No cultural features were observed at the time of our visit, but burials have been reported by avocational archeologists.
site_size: Walking plowed fields and shovel tests.
basis_thk: Examination of creek bank exposure and pot hunter's holes.  Shovel tests.
artifact: Very thick sherds; burned rock; calcined animal bone; mussel shell; flakes.
circum: Sunny fall day, good exposure on W side of creek.
landuse: Oak in forest; weeds (Devil's Claw, etc.) in old field.
natural: Erosion from 1920's channel diversion has washed out the center of the site.
artificial: Plowing has occurred on at least 75 percent of the site.  Channel diversion caused the creek to bisect the site.
future: No changes in land use are likely in the near future.
invest: At some point this site should be tested to evaluate its National Register eligibility.  Until then, regular monitoring by avocational archeologist is the best that can be done.

Turn E and follow road as it curves around to N, up beyond landing strip and on down to the base of the slope at the junction of the Red River floodplain and the bluffs.  Follow the base of the slope W about 100 meters to a plowed field.  Site is in this field and across creek (artificial channel cut through site).. Silty loam. Site is situated on an alluvial terrace of the Red River along Blue Hollow, a permanent tributary.  Blue Hollow was diverted in the 1920's, such that it now cuts through the site.  The southern boundary of the site was not clearly determined.  It is in the forest, presumably along the base of the hillslope.. Late Prehistoric. A very dark midden is clearly visible in the creek bank extending down 20-30 centimeters below surface.  No cultural features were observed at the time of our visit, but burials have been reported by avocational archeologists.. No Data. No Data

visible: 20 to 40 percent in some eroded areas; 0 percent elsewhere.
env_desc: This is a small rise in the floodplain of North Fish Creek.  The creek is very deeply entrenched.  There is a 20-25 vertical drop to the creek along the northern edge of the rise, where the rise has been cut into by the creek.
artifact: Beveled knives have been collected by Thurman Ward, as well as a piece of obsidian.  We collected two fragments of beveled knives, chert flakes, burned and unburned bone and part of a deer(?) tooth.
landuse: Site is in pasture for the most part, with the eastern edge extending slightly into riparian forest
natural: Some patchy areas of erosion on slope; northern edge of rise (main site area) is being truncated by North Fish Creek.
invest: Site should be tested at some point in the future.

projfund: Texas Historical Commission; Archeological Planning and Review
observe: Various times over the past 20 years.
test_meth: Collected material from shovel test 1.  Shovel test 2 was sterile.  Did not collect any surface items.
desc_loc: Head SE from the Gainesville city limits on S.H. 372 for about 3.5 miles.  Turn E on gravel road 2 miles to rugged dirt road leading to the Clark Cemetery.  Follow road up to cemetery; keep heading N past cemetery downhill.  South concentration begins about 100 meters N of cemetery.  Site continues across creek and up hill on N side.
visible: Fair on the N side of the creek, due to erosional areas.
env_desc: This is an upland setting in the Cross Timbers with much of the site on a gradual to steep hillslope.  A permanent stream bisects the site, and Dr. Martin reports that 90 percent of the artifacts were found on the slope N of the stream.
basis: No pottery has been found, and Archaic diagnostics have been recovered.
cult_desc: No features observed, but Dr. Martin showed us an area where he found a human tooth (post-mortem loss) indicating the presence of at one human burial.
artifact: Dr. Martin found a Meserve point which had been reworked into a scraper.  We observed several flakes of chert and quartzite and a sandstone nutting stone on the N side of the stream.
landuse: Oaks.  Typical Cross Timbers vegetation.  North side of creek and S side are in pasture.
invest: Revisit site and monitor.  Future testing recommended.

type_site: No Data; Open campsite either repetively or continuously occupied at different times.
test_meth: Random collection by primarily 3 individuals over a period of 40 years.  Collections were obtained by surface hunting in cultivated and water-eroded areas.
materials: Projectile points, milling stones, drills, gouges, scrapers, bifaces, nutting stones.
desc_loc: Located in SE Cooke County, 2 miles E of FM Road 372 and approximately 9 miles SE of the city of Gainesville.  Site is situated on the E bank of Indian Creek, 2 miles S of its exit from Lake Kiowa.  Nearest community is Burns City, 1.5 miles WSW of the site.  The highest part of the site is 300 feet away from Indian Creek.
drain_name: Indian Creek, Isle De Bois Creek, Elm Fork of Trinity
ownerinfo: Mr. & Mrs. Ivan Cox, Route 5, Gainesville, Texas  76240
soil_desc: Sand mixed with numerous dark sandstone pebbles.
env_desc: The site is situated on an alluvial terrace 25-30 feet above the bed of Indian Creek.  The terrace slopes from E to W with an additional slope to the SW.  Part of the site is in cultivation, part is now an orchard, and the rest is unimproved pasture.  The terrain slopes away from the terrace to the creek on the W (side) and to a large sandy peanut field on the S.  A large wooded rocky hill rises 125 feet above Indian Creek  one-half mile S of the site.
time_desc: Multiple components ranging from Late Paleo, Early, Middle and Late Archaic to Late prehistoric.
basis: Multiple ages of the projectile points collected.
cult_desc: None visible, but the site is littered with rocks darkened by burning, but all of these have been disturbed by cultivation.  There are most likely undisturbed cultural deposits in the areas of the site that are not being cultivated.
site_size: Extent of cultural debris exposed on surface.
artifact: Paleo Darts - Types:  Meserve, Angostura, Dalton, San Patrice, Scottsbluff, and Calf Creek.  Archaic Darts - Primarily, Wells, Gary, Yarbrough, Kent, Godley, Darl, Lange, Marcos, Martindale, Castroville, and Dallas or Trinity types.  Arrow Points - Only two have been known found at the Cox Site, both of the Bonham type.  Other artifacts present include milling stones, nutting stones, gouges (Clear Fork type), scrapers (both hafted and hand held), and drills.  No beads or pottery have been found at this site.
landuse: None in cultivated areas.  Coastal Bermuda and numerous wild native grasses on the remainder of the site.
natural: Flood erosion in 1966 and subsequent refilling of the area by the landowner has destroyed 5 percent of the site on the lower part.
artificial: 60-70 percent of the site is regularly affected by cultivation.  The rest remains largely undisturbed.
future: None known, other than continued cultivation as before, or occasional surface hunting by artifact collectors.
invest: I feel this site is important due to its apparent long term of occupation.  The compilation of collections of artifacts recovered from the surface indicate a possible occupation time span of perhaps 9000 years.  A significant part of this site remains undisturbed, and could provide information regarding climatic and cultural changes over a long time period that affected prehistoric people in this area.  The landowner is very cooperative, and I am certain that he would allow a systematic investigation and excavation of the site if asked.
disc_desc: No Data

artifact: sandy limestone or sandstone used to construct well/cistern
artificial: recreational all-terrain vehicle traffic in vicinity (4 wheelers)
value: none, other than its identification and record
disc_desc: This well or cistern is constructed of relatively flat but otherwise irregularly shaped, locally available sandstone or sandy limestone.  The rock was not secured with grout or mortar. Not much information to determine age or who was responsible for construction, however, probably dates to time of MKT railroad (ca. 1887) when the area was settled by German immigrants.  Local informants indicated the well/cistern was known as the "Courting Well" for unknown reasons and indicated the primary purpose was a place where locals gathered to water their horses, but also for socializing.
attachmem: photocopy of prints; USGS Quad (Muenster West)

explain: No Data; Site of rail stop on the MKT railroad that existed for a brief time in the 1880s
projname: Elm Fork Watershed, Multiple Purpose Structure(MPS) 19
additional: Local historical volumes: 1)Golden Jubilee History of the Sacred Heart Parish, 1889-1939, by Joseph P. Fuhrmann; 2)Muenster, Texas: A Centennial History - 1889-1989, by Muenster Centennial Committee
desc_loc: Northwest of the City of Muenster: From point where County Road 316 crosses the old MKT railroad grade, site of Lazarus is about 3000ft northwest up the MKT line on the east side of the old railroad grade
water: Brushy Elm Creek, intermittent stream, 800ft southwest
informinfo: Harvey and Della Schmitt, Muenster, TX
soil_desc: Slidell Series, Slidell clay 1-3% slopes (map unit) and Sanger Series, Sanger clay 1-3% slopes (map unit);  information from Soil Survey of Cooke County
env_desc: cool season grass pasture on gently sloping former cropland field; upland
time_desc: informant interview, historic accounts, list of artifacts recovered by local collectors
basis: no evidence of other occupation other than the short-lived rail stop
site_size: 80m northwest to southeast x 60m northeast to southwest
basis_size: topographic limits and position near old MKT rail grade
basis_thk: upland site; no evidence of subsurface deposits or features
artifact: scattered bricks and brick fragments none having manufacturers identification; informant indicated heavy collection of area by local collectors; one local collector listed the following as material collected from the site: harmonica, toy pistol, Warner's Kidney and Liver Cure bottle, dime, smashed Indian head penny, lantern parts, horse shoes, wood stove parts, spoons, Civil War pin.
circum: sunny morning, adequate lighting and surface visibility
landuse: pastureland that was formerly in cultivation
natural: shrink-swell soils, water erosion while in cultivation
artificial: plowing, acceleration of sheet and rill erosion
value: none, other than its identification and record
invest: None. Site has been extensively collected and little if any valuable information remains.
disc_desc: According to local historical volumes, Lazarus was established as a rail stop on the MKT line that was constructed from Gainesville to Henrietta in 1887. Stations or switches were located at 10-12 mile intervals, including the still existing towns of Myra and Lindsay. Lazarus was a station and water stop from 1887 until the founding of Muenster in 1889. Lazarus was abandoned at that time (ca. 1889).  This section of the MKT line was dismantled in the 1960s.

explain: No Data; Location of grounds once utilized for church picnics and youth camp outs.
projname: Elm Fork Watershed, Multiple Purpose Structure(MPS) 19
desc_loc: Northwest of the City of Muenster: From point where County Road 316 crosses the old MKT railroad grade, site of church camp is about 1300ft south, on the east side of Brushy Elm Creek.

informinfo: Harvey and Della Schmitt, Muenster, TX
soil_desc: Tinn Series, Tinn clay (map unit) and Lindy Series, Lindy loam 1-5% slopes (map unit); information from Soil Survey of Cooke County
env_desc: Site occupies an upland ridge that separates Brushy Elm Creek from a tributary to the east and is some 4m higher in elevation than the stream channel.  Site area is flat.  Area is in pasture with bermudagrass base and cool season annual  grass cover at time of survey.
cult_desc: a concrete slab that was used as a volleyball and basketball court is still in place at the center of the site
artifact: No Data
artificial: plowing, change in land use to pasture (trampling, trailing)
future: construction of dam will obliterate the area
value: none, other than its identification and record
disc_desc: This area was utilized for some 60-70 years by the Sacred Heart Parish for church picnics and campsite for youth.  According to local informants, the parish was given about 57 acres of land by a parishioner named Kampshof sometime around 1900.  Kampshof had been on the property cutting wood and was trapped under a fallen tree. He vowed to God that if he were saved that he would give the place to the church.  The church leased the land to various people for farming through the years, but also began using the shaded ridge as a location for church picnics and youth camp outings.  While in use, there was a cafeteria, men and women's restrooms, and a basketball/volleyball court.  The slab of the ball court is all that remains.
attachmem: photocopy of prints; USGS Quad (Muenster West)

additional: R.L. Stephenson, R.K. Harris, J.B. Sollbeiger, 1949.; Information in files: see folder in Cooke County files. Black and white photos. Specimens: retained by investigators.  Remarks: Hearth areas, burials and bones.  See The Record (DAS); Vol. 8, #1, Sept. to Oct. 1949.  King Harris has skull from Burial #3.  Summary: R.L. Stephenson, R.K. Harris and J.B. Sollbeiger drove to Gainsville on the morning of June 12, 1949 and contacted Mr. Tom Hickman. He took us to the county courthouse and showed us 1 deer antler, several deer bones and fragments of other bones and 5 pieces of burned clay from this site.  Here we picked up Mr. Hubert Moss, County Superintendant and went out to the site 1.5 miles S of Gainesville on an artificial channel of Elm Fork.  It is located on the Jordan Farm. Here the city has relocated the stream so that it cuts its modern, meandering chanel in 2 places and an older channel in at least one place, thus is made to flow in a straight line.  The cut is 20 ft deep with steep sloping sides. At 6 to 12 inches above the channel floor is a layer of charred material covering over half the channel. In this burned area is hearth 1 and burials 1 and 2, roughly 19 inches below the surface.  Burial 3 and 4 ft below the present surface as is hearth 2.  The animal bones recovered here were in the same level as burials 1 and 2.  No artifacts, shell, chipped flint or other cultural debris was found in the entire area.
mapname: Gainesville South; See county highway map: N33 deg 35 min, W97 deg 07 min, USGS 7.5 minute Gainesville S, approx. location on bound county highway map

artifact:
Historic - aqua fruit jar bases, opaque milk glass, manganese solarized glass (1880 to 1920) brown snuff bottle base, clear fruit jar bases  (all of these artifacts were found in the mounded area except one piece of manganese glass was found in the road)
Prehistoric - chert end scraper, chert point tip, medial section of a serrated arrow point, quartzite biface  (material - 70 percent quartzite, 30 percent chert) - 90 percent of prehistoric artifacts visible in the road; None - endscraper and alternately beveled tools were photographed

disc_desc:
Citations of source material:  1,3
CO55 was relocated 11.08/85 by Kooren and Mehalchick.  The historic debris concentration was found in a mound-like area.  The prehistoric site limits are delineated correctly on the map with a heavy density of lithic material visible in the western section of the road.
The site area is presently pasture and is somewhat deflated.  A mottled clay is present to a depth of 10 cm below surface.
The site tag was relocated, the site was flagged, adn a magnetic tape strip buried for future relocation.
Ferring and Prikryl visited CO55 on 11/15/85.  The site area was enlarged to 130 m E/W by 115 m N/S due to the artifact surface scatter.  Many of these artifacts are present on the terrace slopes or in highly deflated areas, however, a broken quartzite biface and the medial section of a serrated arrow point (quartzite) were found in the road.  Two shovel tests were dug, both sterile and lacking depth.  Test #1 showed a 10 cm gray sandy loam with a reddish brown clayey sand underneath.  Test #2 had the B horizon exposed at the surface.  Surface collection recommended.; Site consists of a large scatter of quartzite flakes (5), a few chert flakes (10), a chert endscraper or possible or possible gouge and an alternately beveled tool of pink chert.  No diagnostics could be located.  Site overlooks Isle du Bois Creek approximately 200 m to the west.  A large scatter of historic material is also present, including glass, crockery, metal and brick fragments and china

disc_desc:
Citations of source material, 1, 3

CO70 was relocated by Kooren and Mehalchick on 10/21/85.  Nothing was visible on the surface and three shovel tests were dug.  Shovel test #1 was dug on the terrace top.  The upper 5 cm was a humus layer, 5 to 20 cm was a sandy loam, and 20 plus cm was a reddish brown clay.  Shovel test #@ was placed on the terrace slope and consisted of the same soils as shovel test #1, however, #2 contained heavy gravels.  Shovel test #3 was dug east of the road and fence line and again consisted of the aforementioned profile.  All three tests proved negative.  Visiblility - 40 percent.
A new site label was nailed to a tree, the site was flagged, and a rebar buried for further relocation.
No further work is recommended; Site is on the first terrace above Indian Creek on the east side.  There are 9 flakes, 1 medial section of a biface and 1 piece of bone.  All were found in rodent intrusions and areas with no grass

disc_desc: CO95 was relocated 10/28/85 by Kooren and Mehalchick.  A heavy artfact density was visible in the road ( 100 percent). One shovel test was dug on the E side of the road. The site tag was relocated, the site flagged, and a magnetic strip buried for future relocation. Prikryl and Ferring visited CO95 on 11.11.85. Three points, 2 arrow, 1 dart (collected) and a quartzite biface fragment were found on the surface. Three shovel tests were dug down slope W of the barn area. soil_desc: Houston Black clay, 1 to 3 percent slopes
env_desc: Upland between drainages, heavily grassy area.
artifact: stoneware, whiteware, bottle glass, milk glass, marbles, brick
intact: Extensive disturbance in proximity to County Road 400, a field road and two ditches.
value: Given the lack of any subsurface deposits at the site, the extensive disturbance, and the presumed occupation of the site into the recent era, it appears to have little research potential. Consequently, site 41COL100 is considered ineligible for inclusion in the NRHP or for nomination as a SAL (Hunt et al. 1998).
invest: No further work is recommended at the site (Hunt et al. 1998).
disc_desc: Four sterile shovel tests were excavated at site 41COLCOL100, one in the field road and three within the surface scatter. All shovel tests were placed within the project right-of-way. The shovel testing revealed a dark gray to very dark grayish brown clay over 40 cm deep, underlain by an olive brown clay subsoil. A noncontrolled surface inspection was undertaken at the site, identifying stoneware, whiteware, bottle glass (manganese solarized [1880-1920], clear [post-1880], and aqua), milk glass, marbles and machine-made brick (post-1900). A selective surface collection was taken from this scatter, including five domestic artifacts and two personal items. The domestic artifacts include a piece of ivory-tinted whiteware (post-1920), a blue-tinted ironstone cup fragment (1850-1910), a piece of white whiteware decorated with imitation flow blue and relief molding (1890-1925), a piece of porcelain decorated with decalcomania (1890-1950), and a Bristol interior/Bristol exterior stoneware fragment decorated with an incised line (post-1900). The personal items consist of two marbles, both made of white milk glass. One marble is reddish brown opaque patched (1929-1977) and the other is bluish opaque brushed (1929-1938; Randall 1979:37-40; Hunt et al. 1998).
Concat_site_variables: No Data; farmstead. No Data. February 13-19 1998. February 13-19 1998. n/a. Site 41COL100 is directly north of County Road 400, 0.40 miles west of Beauchamp Boulevard.. additional:
