desc_loc: Site 41COL101 is directly north of County Road 400, approximately 0.20 miles west of Beauchamp Boulevard.
drain_name: Unnamed tributary of East Fork Trinity River
soil_desc: Houston Black clay, 1 to 3 percent slopes
env_desc: Upland area between streams, plowed field with little grass.
artifact: stoneware, whiteware, bottle glass, milk glass, iron hardware
intact: Poor to fair contextual integrity as a result of erosion and plowing
value: Site 41COL101 is considered to be ineligible for inclusion in the NRHP or for nomination as a SAL (Hunt et al. 1998).
invest: No further work is recommended at the site (Hunt et al. 1998).
disc_desc: Six shovel tests were excavated while recording the site, five in the area defined by the heaviest surface scatter and one in the lower density area between sites 41COL99 and 41COL101. All six shovel tests were sterile. The shovel tests revealed a soil profile consisting of a very dark gray to very dark grayish brown clay A horizon 15 to over 40 cm thick, underlain by an olive brown clay B horizon. A noncontrolled surface inspection was undertaken at the site, identifying stoneware, whiteware, bottle glass  manganese solarized [1880-1920], clear [post-1880], aqua, brown, and light green), milk glass, and iron hardware parts. In addition, there was an extensive scatter of gravels and cobbles, some of which appeared altered through plowing. However, with a very small number of pieces, patterning was noted in the flake scars, suggesting a cultural origin. It is possible that this area was utilized as a lithic procurement area; however, no flakes were observed at the site (Hunt et al. 1998).

desc_loc: Located 3rd block west of 121 and 1 blk (?) north of Standifer Street in McKinney, Tx. Should be at the corner of Bevor and Tennessee St. It is one block south of the McKinney Courthouse Square.
water: City water; 20 ft deep well uphill east 50 ft; now sprinkler system.
drainage: Creek-gully across road to west S. Kentucky St.
ownerinfo: Mark & Carol Barratt312 S. TennesseeMcKinneyTX75069972727-8280
informinfo: Mark & Carol Barratt312 S. TennesseeMcKinneyTX75069972727-8280Melinda Fisher831 Timberwood LaneFairviewTX75069
visible: No vegetation since it was winter, sodded day after excavation.
env_desc: 2 homes 311 S. Kentucky St., 312 Tennessee St.. Land slopes toward a creek on the west side past a street and another house. A well with 20 ft deep water is at the top of the hill. Landscapers have moved in large truck loads of diret and tilled up almost all of the soil. New sidewalks were poured.
time_desc: Modern--house built in early 1911--312 S. Tennessee.
basis: House on property- present home built in early 1900s. McKinney is 150 years old (dating to the Middle Statehood period).
cult_desc: In backyard of 312 S. Tennessee St. was a cement flat patio with a Bois D'arc log connected to it. The cement curl up over the rounded edge of the log. Post hole under the cement adjacent to the log is drawn. Brick walkway and small dwelling built upon blocks. Had gas pipes, water, and linoleum. Floor left as a stage. Brick walk removed.
basis_top: Material from where postholes for new wooden fence were dug and sprinkler trenches.
artifact: Buttons, glass fragment, Bois D'Arc log--placed by new pond and saved. Cement patch saved.
circum: Workmen stripping debris off yard to plant sod.
intact: 100 % underneath 1 foot depth; 10 % on hilltop surface.
landuse: Wedding and reception home with gardens.
artificial: Planting of sod, installing flower beds, and laying sidewalks.
value: To proved heritage information for the homeowners and guests. Frame marbles, buttons, etc. for owners to display and frame a historiy of the home for the owners.
invest: Advised the owners to leave the well as is and not to fill it in. It has good clean water, and may have historical significance.; We can't disturb her landscaping now. She was wedding reception every weekend.
disc_desc: This was most likely a structure behind the existing house.

desc_loc: Located on S. Kentucky St. 300 Block.
ownerinfo: Sullivan & Assoc. Steven E. Sullivan(present) 4436 Ballinger Dr. Plano Texas, 75093, 1972 612-7067
env_desc: Flat; Old Wooden Courthouse was said to be located on this site before prsion was built. City Jail was directly across the street to the west.
cult_desc:
Stone Buliding- 2 rooms in front with beatiful staircase and up stairs living areas.
1 Story prison with elevated celling later changed to 3 Stories with different stone used for the top floor.
basis_thk: 27 ft deep for well. 24' from surface.
artifact: See attached & slides & photos. Typical refuse found around living quaters & prison fro 1804's to the present. Especially under the windows and doors.
circum: 10 years passed; people remembered differently of methods, etc.
natural: Roof is leaking very badly and destorying the building.
artificial: Vandalism. Windows are broken out & a fire was set.
future: Possibly to be renovated into office buliding or restanrant (needs a new roof badly).
invest: Southside could be excavated. A patio is being planned to cover prison yard.
disc_desc: Already registered with THC. This was probably a dumpsite for Wm Davis family or tenats before the site was used for the wodden courthouse. The wooden courthouse was purported to have been moved here while the stone one was being bulit. Then the prison was bulit after the Civil War. A few items are older than the city of McKinney (150 yrs.) County seat was moved from Throckmortten to McKinney to be center of the County. Wm Davis donated the land.

disc_desc:
This site occupies the area of an abandoned farm, is largely cultivated, of uneven terrain and the upper terrace, profusely strewn with camp refuse, but no artifacts were found.
This site is located on the eastern slope of a ridge between Pilot Grove Creek and Tickey Creek, 200 yds west of Pilot Grove Creek. It is a non-pottery campsite producing large quantities of camp refuse but no artifacts.  No further work need be done here

recname: Kevin Stone, Alexandra Younger, Josh McCormick
desc_loc: On bank of Sloan Creek
soil_desc: Tinn clay, 0 to 1 percent slopes, occasionally flooded
env_desc: Stream terrace of Sloan Creek
basis_size: extent of surface artifacts and positive shovel tests
artifact: Faunal remains, fire cracked rocks, lithics (bifaces, points)
value: This site is potentially eligible for nomination to the National Register because its buried deposit, although dispersed, has the potential for contributing to a better understanding of Late Prehistoric occupation and utilization of a minor tributary in the Blackland Prairie. The site is also potentially eligible for registration as a State Archeological Landmark as it has the potential to contribute to cumulative history by the addition of new information  (Skinner and Kent 1999).
disc_desc: This site is a small low density prehistoric deposit which represents a limited set of maintenance activities. Based on the arrow points and the animal bone, it is likely that this was a Late Prehistoric hunting camp. Part of the site, possibly most of the buried deposit, remains in place in the creek bank (Skinner and Kent 1999).

explain: No Data; Scatter of historic ceramics, glass, metal and building debris in a pasture; no structures remain, but flowerbeds of irises exist
projname: Lake Chapman Water Transmission Line Survey
additional:
No previous investigations known (but see Duane E. Peter, 1981, "Survey of a Proposed Pipeline Crossing Pilot Grove, Pot Rack and Indian Creek Drainages, Lake Lavon Reservoir," Letter Report submitted to Matador Pipelines, Inc., Geo-Marine, Inc., Plano, Texas, describing a cultural resources survey of a nearby natural gas pipeline.
Current project report: Jeffrey D. Owens, 1999, "Cultural Resources Survey and Geoarcheological Investigation of the Proposed Lake Chapman Water Transmission Line, Collin and Denton Counties, Texas," Miscellaneous Reports of Investigations 181, Geo-Marine, Inc., Plano, Texas.
surf_tech: Non-controlled surface inspection and selective collection of artifacts observed
records: prints, aerials, slides, analysis notes, maps/drawings, shovel test records, slide log, print log, daily journal, field catalog
desc_loc: The site is situated in an open pasture atop a second terrace (T2) bench between two unnamed, intermittent drainages that flow into the Harrington Branch to the south. The site is located 2.0 km southeast of Verona Church (or the intersection of FM 1377 and an east-west connector road that crosses the Lick Branch), 1.0 km southeast of Verona Cemetery, and 540 m west of the FM road that traverses the western terrace of Pilot Grove Creek along the existing right-of-way of a natural gas pipeline.
water: Intermittent tributary of Harrington Branch 450 m east of site
soil_desc: Houston Black-Houston association; Houston Black clay, 1 to 3% slopes
env_desc: The site is situated on the approximate center of a broad, flat second terrace (T2) bench between two intermittent drainages that flow into the Harrington Branch to the south. The site is located in an open pasture and is bisected by two natural gas pipelines. Vegetation on the site consists of short-cropped grasses, one large oak tree, and several circular and polygonal stands of irises (of cultural origin). A large stock dam is visible on the edge of the Harrington Branch flood plain 300 m south of the site, an abandoned brown farmhouse stands roughly 300 m north-northeast of the site, and a blue water tower can be seen on the northwestern horizon. A fenceline runs north-south through the site, and six pipeline signposts (3 orange and 3 blue) mark the natural gas line routes where they cross the fence.
time_desc: Diagnostic artifacts from surface collection and shovel tests
basis: Diagnostic artifacts indicate an early- to mid-20th century occupation
cult_desc: Two, or possibly three, cultural features were observed on the site. First, a 1-m-sq fieldstone well base or other structural element is located in the southwestern portion of the area demarcated by the surficial artifact scatter. No above-ground portion of this well remains, only several flat, shaped fieldstone slabs forming a hollow square with a sloughed depression in the interior of the feature. South of the southern extent of the surficial artifact scatter is a 1-m-sq, square depression in the modern ground surface. This may be a second well feature or another type of excavated and subsequently filled-in feature, but no stones are visible on or immediately below the modern ground surface, and no artifacts are associated with this depression. This feature may be natural in origin and, in any case, is not directly associated either with the artifact scatter or any other cultural feature. Third, nine stands of irises are present along the western edge and across the center of the site. Six of these stands of flowers are perfectly circular, and the largest stand is lined along its western edge by a trimmed log, suggesting that this stand was a lined flowerbed. The stands in the approximate center of the site form an L-shape, suggesting that the original location of the house was in the east-central portion of the site.; No records of a homestead or farmstead at this location have been located.
basis_size: Artifacts observed on modern ground surface; extent of positive shovel tests
basis_top: Artifacts observed  on modern ground surface
thickness: 10 cm bs (all subsurface artifacts occur immediately under grass root mat)
artifact: A low-density scatter of historic artifacts was observed on the modern ground surface, and a non-controlled sample was collected. Artifacts include stoneware (Bristol slipped), whiteware, glass (aqua, clear, ash tint, milk glass, table glass, bottle glass, jar glass), building materials (ceramic sewer pipe fragment), and metal (piece of wire). Artifact densities are slightly higher in the southwestern portion of the site (north and south of the well base). Nodules of melted glass suggest that one or more of the structures once present burned down or were burned after demolition.
circum: Slightly overcast day; 3:00-4:30 pm; excellent ground visibility (short-cropped pasture grasses)
natural: Small amount of natural erosion; bioturbation from cattle possible
artificial: Burning and/or clearing of structure(s) on site; construction associated with installation and maintenance of natural gas pipelines (8-in-wide trench visible)
future: Construction of new subsurface water transmission pipeline (86-in-diameter) through site; possibly a small amount of continued erosion
value: The site currently possesses virtually no contextual integrity, contains very few remaining cultural resources, and is considered to have very little to no research potential. The site consists of an early- to mid-20th homestead or farmstead, but the only remains of the occupation consist of a low-density artifact scatter, a stone alignment that may be a well base, a second depression that may be another excavated type of cultural feature, and several stands of irises.
invest: None; No further investigations are recommended at the site. The site is highly disturbed, with very few physical remains yet existing, and possesses very little research potential. Any standing structures and cultural features other than the possible well base that once were present have been removed or otherwise destroyed, with the exception of the stone alignment of the well base and the flower stands. No subsurface cultural deposits exist below the root mat.
disc_desc: No records of a historic homestead or farmstead at this location have been located.

records: prints, aerials, slides, analysis notes, maps/drawings, shovel test records, slide log, print log, daily journal, field catalog
desc_loc: The site is situated in an open pasture atop a second terrace (T2) bench east of an unnamed drainage that flows into the Harrington Branch to the south.  The site is located 3.0 km southeast of Verona Church (or the intersection of FM 1377 and an east-west connector road that crosses the Lick Branch), 1.2 km southeast of Verona Cemetery, and 290 m west of the FM road that traverses the western terrace of Pilot Grove Creek along the existing right-of-way of a natural gas pipeline.
water: Intermittent tributary of Harrington Branch 160 m east of site
soil_desc: Houston Black-Houston association; Houston Black clay, 1 to 3% slopes
env_desc: The site is situated on the approximate center of a broad, flat second terrace (T2) bench east of an intermittent drainage that flows into the Harrington branch to the south. The site is located in an open pasture and is bisected by a natural gas pipeline. The only vegetation on the site consists of short-cropped grasses, although scattered oak and elm trees can be seen at lower elevations. An abandoned brown farmhouse stands roughly 370 m northwest of the site, and a blue water tower can be seen on the northwestern horizon. A fenceline runs north-south 60 m east of the site, and three pipeline signposts mark the natural gas line route where it crosses the fence.
time_desc: Diagnostic artifacts from surface collection and shovel tests
basis: Diagnostic artifacts indicate a late-19th to early 20th century occupation
cult_desc: A cement fragment, measuring roughly 0.5 m in diameter, is set into the ground, level with the modern ground surface, near the southern edge of the site. This slab may have been part of the original house foundation, part of an outbuilding, or a piece of structural debris. No other evidence of cultural features was observed.; No records of a homestead or farmstead at this location have been located.
basis_top: Artifacts observed on modern ground surface
thickness: 10 cm bs (all subsurface artifacts occur immediately under grass root mat)
artifact: A low-density scatter of historic artifacts was observed on the modern ground surface, and a non-controlled sample was collected. Artifacts include stoneware sherds (including Bristol slipped, natural clay slipped, salt vapored), one ironstone sherd (blue-tinted), whiteware (including blue-tinted, undecorated, and imitation flow blue), manganese bottle and table glass, other bottle glass, and an iron horseshoe nail. Artifact densities are slightly higher in the approximate center of the site. Nodules of melted glass suggest that one or more of the structures once present burned. Aside from the small concrete fragment near the southern edge of the site, no evidence of cultural features was observed.
circum: Bright, sunny day; 10 am - 11:15 am; excellent ground visibility (short-cropped pasture grass)
natural: Small amount of natural erosion; bioturbation from cattle possible
artificial: Burning and/or clearing of structure(s) on site; construction associated with installation and maintenance of natural gas pipeline (8-in-wide trench visible)
future: Construction of new subsurface water transmission pipeline (86-in-diameter) through site; possibly a small amount of continued erosion
value: The site currently possesses virtually no contextual integrity, contains very few remaining cultural resources, and is considered to have very little to no research potential. The site consists of the remains of a turn-of-the-century historic homestead or farmstead, but the only remains of the occupation consist of a low-density surficial artifact scatter (75% of which was collected during the survey) and a small concrete fragment.
invest: None; No further investigations are recommended at the site. The site is highly disturbed, with very few physical remains yet existing, and possesses very little research potential. Any standing structures and cultural features once present have been removed or otherwise destroyed, with the possible exception of a small concrete slab. No cultural deposits are associated with this site.

Concat_site_variables: No Data; historic. No Data. 2/1/5/99. 2/15/1999. No Data. The site is situated in an open pasture atop a second terrace (T2) bench east of an unnamed drainage that flows into the Harrington Branch to the south.  The site is located 3.0 km southeast of Verona Church (or the intersection of FM 1377 and an east-west connector road that crosses the Lick Branch), 1.2 km southeast of Verona Cemetery, and 290 m west of the FM road that traverses the western terrace of Pilot Grove Creek along the existing right-of-way of a natural gas pipeline.. Houston Black-Houston association; Houston Black clay, 1 to 3% slopes. The site is situated on the approximate center of a broad, flat second terrace (T2) bench east of an intermittent drainage that flows into the Harrington branch to the south. The site is located in an open pasture and is bisected by a natural gas pipeline. The only vegetation on the site consists of short-cropped grasses, although scattered oak and elm trees can be seen at lower elevations. An abandoned brown farmhouse stands roughly 370 m northwest of the site, and a blue water tower can be seen on the northwestern horizon. A fenceline runs north-south 60 m east of the site, and three pipeline signposts mark the natural gas line route where it crosses the fence.. Diagnostic artifacts from surface collection and shovel tests. A cement fragment, measuring roughly 0.5 m in diameter, is set into the ground, level with the modern ground surface, near the southern edge of the site. This slab may have been part of the original house foundation, part of an outbuilding, or a piece of structural debris. No other evidence of cultural features was observed.; No records of a homestead or farmstead at this location have been located.. No Data. No Data

Current project report: Jeffrey D. Owens, 1999, "Cultural Resources Survey and Geoarcheological Investigation of the Proposed Lake Chapman Water Transmission Line, Collin and Denton Counties, Texas," Miscellaneous Reports of Investigations 181, Geo-Marine, Inc., Plano, Texas.

desc_loc: Site is situated near the southernmost point of a low terrace finger overlooking Stiff Creek to the south and an unnamed tributary to the west.  The site is located 1.6 km southwest of the town of Altoga, 280 m east of FM 1827, 750 m north-northeast of the intersection of FM 1827 and FM 75, and 500 m north-northwest of the confluence of Stiff Creek and an unnamed tributary stream.
water: Stiff Creek 500 m to south & unnamed tributary stream 150 m west of site
ownerinfo: Old Preston Road Partnership LP (Glenn Williams)17811 Davenport RoadSuite 42DallasTX75252-5881972248-6062
soil_desc: Houston Black-Austin association; Lewisville silty clay, 3 to 5% slopes, eroded; and Altoga silty clay, 5 to 8% slopes, eroded
env_desc: The site is situated on the southern end of the crest of a low terrace finger between a tertiary stream and an intermittent drainage (now a low area in a plowed field) that feed into Stiff Creek to the south. The site is located in an active agricultural field and is bisected by a natural gas pipeline. There is no vegetation cover on the site itself, although a small copse of trees and underbrush abuts the western edge of the site. A modern barn and stock dam lie immediately southwest of the site across a fence demarcating the property boundary. FM 1827 passes roughly 280 m west of the site. The fields surrounding the site are open and landmarks are few, although the dissected upland terraces provide an undulating character to the landscape.
time_desc: Diagnostic artifacts from surface collection and shovel tests
basis: Diagnostic artifacts indicate mid- to late-19th century, early- to mid-20th century, and modern occupations
cult_desc: None observed ; No records of a homestead or farmstead at this location have been located.
basis_top: Artifacts observed on modern ground surface
artifact: A high-density scatter of historic artifacts and modern trash was observed on the modern ground surface, and a non-controlled sample was collected.  Artifacts include stoneware sherds (including Bristol slipped, natural clay slipped, salt-vapored), ironstone sherds (including blue-tinted), whiteware, porcelin sherds, manganese bottle glass, other colored glass fragments, embossed milk glass, building debris (brick fragments, shaped stones), metal (wire nails, clips and tool fragments), and window glass. Artifact densities are highest in the approximate center of the site, and some lateral dispersion from plowing and downslope erosion to the east and west is evident. Nodules of melted glass suggest that one or more of the structures once present burned. No cultural features were observed, and it is unlikely that any remain.
circum: Bright, sunny day; 11 am - 12:30 pm; excellent ground visibility (survey conditions ideal; field harvested, turned-over, rained on)
natural: Natural erosion from sheetwash, gullying and rilling
artificial: Plowing, construction associated with installation and maintenance of natural gas pipeline
future: Construction of new subsurface water transmission pipeline (86-in-diameter) through site center; continued plowing and erosion
value: The site currently possesses virtually no contextual integrity, and is considered to have very little to no research potential. The site consists of the remains of a late 19th- to mid-20th-century farmstead or homestead, but the only remains of occupation consist of an artifact scatter in a disturbed context (plowzone).
invest: None; No further investigations are recommended at the site. The site is highly disturbed and possesses very little research potential. Any standing structures and cultural features once present have been removed or otherwise destroyed, and plowing has destroyed the contextual integrity of the artifacts.

sitename: No Data; McKinney African American Cemetery
projname: City of McKinney Historic Cemetery Delineation
additional:
Gough, Jay, and Ned Hoover.  1995.  Cemeteries of Collin County.  Privately published.

Tine, Angela L., and Melissa M. Green.  2000.  An Archeological Delineation of a Historic African American Cemetery in McKinney, Texas.  Letter Report No. 44.  Geo-Marine, Inc., Plano, Texas.
records: daily journal, map drawings, print log, prints, slide logs, slides, aerials
desc_loc: Within city limits of the south side of Wilson Creek Parkway and immediately east of Town Lake Recreation Area.
ownerinfo: City of Mckinney, 308 North Tennessee, McKinney, TX  75070  Phone:  (972) 547-7480
env_desc: The known site is primarily within a tree stand separated by a dirt lane from a historic tree nursery to the east.  The tree stand is surrounded by a grassy field to the south and west and is slightly elevated in relation to the field.  North of the tree stand is a grass-covered buffer (which contains burials) that separates the trees from the eastbound lanes of Wilson Creek Parkway.  Fill for construction of the road leaves the street and grassy buffer area elevated in relation to the rest of the site.  The ground of the tree stand is primarily covered with periwinkle.
basis: Oral history; shape and organization of burial shafts, absence of prehistoric artifacts
cult_desc: A minimum of five historic grave outlines are present.  These are oriented east to west along the long axis.  The graves appear to be in north-south running rows.
basis_top: Distance from top of grave shaft to ground surface
artifact: None - no collections made
circum: Presence of trees and underground utility lines; part of cemetery likely under paved road
future: Use of area by the city as a recreational facility.  City plans to fence off cemetery to avoid impact.
value: Relatively little known about the lives of historic African Americans in national, state, or local history
invest: No further work; physical delineation and avoidance of area have already been recommended and agreed upon
disc_desc: oral informant believes that half or more of the cemetery has been paved over with Wilson Creek Parkway.  The presence of burials in the grassy easement between the road and tree stand where burials were thought to be supports this possibility.
attachmem:
1.  Copy of topo map showing site location
2.  Plan map of site

sitename: No Data; Houston Texas Central & New Orleans RR arch bridge
projname: Houston Texas Central & New Orleans RR arch bridge
recname: Melinda Fisher and David Petefish  (DP address see Owner)
temphouse: Melinda Fisher, 831 Timberwood Ln.,  McKinney, TX  75069
desc_loc: Where RR tracks cross Sloan Creek just west of Hwy 5 and east of Hwy 75.
ownerinfo:
Virginia Lea (sister), 1226 Cherokee, Richardson, TX  75080, tel: 972-234-4999
David Petefish (brother), PMB 105, 151 S. W. Plaza, Arlington, TX  76016-4453, tel: 817-572-5670
informinfo:
Nancy Bush Morian (Mrs. Frazer), 101 Westwood Circle, McKinney, Tx  75070
Tel: 972-562-1686  (grew up there, lived at site)
env_desc: Blackland Prairie - white rock creek bottom.
time_desc: 1872+ was called Bush Springs with a small recreational dam and BBQ pit for local people who traveled there on the interurban for the day.
cult_desc: Large remnants of 6ft. tall concrete dam east of RR bridge - ruined by a flood in the 1930's.  Homesite of Edgar Bush - "first mayor of Fairview".  Original Bush family was a large prominent family in Collin County history.
site_size: Brick & stone arch approx 13 x 17 ft high; 50' length of arch & 30" of wing walls
artifact: "Early made brick arch (4 layers of brick with cut rock support).  Cutrock finished at edges, typical of 1872-1900 type work. Est. source of rock quarried east of McKinney. Brick probably from Palmer area of Texas.  No names or dates are on bricks or bridge."  David Petefish.
natural: Separating wind wall NW cut rock supports being undercut (can be stabilized by concrete sill at base).  D. Petefish
artificial: In path at DART (Dallas Area Rapid Transit)
future: Probable removal by DART.  Can be saved by use of pilings through embankment - support RR about as cheap as new bridge.
value: One of the last brick arch bridges along RR.  Beautiful example of "Italian" brick masonry in bridges prior to 1900.  100-125+ years old.
regist: as part of future city park
disc_desc:
Farm largely developed from 1920's.  Used to have cement terraces to control erosion.  Now they are piled at the north side of creek near the RR bridge.
    1/4 mile south of arch bridge is a smaller 6' tall bridge of all brick.
   On south side of Sloan Creek, east of RR tracks, is a site where an old log cabin stood.  Before 1910 it had fallen in.  Bush Road is here.
    2 old postal roads are probably on this property.  This property has been used only for grazing - the owners have preserved the historical areas.
attachmem:
Photo A 1872 RR bridge
Photo B of telegraph wire
Photos CD smaller 6' arch bridge
Sketch A - large Rr bridge by David Petefish
Sketch B - by M. Fisher

additional:
This site is located on a very high knoll, 400 yds NW of the junction of Wilson Creek and East Fork, on the north side of Wilson Creek and west side of East Fork.  This knoll forms the southeastern end of a ridge extending into the East Fork bottomlands.  On the south slope of the knoll, near an old spring is a 1/4 acre or more of refuse.  Very little was found other than refuse, but it is a pottery site, probably of a small, temporary camp.
No further work need be done here

disc_desc: This site occupies at least the south slope of a very high, isolated knoll at the edge of the bottoms.  Surrounded on north, east, and south by timbered area.  Cultivated are to the west and northwest

sitename: No Data; St. Mary's Baptist Church
additional: St. Mary's Church was given to the Alleu Heritage Guild by Rev. Anderson in 1999.  It was located within a block community that is mostly gone now.  The church is being restored presently Rev. Anderson was a long time pastor of this church.
surf_tech: surface collection, under church and church kitchen additional when floorboards were removed in spring 01.
temphouse: 831 TIMBERWOOD LN.  HOME OF MELINDA FISHER
desc_loc: go to north main st. in downtown allen.  go north on cedar sevial block.  go right in St. Mary's Drive.  The shurch is located jst before the creek on the right.  It is across the street from a brand new lighted well maintained soccer feild for Allen Station Park.  The Allen Park Dept. is planning fir this St, Mary's area to be te site of a historical village.  Other old homes are planned to be moved here.  The AHG plans to move the Bush house onto this property behind the church.

722 sycamore creek
alley, tx 75002
390-1744

972-727-3137
env_desc: flat surface, read in front od the church North creek beside and behind east flat clear lot on west side that is surrounded by a chain link fease.  Creek has been used by dumping mostly of building materials.
cult_desc: Church- septic tawk hole wast toward the creek.  The kitchen addition was done in the 1940's and had to be replaced due to substandard consruction.  After the church was moved it was expanded toward the back and lengthened to original structure was leaning toward the back and not connected.  Photos of this are included.  The rest of the lot is low flat and cleared, but many small homes were once located there and accross the road in the present soccer feild.
artifact: photos to be sent later.  I used to label them with their site number first.
circum: good conditions, area is mowed regularly
future: City of Allen plans to preserve and use as a wedding chapel.  Will be landscaped well.
value: surface collection only to show and display old artifacts in the church.  No obvious ald trash pit could be located.  Enough items have been secured.  I plan to monitor
invest: the inctallatior of the sprinkler system and landscapping in order to record and pressure any new findings, before they are lost.
disc_desc: outhouse is missing, however another outhouse in lying in the creekside directly behind the church due E.  Rev. Anderson started that this was not the church outhouse, but from another home that was located behind the church.
attachmem: survey, photo of St. Mary's and markers newspaper.  Map of area to be sent later.

desc_loc: The site is located in a plowed field .4 km south of the intersection of County roads 472 and 474.
drainage: an unnamed branch of Sister Grove Creek
soil_desc: Collin County Soil Survey, Burleson Grey Black Clay
env_desc: The site is located in a plowed field on the east side of the fence line, with what appear to be cotton seedlings starting to sprout. The west side of the fence had dead wheat still standing.
artifact: Prehistoric:tested cobbles, and primary flakes
circum: clear warm sunny day in a plowed field
disc_desc:
The site is located in a plowed field. The site is defined by a long scatter of quartz cobbles(ogallala) in a 70m strip running somewhat parallel with a fenceline. Mixed with these cobbles are several tested cobbles and primary debitage. The density of the artifacts was quite low perhaps one culturally altered stone every 10m square.


A total of four shovel tests were placed in the site and right-of-way all were culturally negative. One of the shovel tests were forced to 60 cmbgs, through the compact clay to explore the extent of the soils.

records: computer disks, map drawings, shovel test records, print log, prints
desc_loc: The site is located at the intersection of county road 475 and county road 503.
soil_desc: Collin County Soil Survey, Leiwsville Silty Clay
env_desc: The site rests on the uplands overlooking the Sister Grove Creek floodplain. While the site is in pastureland the surrounding properties are plowed field with better visiblity.  The lack of cultural material in the surrounding field indicates that the site was contained to the pastureland property. The soil here is light grey brown in color and has a strong clay content. The vegetation is pasture grass, low brush, and ceder.
artifact:
Clear, brown, and amethyst glass
undecorated whiteware
circum: clear warm sunny day with only low vegetation
disc_desc:
The site is a historic surface scatter on a hilltop overlooking the Sister Grove Creek. An intensive visual surface survey revealed no sign of structural remains. The artifacts have a density of approximately two per meter square. The only other thing of note is that there is a area that was recently burned at the eastern edge of the site that had a larger concentration of historic artifacts. Perhaps they were raked into a pile with other garbage.

A total of 6 shovel tests were attempted on the site none of which were positive with cultural artifacts. One shovel test was forced to 60 cm to in order to explore the extent of the clay soil.

records: computer disks, map drawings, shovel test records, print log, prints
desc_loc: The site is located west of the intersection of FM 2862 and CR503 approximately .45 km.
soil_desc: Collin County Soil Survey, Hunt Clay
surf_tex: dry flaky surface to wet compact clay
env_desc: The site is located in a field with sorghum approximately knee high. Evidence of corn cobs throughout the field suggest that the crops are rotated regularly. The soil was a dark grey black clay that showed evidence of erosion in many areas.
artifact:
Clear, brown, and blue glass
undecorated whiteware
a horseshoe, and other unidentified metal
circum: clear warm sunny day in sorghum field
disc_desc:
The site is a historic surface scatter on a hilltop in a cultivated field. The scatter density was approximately one artifact ever square meter. No evidence of a structure was located.

A total of four shovel tests were placed in the site all of which were culturally negative. One of the shovel tests was forced through the clay to determine the extent of the clay subsoil which was halted at 60 cm with no change.

disc_desc:
This site is flat and unimpressive, However, it is on Hwy 5, which used to be Hwy 75. this follwos near to the old Houston and Texas Central RR tracks. Therefore it is amid our surviving histoical homes. This site is due North 1/2 mile from the Bush House that is over 150 years old. It is worth remembering in photos and history and exhibiting some artifacts.

The city of Allen has its first historical society begun in 1996.  We plan to keep this from happning again.  The city awareness of historical important was raised bt discovery of the Allen Station Railway Dr. very near to this site.

Artifacts are found at the base of very large trees and near fence posts.  see attatchd sheets fpr description and drawind of the well.
artifact: recent and older trash from this house is found, especially toward the rear of the yard and where soil has been eroded away.  Old 1800's medicine bottle fragments, peices of bottle fragments, peices of broken dishes, square cut and round nails.  The immediate perimeter of the house has an elevated flower bed and is free of artifacts.
natural: hwy 5 was widended recently and this cut-off part of the fron tyard.  Weathering
future: the house will be demolished soon if the Allen Heritage Guild does not move it.
value: asked allan skinner for advice on excavating the bottom of the well for artifacts.  More surface collection in hopes of finding mid 1800 items for display
invest: the AHG would like to have some artifacts for display that are more whole.  Possibly some whole of 1/2 of late 1800's medicine bottles can be found at the bottom of the well.  Or marbles, etc.

records: aerials, map drawings, print log, oral history transcripts
desc_loc: It is located just east of Vaughn Elemntary School across the street (named Cottonwood Dr.) and west of Cottonwood Creek. This is about 200 ft. south of the pipe that crosses Cottonwood Creek and is surrounded by a chain link fence.
water: Cottonwood Creek to the east about 25 ft.
ownerinfo: City of Allen Parks and Recreation Dept.   1 Butler Circle   Allen, TX 75002   (972)-727-0140
informinfo: O. Ed Lynge   3 Whisenant Circle   Allen, TX 75002   (972)-727-3393
env_desc: east of Vaughn Elementary School in Allen. east of the road (Cottonwood Dr.) and west of Cottonwood Creek. All mowed bermuda grass, kept up as park property. Was probably cleared and leveled with bulldozers when the sidewalks were put in. drops off steeply into the creek. See photo taken from site. Heavily wooded near the steep slope. A curved draw is to the north of the site where the wagons used to go down to the creek.
cult_desc: no evidence of the school still exists. It is a flat area bounded by Cottonwood Creek Park walkway with a sidewald on the east and a road (Cottonwood Dr.) on the west. Mowed Bermuda grass throughout. The Creek is spring fed with a large spring that even ran during droughts was located here. The farmers used to fill barrelles up in their wagons to take back to the homesteads.
artifact: none
circum: Bermuda grass over site; creek draw and creeksides are heavily wooded.
intact: 0% of schoolsite; some artifacts possible from wagons going down to river.
value: Good place for a city of Allen historical marker.
invest: could surface inspect the creek and the draw during winter when the vegetation is dormant and look for evidence of pioneer occupation.
disc_desc: This would be a good site for a historical marker. Many people, especially school children, would be able to see it. It is interesting to see that a current Allen School is built so close to this very site. There is no relationship to Vaughn Elementary School except that they were both Allen schools. Possibly there are artifacts left on the creekside or in the draw since there is heavy vegetation there and probably not much traffic recently.

Roy F. Hall, letter about the old Wetsel school house from the archives of Capt. Roy Hall, Photographic log with one photo of a wooden toy gun, interview with Ed Lynge, report on site surface inspection done in June 2001, by Lindy Fisher and Marie Burton.

explain: No Data; Flat piece of property at the SW corner of Stacy Rd. and Hwy. 5 in Allen, Texas. An old school was located there for about 90 years. A teacherage was also there.
additional: Gwen Pettit's newspaper column on the Wetsel family and the Wetsel Gas Station. She now lives in Leonard, Texas.
records: aerials, map drawings, print log, oral history transcripts, archival notes, newpaper article by Gwen Pettit "Between the Creeks," early Collin County school records from the Post Office Museum in McKinney
desc_loc: at SW corner of Hwy 5 and Stacy Rd. In Allen, Texas inside old triangle
water: Cottonwood Creek to west, Sloan creek to NE
ownerinfo: Exxon-Mobil Oil Co.- Mark Zuschek  3225 Gallows Rd.    Fairfax, VA  22037   (703)-846-2793
informinfo: O. Ed Lynge   3 Whisenant Circle   Allen, TX 75002   (972)-727-3393
env_desc: flat traffic island without buildings for the last 50-60 years. Old Reid Farmstead was due west and vacant since 1990
time_desc: objects found from 1800s. and location of site from verbal histories and early school records
cult_desc: flat ground, 1942 aerial photo shows the old stage line that this school faced. The newer paved Hwy 5 was made to be straighter and went behind the schoolhouse. A few trees are located here. Trucks and cars have driven on and parked here often. It has been a vacant lot for the last 50 years.
artifact: No Data
circum: mowed native grasses. A few clumps of native trees.
intact: school was moved about 60 years ago.
artificial: cars and trucks drive over this lot and park here.
future: an Exxon station is planned for here soon.
value: This is a particular interest ot the City of Allen. They are obtianing city site markers for their historical school sites. They want historical objects and history saved for their museum.
invest: Need to map and explore whatever artifacts may be left on this site. And save them for Allen to display. The Exxon Co. will probably be asked to leage a place for an historical marker. They are already interested in the historical preservation endeavor by giving us a basic access agreement to work on this site.
disc_desc: Henry Wetsel and his 3 sons and one son-in-law headrighted land in this area. They had 640 acres each. They had a wood mill here and they were furniture , cabinet, and coffin makers. They donated the land for this school. This corner was known as Wetsel for a while in the 1800s. The schoolhouse was moved around the 1940s and the lot has been vacant ever since. It is a traffic triangle. A fruit stand stood on the NW corner and the Fairview metal water tower is also on that corner. There used to be a teacherage next to the school. During WWII there was a canning building at this site. The Reid farmstead was due west of this site about 300 yards. An aerial photo from 1942 shows the location of the old stage road in relation to this schoolhouse. Bonnie and Clyde were reported as having stopped at this old Wetsel gas station.
attachmem: See photo of toy wooden rifle and photo of the Wetsel gas station that was located on the NW or SW corner of this intersection, topographic map section, aerial photo of site from 1942, city map section, New article by Gwen Pettit, early Collin County school records..

desc_loc: Site 202001-6 is a prehistoric lithic scatter/open campsite located in the southeastern corner of Collin County. The site lies on the upland slope ca. 300 m west of Bois d'Arc Creek, a tributary of the Sabine River.
water: 300 m west of Bois d'Arc Creek
soil_desc: Houston Black clay soils are mapped for this area.
env_desc: Site 202001-6 is a prehistoric lithic scatter/open campsite located in the southeastern corner of Collin County. The site lies on the upland slope ca. 300 m west of Bois d'Arc Creek, a tributary of the Sabine River.
time_desc: lithic scatter with no diagnostic artifacts
site_size: a. 140 m northeast-southwest by 100 m southeast-northwest
artifact: The site was identified when 5-10 flakes and 2 burned rocks were observed scattered over an area of ca. 140 m northeast-southwest by 100 m southeast-northwest.  Recently plowed agricultural terraces provided excellent ground surface visibility. Six shovel tests were excavated to a depth of 50 cm below the surface, but none yielded cultural materials.
invest: Site 202001-6 is an extremely sparse scatter of lithic debitage and burned rocks. Due to disturbance from terracing and plowing, the surficial nature of the cultural remains, the sparseness of artifacts, and the lack of temporally diagnostic artifacts or datable organic materials, the site appears to lack the capacity to yield important information. It is considered ineligible for listing in the National Register of Historic Places. No further work is recommended.
disc_desc: Site 202001-6 is a prehistoric lithic scatter/open campsite located in the southeastern corner of Collin County. The site lies on the upland slope ca. 300 m west of Bois d'Arc Creek, a tributary of the Sabine River. Houston Black clay soils are mapped for this area. The site was identified when 5-10 flakes and 2 burned rocks were observed scattered over an area of ca. 140 m northeast-southwest by 100 m southeast-northwest.  Recently plowed agricultural terraces provided excellent ground surface visibility. Six shovel tests were excavated to a depth of 50 cm below the surface, but none yielded cultural materials. As staked originally and as shown on air photo sheet 1148, the pipeline route bisects the site; however, the route was moved to the east at the landowner's request, and the currently staked alignment bypasses the site.

This site is located on the east side of Tickey Creek, one mile due south of the community of Culeoka and 200 yds east of the Tickey Creek crossing of a county road from Culeoka.  It occupies a low ridge adjacent to the creek floodplain and is profusely strewn with camp refuse.  No artifacts were recovered.  The site is nearly identical to 41-18D7-10 and is a non-pottery campsite of moderately extensive occupation
No further work need be done here

additional: This site is located on the north bank of Elm Creek, 500 yds east of the Lavon-Farmersville highway and adjacent to the Gulf Coast and Santa Fe Railroad, and on a slight slope leading from Elm Creek to the uplands.  It is apparently a small campsite.  No artifacts were recovered here but the landowner reports several fragmentary burials and some projectile points were recovered during cultivation.  He stated that no artifacts accompanied the burials, (however, he was not looking for artifacts when he discovered the burials and only noted the burials incidentally).  At any rate no pottery has been reported here.  No further work need be contemplated at this site

additional: This site is located on the eastern edge of the Pilot Grove Creek floodplain, 1 3/4 miles south of highway #24, 1,500 ft east of that stream and 3,000 ft southeast of the junction of Pilot Grove and Sister Grove Creeks.  An overflow slough of Pilot Grove cuts through the site with an accompanying zone of brush and willows.  The remainder of the site, 3 to 4 acres is under cultivation.  This is a relatively large site and profusely strewn with camp refuse.  Artifacts were not plentifual but some were found.  The site may be one of the large pottery villages but no wattle  impressed daub, or other evidences of house structures were located nor was one of the large "ceremonial pits" found.  An extended test trench eas and west and one north and south is recommended here as it is though that considerable information can be derived from this site.  Priority A and 0.25 excavation units are recommended

None other numbered specimens are not artifacts

additional:
Lower Farmersville; this site is located on the west bank of Pilot Grove Creek in the floodplain, on a very small rise.  It is frequently inundated.  A small amount of refuse marks the surface and occasional artifacts are found.  It may have been a larger site in the past but if so most of the cultural material has been washed away.  Pottery is reported here but none was found nor seen.
Cultural affiliation is indeterminable from this small amount of material but probably fits into the culture of the large pottery sites.  No further work need be done here

Observed a great amount of lithic debris and firecracked rock in Henry's excavation; Situated on the edge of the terrace leading out of the Pilot Grove Creek floodplain, it covers 4 or 5 acres and it lies on both sides of the county road. additional: Farmersville Mound; Pot hunting; This site, at the junction of Potrack and Indian Creeks, is apparently a large artificial mound.  It is 15 to 18 ft long and 200 ft wide, ovoid in shape and terraced.  The upper section is roughly 100 ft in diameter and circular.  Considerable refuse in the form of mussel shell, flint chips, bone etc. were found over the surface.  It is recommended that a test trench be dug across this mound to determine its origin.  The surrounding field showed no signs of cultural material but this may have been due to the grass covering that was quite heavy at this time

visible: 0 percent on hilltop; slopes average 30 percent.
env_desc: Large sandy hill with dense grass cover and a few scattered trees, erosion present on base on all sides.; Upland hilltop adjacent to the former flood plain of Pilot Grove Creek.  Tall grasses cover the hilltop, and evergreen trees are interspersed throughout.
time_desc: Site was originally reported as a prehistoric lithic scatter possessing no diagnostic artifacts.
artifact: No artifactual materials were observed.
circum: There was no ground visibility on the hilltop.  Due to erosion, there was patchy ground visibility on the hillsides.
intact: Due to shaving off of S slope, 1 observed a light colored sandy soil with a dark band starting at surface and extending about 2 ft down.; No evidence of the site was observed.
landuse: Land is now part of Caddo State Park.  A boat ramp and parking lot is directly north of the site.
artificial: Landscaping, contouring, construction of US 380, the boat ramp, and parking lot.  Site is accessible to the public.
future: Further construction along US 380; continued access by the public; any improvements to the park in that area.
value: Because testing and survey has failed to identify any remaining portion of this site originally recorded in 1973, the site is deemed ineligible for inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP).
invest: Massive lithic scatters, perhaps not too promising due to lack of associated tools, however when land is stripped as archeologist should be called to check for deposition and placement of artifacts.; No further investigations at this site are recommended.
regist: The site is not considered potentially eligible for inclusion in the NRHP.
disc_desc:
Great amount of lithic debris, many core fragments, bifaces, no points or ceramics.  No concentrations of fire cracked rock. Lithic scatters on crest and upper W/E slopes.; The site was originally discovered during a surface survey conducted by J. Sledge and D. Gibson in 1973.   The site consisted of a large quantity of lithic debris, including core fragments and bifaces, but not ceramics or projectile points.   US 380 was still under construction.  Although the recorders make reference to the hill  (elevation of 157.0 m [515 ft] amsl), its areal extent is unclear. Today, the hill on which site 41COL56 is located is extremely steep sided,  measuring approximately 10 x 15 m.  On the hilltop, grass cover and a few evergreen trees prevent any ground visibility, but visibility on the slopes is patchy.

The current investigations began by conducting a  surface inspection in 5-m interval transects, including the lake shore and slopes, where ground averages 30 percent.  In order to identify any possible subsurface deposits, seven shovel tests in a cruciform pattern oriented in the cardinal directions and spaced at 5-m intervals were excavated on the hilltop.  With the exception of ST1, all shovel tests exhibited yellowish brown (10YR5/6) silty, sandy, clay with numerous pebble inclusions.  Shovel test 1 contained a dark yellowish brown (10YR3/3) silty clay.

No artifacts were found in any of the shovel tests, and only gravel was observed on the surface of the slopes.  A high degree of disturbance, access by the public, exposure and erosion are all factors that would account for the disappearance of the site.  Bridge and highway construction, followed by the addition of the parking lot and boat ramp, has led to the exposure and the subsequent erosion evident along the western and eastern sides of the hill.  The USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle (Culleoka 1960, photorevised1968, photoinspected 1973) further indicates that the hill was once part of a ridge that has been destroyed during construction episodes.
unmatched: site_situ: Site located primarily on crest of hill, however, lithic debris very prevelent on E/W slopes, N slope very sparse, no flooding at main concentration however erosion present on all bases of hill.

desc_loc: Site is located in a small cluster of trees amidst an area which has been heavily developed by the Stonebridge Ranch Project. The site is approximately 4.3 km west of Highway 75 and 2.5 km north of Highway 720. A greenhouse/nursey is located roughly 350 m to the northwest. The site is located in the Briar Ridge Village Development of the Stonebridge Ranch Project (LaVardera 1988).
informinfo: Jerry Ragsdale, Republic Investments, Dallas, TX
soil_desc: Austin silty clay, 1 to 3 percent slopes
env_desc: Site is located on a north trending slope in the Briar Ridge Village section of Stonebridge Ranch. Area around cemetery has been significantly altered by development.
cult_desc: A total of 7 marked graves are located in the cemetery. Two unmarked children's graves and an unmarked negro grave are also noted in Collin County Cemetery Inscriptions, however these were not observed during this recording. Two small depressions do occur in the northeast corner of the cemetery and may be unmarked graves (LaVardera 1988).
artifact: marble and granite headstones and footstones (LaVardera 1988).
future: Site is being protected from future disturbance by a stone wall constructed around site area by the developer.
value: Site should be considered as a state archaeological landmark because of the role George McGarrah had in the development of the area. The McKinney Historic Society will maintain control and grounds keeping of this site  (LaVardera 1988).
disc_desc: The seven marked graves are oriented with the headstones to the west and the footstones on the east. The cemetery is the family cemetery of George McGarrah, an early settler in the McKinney area (LaVardera 1988).

desc_loc: Site is located on the west side of Grey Branch tributary of Wilson Creek. The site is situated in a pasture with scattered elm, hackberry, and juniper approximately 2 km east of Highway 2478 and 3.8 km south of Highway 24. Site is roughly 100 m east of Stonebridge Ranch Drive.
soil_desc: Houston Black clay, 1 to 3 percent slopes
env_desc: Site is situated on the first terrace of Grey Branch of Wilson Creek. A plowed field is located to the east. Stonebridge Ranch Drive is located approximately 100 m west of the site.
cult_desc: Site consists of a small, four room house, two barns, and a collapsed outhouse building. House is constructed of horizontal boards and has a metal, pitched roof. A screened porch is located on the front or east side of the house. House does not have a chimney and is supported on a wood block foundation. The barns are constructed of wood and corrugated metal. Several small pens are also present (LaVardera 1988).
artifact: Clear glass, green glass, metal fragments. Artifacts appear to be fairly recent and relatively few in number (LaVardera 1988).
invest: Archival research to determine dates of occupation and ownership (LaVardera 1988).
disc_desc: The site probably represents a small homestead or ranch. No well was located on site and water may have come directly from the creek. Site appears to have been abandoned for approximately 10 to 20 years (LaVardera 1988).

desc_loc: On  the bluff above Spring Creek 0.3 km east of the S.P. RR line, actually outside of the park area; The site is on both sides of the Southern Pacific RR tracks east of Central Expressway (U.S. 75) and contains Routh cemetery, an unnamed cemetery, a gravel pit, a well, and two structures that are shown on the Garland quadrangle.   The site center is about 800 SW of the 605 ft elevation at the intersection of Renner Rd and Greenville Ave,  750 m NW of BM 574 along Greenville Ave,  620 m SE of the 582 ft elevation at the intersection of Renner Rd and the southbound US 75 frontage rd, and 780 m north of the Dallas/Collin county line.
water: Spring Creek is the north boundary of the site

ownerinfo: Private; William Herbert Hunt Trust EstateTX
soil_desc: Altoga silty clay loam, 5-8% slopes, eroded; Austin silty clay, 3-5% slopes, eroded; Eddy gravelly clay loam, 3-8% slopes, eroded; Houston Black clay, 1-3% slopes
env_desc: On bluff above creek, there was a steep bluff south of the creek and a floodplain on the north side of the creek; This historic farmstead is located on the terrace of Spring Creek.  Spring Creek is the northern site boundary and part of the western boundary.  Most  of the site is located in wooded areas consisting of various hardwoods, evergreens, mixed short grasses and tall grasses, and briars.
cult_desc:
The cemetery is outlined with a wrought-iron fence which has been partially repaired with chainlink, there are 3 headstones with the bodies placed E-W with headstones on the west side, the north headstone is a rectangular sandstone slab with a rounded top, the stone reads Jacob Routh, BORR DEC. 22, 1818, DIED APR. 30, 1879 and below ASLEEP IN JESUS
The next is a natural granite boulder that reads MRS L.A. ROUTH, NOV. 16, 1833 - OCT 8, 1916.
The third reads ROUTH,ROSE  SEPT. 18, 1879 - SEPT 24, 1954 and CLARA  JUNE 7, 1876 - JUNE 1, 1962; Two circular, corrugated tin troughs approximately 5 m in diameter; four white brick gate/property markers near the creek, with two of these in situ while the other two have been pushed over; a picket fence measuring 22 m N-S x 8 m E-W; a rock wall ca. 20 cm thick and 20 m long; wooden drainage next to old road; old concrete road with bridge supports on both sides of creek; wooden supports of swing bridge - these are on both sides of creek; two family cemeteries; one pet cemetery; laborers house/trash pile; well house; modern outbuildings and trailers; None
site_size: 400 m E-W x 285 m NS; Based on historic information
basis_thk: Shovel testing; Whichever was needed for interment
artifact: Subsurface artifacts include brick, whiteware, square nails, bone, aqua and clear glass, window glass, RR spike, decorated pipe fragment, decorated brown glass, earthenware, and amethyst glass
landuse: Cedar elms are common on upland; two cemeteries; woodland; dumping along western edge
natural: Erosion; Natural erosion, nearby gravel quarrying
artificial: RR construction, recreation (fishing at creek, and walking park along east edge)
future: Should not be impacted by park project as designed; The DART North Central Corridor will impact a small portion at the west edge of the site
value: Site 41COL 83 may still retain some research potential as it has good contextual integrity and there several lines of evident that could be pursued, such as archival data,  oral history  of the Routh family and their impact upon the site.  Many of the feature on the site are intact to some degree; much of the interior portion of the site has been intentionally left alone by the present owners.   However, most of the site is outside the DART corridor and this includes many of the important areas of the site.   The site is considered of unknown eligibility for inclusion in the NRHP or as a State Archeological Landmark.; TRUE
invest: No further work; Despite being recommended as of unknown eligibility for inclusion in the NRHP, it is considered that the proposed DART action will, at worst, impact upon an insignificant portion of the site.; Protect from disturbance by park development
disc_desc: Site 41COL 83 was originally recorded by S.A. Skinner and was considered to consist only of the Routh Cemetery.  During the current investigation, additional, associated components were encountered,  such as the Jacob Routh Pioneer Cemetery,  the pet cemetery, the homestead, and a laborers home.  Rather that define a new site, it was decided that adding these components to the already recorded and associated Routh Cemetery was more appropriate.  Since the initial recordation, the Routh Cemetery does not appear to have been additionally impacted.

The third reads ROUTH,ROSE  SEPT. 18, 1879 - SEPT 24, 1954 and CLARA  JUNE 7, 1876 - JUNE 1, 1962; Two circular, corrugated tin troughs approximately 5 m in diameter; four white brick gate/property markers near the creek, with two of these in situ while the other two have been pushed over; a picket fence measuring 22 m N-S x 8 m E-W; a rock wall ca. 20 cm thick and 20 m long; wooden drainage next to old road; old concrete road with bridge supports on both sides of creek; wooden supports of swing bridge - these are on both sides of creek; two family cemeteries; one pet cemetery; laborers house/trash pile; well house; modern outbuildings and trailers; None. Site 41COL 83 was originally recorded by S.A. Skinner and was considered to consist only of the Routh Cemetery.  During the current investigation, additional, associated components were encountered,  such as the Jacob Routh Pioneer Cemetery,  the pet cemetery, the homestead, and a laborers home.  Rather that define a new site, it was decided that adding these components to the already recorded and associated Routh Cemetery was more appropriate.  Since the initial recordation, the Routh Cemetery does not appear to have been additionally impacted.. No Data

cult_desc: A berm running a majority of the length of the north/south tree line and a shallow ditch along the east/west tree line second from the south end of the site. Both the berm and ditch appear to be from the original fence line location, which has now been replaced by the tree line. Additionally, two square fence posts are located at the southwest end of the site.; Remaining structures on the site consist of the principal residence (west-facing  original 2 room house [w/shed rooms to rear and off set front porch roof] heavily altered by addition of additional roomsand an attached garage to the rear, ca. 1960), two barns/corrals to the S, and associated smaller sheds and outbuildings between the barns and creek to S.

disc_desc: the site dimensions were expanded west of Emerald Coast Drive where there are three tree lines running east/west and a north/south tree line that used to be fence lines. The north/south fence line was approximately 78 meters west of the existing site boundary marking the western end of an old cattle or horse grazing area. Parallel to the north/south tree line is a berm that runs nearly the entire length, which could have been an erosional control method. Additionally, a shallow ditch runs along the east/west tree line closest to Chapparral Drive. At the southwest corner of the site two square fence posts were observed that still have some barbed wire attached. Determination that old fence lines once existed was based on the remnants of old fence embedded into one of the trees on the second tree line row from the south. A total of ten shovel tests were excavated within the addition to the site and all were negative for cultural material. The remainder of the site east of Emerald Coast Drive that consisted of structures (the farm house) has been completely destroyed. A housing subdivision now occupies the land where the old farmstead house once stood.

cult_desc: 8 plus graves with limestone markers, 4 of which are wholly legible.  Published references to the cemetery point to the possible existence of up to 100 graves here.  The grove of hackberry trees is said by informants to have never been cut and it is visible in Texas Department of Transportation 1938 Tobin aerial photographs and 1964 Soil Conservation Service aerial photographs.

additional:
Site form generated from information provided in the following:
Hunt, Steven M., Melinda Goelz, Duane E. Peter, and Melissa M. Green (1998) Intensive Pedestrian Survey and Geoarcheological Investigation at the Proposed Princeton Lift Station Project, Collin County, Texas.
recname: Kevin Stone, Josh McCormick, Alexandra Younger

permhouse: Texas Archeological Research Laboratory, The University of Texas at Austin
desc_loc: Site 41COL98 is approximately 180 m south of Myrick Lane, 400 m east of South Bridgefarmer Road in Lowry Crossing
soil_desc: Lewisville silty clay, 3 to 5 percent slopes, eroded
env_desc: Top of a slope rising from East Fork bottoms, mainly grass with hackberry trees.
basis_size: extent of positive shovel tests and surface artifacts
basis_top: artifacts recovered at depths of 0-20 cmbs in shovel tests
basis_thk: no artifacts recovered below 20 cmbs in STs
artifact: machine-made brick, metal fragments, nails
value: Site 41COL98 is a small, very low density historic site, probably occupied during the twentieth century. Given the lack of any domestic artifacts from the assemblage, the site likely represents an outbuilding rather than a residential site. A structure is shown in this location on the 1930 map of the area (Beck et al. 1930), the 1936 highway map, and the McKinney East quadrangle. Given the fair contextual integrity and dearth of subsurface deposits at site 41COLCOL98, as well as the presumed function of the site, it is considered to have little research potential. Therefore, site 41COLCOL98 is considered to be ineligible for inclusion in the NRHP or for nomination as a SAL  (Hunt et al. 1998).
invest: No further work is recommended at this site  (Hunt et al. 1998).
disc_desc: Site 41COLCOL98 was defined primarily through the presence of an extensive scatter of bricks and metal, in the location of a structure shown on the early soil map (Beck et al. 1930), the 1936 General Highway Map of Collin County, and the McKinney East quadrangle (1960, photo revised 1968, photo inspected 1973). The structure is represented on the McKinney East quadrangle with the symbol for an outbuilding. The structure is no longer extant. Site 41COLCOL98 is primarily composed of a surface scatter of machine-made brick and unidentified metal fragments. Some of the brick was embossed with 'CHRISTY ST. LOUIS.' In addition to the surface scatter, one 8d wire nail was collected through shovel testing. No features were observed at the site  (Hunt et al. 1998).

disc_desc: As a part of the 2016 IES survey, site 41COL99 was revisited to verify the site?s presence and the THC?s NRHP eligibility determination.  During the survey, investigators observed that the site had been heavily disturbed by past agricultural activities.    A low density trash scatter of historic-period artifacts was observed near the original recorded centroid of the site.  Nine shovel tests were excavated within and adjacent to the site.  Three shovel tests were positive and yielded a porcelain ceramic sherd, three purpled glass shards, and a clear glass shard.

soil_desc: Sandy clay surface to bottom of test pit (2 meters below surface)
env_desc: No Data
artifact: Sifting of plow zone over c. 100 square meters recovered fish and shellfish remains.  Bone of larger animals largely unidentifiable.  Numerous  ground and flaked stone tools.  Bone tools and (rarely) bone beads.  Projectile points almost entirely Harrell.  Plain gray to black pottery.  One human cranium - unassociated with other cultural material, no evidence of formal burial.
intact: Cultivation affecting site to depth of 0.7 meters
invest: Site appears to be worthy of excavation
disc_desc: The point on which the site is located is ca. 50 feet above the floodplain.  The area examined is on the eastern end of the point.  The area has been in cultivation for more than twenty years.  Surface survey recovered cultural material over an area of approximately 10,00 square meters.  Test pit contained Henrietta Focus material more than 1 meter below the plow zone.  Extensive areas of burned rock and scatters of charcoal.  Local residents have collected artifacts from the site for c. 30 years.  The extent to which the surface distribution is a function of cultivation is uncertain.  No structural remains were identified.

cult_desc: During background research, conflicting information pertaining to the location of site 41DL125 was discovered within the TASA records and the original site form’s site location description.  Although TASA records illustrate the site centroid as being within the north central portion of the project area, the site form acquired from the Texas Archeological Research Laboratory depicted the site as being located south of East Forney Street approximately 0.5 mi west of the intersection of East Kearney Street and SH 352.  Based on this description, topography, and a review of historic aerial imagery, it was determined that the approximate location of the site was in the northwestern portion of the project area.  However, to accommodate the discrepancy, an area encompasses both the TASA database and the original site form description locations was surveyed. Subsequently, 14 shovel tests were excavated were excavated in an attempt to relocate site 41DL125.  However, no surface or subsurface cultural materials were documented during this survey.  Site 41DL125 was not relocated within the proposed project area and the NRHP-eligibility of the site could not formally assessed or evaluated during this effort.  The site is therefore recommended to be of undetermined eligibility for inclusion in the NRHP.  A site revisit form was submitted to the Texas Archeological Research Laboratory reflecting the current survey effort.

basis_size: Previous site boundary, plus positive survey trenches

value: The prehistoric component was first documented on a sandy hill above the Trinity River by Kirkland in the 1940s. The hill and site have since been completely quarried away and there is little to no  prehistoric component remaining. The  historic age component is in a mixed context and appears to be from multiple construction episodes likely relating to Dowdy Ferry Rd  and possible previous commercial real estate in the area. Research value is very low within the current APE.
invest: No further work is recommended within the current APE
disc_desc: Mussel shells; Site 41DL139 was recorded in 1940 by Kirkland as a pre-contact period lithic production site. Kirkland describes the site located ?about 3 miles east of Hutchins at west end of Trinity River bridge?, and his site form indicates that ?micro-lithics, arrowheads, blades, [and] hammerstones? were found over the area, which was ?about 300 x 200 yds on sandy end of hill next to river.? His map also indicates that the site was on top of a small hill that is no longer present at the site due to quarrying activities in the twentieth century. At site 41DL139 in summer 2022, Acacia excavated six shovel tests and three trenches within the previously defined site boundaries. An additional two trenches were excavated just north of Dowdy Ferry Road and extended the site area to the south. Shovel tests were all negative and showed recently disturbed soils with compacted sands and gravels through the entire profile. Three survey trenches were positive for cultural materials, though all these trenches exhibited some degree of recent disturbance in the soil profile. In all site-associated trenches, archeologists excavated column samples to better delineate the extent and distribution of materials. Currently, the site is in a largely open pasture with sporadic small stands of elm, pecan, and juniper trees. Additionally, Acacia archeologists documented artificially cut ridges indicating the edge of prior quarrying activities, as well as small depressions and large slag hills across the APE and site area. These modifications can be seen in the USGS 2018 LiDAR imagery of the area. Acacia?s investigations found only three flakes of the prehistoric component within the APE. Historic period artifacts were found within two trenches at the southern end of the site, just off of Dowdy Ferry Rd. The extremely limited prehistoric materials and the presence of destroyed historic materials can be attributed to more than 80 years of quarrying, construction, and earth moving have erased site integrity within the APE.

disc_desc: Site 41DL140 was documented by Kirkland in 1936 on a small draw or rill on a hill above the artificial lake northeast of the site. Acacia revisited the site in summer 2022 and found no evidence of cultural materials whatsoever within the current APE. The site location was the location of sand and gravel quarrying in the mid-20th century, and  this activity likely obliterated all  cultural deposits. Acacia excavated two mechanical backhoe trenches and seven shovel tests, all of which were negative for cultural materials.

additional:
Site form generated from information provided in the following:
Southern Methodist University Site Survey Form (Connors 1978)
recname: Alexandra Younger, Josh McCormick, Kevin Stone
desc_loc: Off Belt Line Road, on dirt road just south of bridge on Walnut Creek, Site is located off un-named dirt road, approximately 100 m, almost at the edge of present fields. Site is ca 0.45 mi SW of the Walnut Creek/ Belt Line Rd intersection 0.15 miles S of Walnut Creek, 0.8 mile south of Belt Line Rd.
env_desc: South of Walnut Creek, at edge of uplands. Presently in interface between floodplain fields to N, and small residential complex with associated upland terraced fields to S. Site is located on the edge of a small finger like extension into the floodplain.
cult_desc: Scattered house remains measuring 5 by 10 m; a collapsed cattle feeder to the N/NW (Connors 1978).
artifact: Glass container fragments, ceramic fragments (earthenware, semi-porcelain, stoneware), misc. metal, faunal.
disc_desc:
Site consists of a historic, 2 room partially collapsed house (circa 1900). The house was painted originally white, and had a porch that extended the length of the house. The porch is now collapsed. The house is constructed of lapped plank siding, a shingle roof, and raised pilastered foundation. The site has 2 windows in the front, as well as windows at both ends. There was one window in back and a back door. House dimensions approx. 7x3.5 m. Very few associated historic artifacts in association with structure. Some brown earthenware pottery may be contemporary. Presently a collapsed cattle feeder to N/NW  (Connors 1978).
This site is significant in its relationship to the nearby Hintze site (41DL182). Built about three years after the original Hintze home, this residence of other Hintze family members (see Hintze Oral History summary). It is instructive to note some of the construction changes compared to the earlier house, such as a complete change from cut to wire nails, the much simpler floor plan, etc. Completely different trash disposal patterns are evident as well. Sheet trash is evident all about the older house, while neat trash pits characterize the Hintze tenant site. The close age and direct family relationship encumber ethnic pattern detection with respect to trash disposal habits. Further work at the site should involve excavation of the located trash pit, as well as the search for others in the immediate vicinity. Analysis of these artifacts should be done to provide further data for comparison with the Hintze site as well as others in the Lakeview area (Raab et al. 1982).

additional:
Site form generated from information provided in the following:
Southern Methodist University Site Survey Form (Connors 1978)
recname: Kevin Stone, Alexandra Younger, Josh McCormick
desc_loc: .4 mi SSE of the Walnut and Lynn Creek intersection. Access to the site can be obtained from a small ranch complex to the west. A dirt road leads to the site.
soil_desc: Lewisville silty clay, 1 to 3 percent slopes
env_desc: At the edge of the uplands, presently in mesquite and grass cover. The site is located on a small finger of the 550 ft contour south of Walnut Creek, within Dallas County. The site is located at the edge of the uplands, presently adjacent to cultivated fields.
cult_desc: A collapsed four-room, double entry historic house; historic trash. Pump; Stove; heater; contemporary windmill.
artifact: n/a
intact: Very poor. House is almost totally collapsed.
value: Very poor, except as a representative (in terms of time and style) site (Connors 1978).
disc_desc: The site consists of a collapsed 4 room, double entry historic house, with associated historic trash. The house had a porch which ran the length of the front of the house. The house was constructed of shiplap planking, with a wooded shingle roof, and doors with white enamel handles. The house area measures approx. 7x7 m. GLOBE bricks are scattered outside the house to the W, and within the collapsed rooms. The remains of a rusty pump can be seen to the rear of the house, and it is topped by a contemporary windmill. (The house faces West.) In addition, the rusted remains of an old stove (or possibly gas heater) can be seen to the rear of the house, along with associated historic trash; twist top jars, and a rusted cistern/bucket. The remains of a rusted wagon, with metal spoked wheels can be seen to the W/NW of the house; and historic trash is eroding into the stream channels that bisect the ridge. It should be noted that the house did have electricity at its demise; however that may have been incorporated after construction was finished, or at a later date. The house is presently shut off by a barbed wire fence in the front of the house. There is a contemporary building (with metal siding) to the east of the house site. There is considerable historic trash scattered around the area surrounding the house. No specific date could be ascertained for the house; however the double entry may be indicative of a temporal affiliation. (The house was not raised off the ground.) (Connors 1978).
