Raab, L. Mark, Allan J. McIntyre, James Bruseth, Daniel E. McGregor, C. Reid Ferring, and Nancy Reese (1982) Archaeological Investigations at Lakeview Lake: 1979 and 1980
recname: Kevin Stone, Alexandra Younger, Josh McCormick
test_meth: Eight (8) 1 x 1  m excavation units and Two (2) backhoe trenches
desc_loc: Located in Joe Pool Lake approximately 0.25 miles northwest of the intersection of Sanctuary Drive and Preserve Boulevard
env_desc: small floodplain gravel knoll at the base of a series of upland ridges and rolling hills overlooking a floodplain.
time_desc: Seven (n=7) temporally diagnostic projectile points ( Edgewood, Ensor, Yarbrough, Wells)
basis: diagnostic artifacts from multiple prehistoric periods recovered
cult_desc: Two definite features with a possible third. Feature 1 was shown to be a naturally-occurring cluster of sandstone rocks. Feature 2 was a possible posthole located in Unit 1. Feature was defined by an accumulation of charcoal flecks and a dark soil stain. Feature 3 was a mussel shell concentration with a few flecks of charcoal and some possibly burned rock (Raab et al. 1982).
site_size: 60 m (190 ft; N/S) and 20 m (66 ft; E/W), 0.30 ac
basis_size: extent of surface artifacts and positive test units
basis_top: artifacts recovered at depths of 0-80 cmbs in test units
basis_thk: no artifacts recovered below 80 cmbs in test units
artifact: lithic debitage, faunal, projectile points, groundstone
circum: Dense vegetation across portions of the site
intact: Most of site has been impacted by agriculture. Western portion of site has been eroded away by Mountain Creek. Site is moderately intact.
value: significant according to Criterion 4 of 36 CFR 800.10 (Raab et al. 1982, 96)
invest: Any future work at this site should attempt to evaluate Hypotheses 1 and 2. Also, to the extent that faunal and floral remains can be recovered from this site. Hypothesis 3 and 4 should be evaluated if possible (Raab et al. 1982, 102).
disc_desc: Site 41DL199 is a single component site comprising a span from Late Archaic to the  Early Neo-American Stages . It includes a dense lithic scatter and a few features (Raab et al. 1982).

desc_loc: From the intersection of Mason Road and Lavender Road, travel S along Lavender Road for approximately 0.85 mi.  The site is located direct SW of the roadway.; Residences and outbuildings are located on the southern end of the knoll.  The county road crosses it.
water: Tenmile Creek, 144 ft, SW; Tributary to Ten Mile Creek; W; 25 m; 415 ft
ownerinfo: Private, with utility easement overseen by TRA
soil_desc: Lewisville and Suvev Soil Complexes; Tan silty calcareous clay loams overlying thin lay
surf_tex: Silty, calcareous, clay, tan loam oerlying a layer of small limestone gravels reportedly overlying "soapstone"?; silty clay and clay loam
env_desc: Low but prominant knoll (actually an extention of the toe of the N valley wall) in the floodplain of Ten Mile Creek; summit of the terrace landform bordering the Tenmile Creek Floodplain
time_desc: Late prehistoric/lithic/ceramic; Only prehistoric materials observed; previous site recordation
basis: Only prehistoric materials observed; previous site recordation
artifact: Lithic artifacts consisted of debitage (n=4), FCR (n=6), and an expended amorphous core.  The expended core (4 by 5 cm), was manufactured from metaquartzite.  Chipped lithic debitage raw materials included gray chert (n=1) and Ogallala quartzite (n=3).  FCR (n=6) equally comprised both quartzite (n=3) and limestone (n= 3).
landuse: Domestic, agricultural; Most is cultivated; pasture grasses on northeastern portion; weeds and scrub vegetation on borrow pit (western 1/3).; Floodplain pastureland; riparian zone along Ten Mile Creek and the tributary, pastureland on valley wall to the N and NE.; None (evidence of degos, deer, rodents).
invest: Avoid with project, encourage protection by landowner(s); True; No further investigations warranted
disc_desc: Site 41DL229 likely represents a logistical or foraging camp occupied for an undetermined interval of time during the prehistoric period.  However, during the original recording of 41DL229, Fox suggested that the site dates to the Late Prehistoric (1982).  The general paucity of artifacts recovered at the site may indicate that the location was used for a short duration or for limited activities.  The site suggests a general trend of chipped stone tool maintenance and short-term inhabitation.  The location of the site near the summit of the terrace landform has restricted the archeological deposits to the shallow subsurface, as little sedimentation is likely to have occurred at that elevation during the Holocene.  In addition, the landform has been subject to agriculture since at least the early 20th century, and possibly since the mid-to-late 19th century.  Since the site is restricted to the shallow subsurface, the vertical extent of the site has almost certainly been completely disturbed.

additional: Summary description from THE RECORD, Vol. 34, No. 1 (1978) provided from TARL archives
test_meth: 11 - 30-x-30 cm shovel tests, dug in 20 cm arbitrary levels
records: computer disks, field catalog, print log, prints, shovel test records, slides, slide logs, slide logs
desc_loc: The site is located along the western edge of a large gravel pit that covers roughly 60 acres.  Cultural materials were also found in a small baulk between two segments of the gravel pit.  The site is approximately 950 m NNE of where Valley View Road crosses the Elm Fork, 1.65 km south from where Grapevine Creek enters the Elm Fork, and 1.1 km WSW from where Cooks Branch crosses Crosby Road (now designated Luna Road).
water: The Elm Fork is about 40 m west
drainage: Elm Fork of the Trinity River
soil_desc: Arents, loamy, hilly, and Trinity clay, frequently flooded
env_desc: The site is found on the western edge of a large gravel pit.  The cultural materials appeared to correspond with small rises (ca. 1-2 m tall) at the edge of the gravel pit.  These rises may represent the edges of the terrace deposits shown near the site area on the 1924 soils map. The site is covered with a mature hardwood forest.  The area formerly had a dense understory, but this has recently been grubbed off by the landowner, who is seeking to sell the property.  A small slough was found just west of the site, perhaps representing a filled in channel of the Elm Fork.
artifact: Small quantities of artifacts, including flakes, shatter, a biface fragment, and FCR were found on the ground surfaces exposed by bulldozing.  The surface scatter can be subdivided into low density and very low density area, with the very low density areas found in the northern part of the site that corresponds to the more heavily bulldozed part of the site, with the artifact being closely associated with the dozer windrows.  It is unclear whether this very of material represents the initial artifact density, removal of the cultural deposits, or the moving of artifacts by the dozer.  Shovel testing was conducted in the part of the site that is within our impact area and in the area shown by the surface scatter.  Shovel testing proved an inadequate method for delineating the site, presumably due to the low artifact density observed.  For example, several artifacts (including mussel shell fragments) were observed on the surface near ST-6, but the unit proved to be sterile.
intact: Poor; most of the site appears to be removed by gravel mining
artificial: Gravel mining, grubbing to remove undergrowth
future: Extension of existing borrow pit for SH-190
value: Given the low to very low density of material observed and the probability that the site center is already removed, 41DL240 appears have little remaining research potential.  It is considered to be ineligible for inclusion in the NRHP.
disc_desc:
Site 41DL240 was originally recorded by Paul Lorraine of the Dallas Archeological Society (DAS).  DAS apparently excavated test units at the site (Paul Lorraine, personal communication) but the results of these investigations are currently unknown. The site was relocated with the help of Paul Lorraine.  The recent grubbing operations proved a mixed blessing.  The ground surface visibility allowed the site to be easily relocated, but it has added the disturbances at the site.  Given the results of shovel testing within the site area, it would have been difficult to relocate the site without the ground exposure.

The site can be divided into two areas:  the portion north of the gully/drainage that is within our impact area and the area south of the gully/drainage which is just outside the impact area.  Our efforts (especially shovel testing) were concentrated on the impact area, with only surface inspection and mapping occuring outside the impact area.  No diagnostics were observed at the site and the only tool was a biface fragment from the south edge.

The site appears to have been located on terrace deposits that have since been borrowed away by gravel mining.  However, it should be noted that the 1924 soil map of Dallas County does not show the terrace deposits this close to the Elm Fork.  Given the extensive deposits observed, the site may have been a large campsite or village.
attachmem:
1.     Plan map of site
2.     Copy of topo map showing site location

mapname: No Data; Carrollton, Texas 7.5 USGS dated 1959.
desc_loc: The site is located about 0.95 miles due E of the North Lake Reservoir dam in NW Dallas County. THe site lies about 250 m N of Ledbetter Road and will be bisected by the proposed northward extension of MacArthur Blvd. THe site is situated on the valley margin of the Elm Fork of the Trinity RIver which is located about 1.1 miles E of the site. An abandoned dairy is situated immediately W of the site.
ownerinfo: Valley Ranch Development and Triland/ Northsted Joint Venture, One Lincoln Centre, Suite 1000, 5400  >> cont .
visible: Good due to machine scraping of right of way for proposed street.
env_desc: The site is located about 1.1 miles W of the right bank of the Elm Fork channel on the border between the river floodplain and the Eagle Ford Prairie uplands. Grapevine Creek lies about 420 m N of the site but a dried up spring located on the W edge of the site was probably the nearest water source in prehistoric times.
basis: 4 Late Archaic dart points found at site
artifact: Chert and quartzite tools and debitage, mussel and snail shell fragments, burned rocks, a few deer sized bones, 1 ground stone fragment (sandstone). 5 projectile points are 1 Elam point, 1 Ellis point, 1 Gary, 1 possible Edgewood, 1 undetermined dart point fragment. All 4 indentifiable dart points appear to be Late Archaic types. All 5 projectile points are made of Ogallala quartzite.
circum: Ground surface visibility was good due to construction activities
landuse: Prairie grasses and weeds; mesquite, pecan and cedar elm trees
artificial: Construction of dairy silo pits and barns. Machine blading of top 10 cm of terrace for proposed construction of MacArthur Blvd.
future: More extensive damage will occur when MacArthur Blvd. is constructed.
invest: Relocation of MacArthur Blvd. eastward outside site perimeter. If this is not possible, the site should be monitored during construction activities. The site should also be test excavated in order to determine National Register eligibility.

additional: Article in the Dallas Morning News and Dallas Times Herald, old Dallas City Directories, 1920-1958.
materials: Artifacts used in manufacture of pottery.  Examples of pottery made here.
desc_loc:
This site is located on the southeastern corner of Davis St. (US Hwy 80) and Ravina St. in the Oak Cliff section of Dallas.
2930 W. Davis St.
ownerinfo:
Mr. Glynn Mitchell
2930 W. Davis St., Dallas, TX 75211
informinfo: Not recorded as a state site
env_desc: Site is in populated area on a large city street.
cult_desc:
1 large L-shaped frame building (2 stories on short end of L).
2 pottery kilns - small round, downdraft types.
basis_thk: This is a late site and has been kept clean - the main depth would be excavation made for kiln bases.
artifact:
Most artifacts used in the manufacture of pottery, such as kilns, jigger wheels, molds, even examples of the wares remain on the site.  These are supposed to be transferred to the pottery at Old City Park restoration, Dallas.
The present owner has conscientiously preserved all o these artifacts and wishes to donate them all to Old City Park.
landuse: City - environment - Bermuda grass, hackberry, chinaberry and pecan trees.
artificial: Addition of more sheds for modern pottery making.
future: To be cleared for expansion of Davis St. (US Hwy 80).  The buildings have been condemned and are to be torn down.  All present artifacts inside as ell as the kilns are to be moved to Old City Park, Dallas.
invest: All of the clay used at this pottery was brought by R.R. from Arthur or Texarkana.  The grounds are therefore relatively unimportant, but the equipment of the pottery still preseved within the  huilding is of a vanishing type.  Although in use in the twentieth century, it represents the types used in many late 19th-century establishments - I should like to see the artifacts preserved because of their historical importance, but the site is not particularly important if the artifacts are kept.

projname: Trinity River Overview for Regional Environmental Impact Statement
test_meth: Diagnostics were the only artifacts that would be collected if found.
mapname: No Data; Hutchins, Tex. 7.5 minute USGS dated 1958 (photorevised 1968 and 1973)
desc_loc: The site is located in the southeast part of the City of Dallas and lies within the bundaries of the Lincoln Memporial Park Cemetery.  The siite was originally exposed in the south wall of a gravel pit situated at the head of a gully at the W end of the cemetery.  The Trinity River channel is located about 400 meters W of the site and Murdock Rd. is about 375 meters E of the site.  The intersection  of Murdock and Rylie roads is about 0.35 air miles SE of the site.
soil_desc: Silawa fine sandy loam from original ground surface down 30 cm.;  >> cont .
env_desc: The site is located on a terrace on the left bank of the Trinity River.  The current river channel is about 400 meters W of the site.  The site is much closer to the shallow side tributary of the river.  Excavation of a gravel pit and land contouring for usage of the surrounding area as a cemetery has altered the creek.  The site lies on the left bank or north side of the creek.  The native vegetation has likewise been heavily altered.
time_desc: Late Archaic Elam Focus.  According to W.W. Crook Jr. only the latter half of the Elam Focus was represented.
basis: Crook's analysis of materials he collected.
site_size: Artifacts were originally seen only in the wall of the gravel pit.
artifact: None seen
circum: Currently, the original gravel pit wall is covered by  >> cont .
landuse: Various grasses and weeds are thick on the clopes of the old gravel pit walls.  Some cottonwood trees are present bottom of the gravel pit.
artificial: Excavation of gravel pit and resulting erosion of walls of pit.  Excavation of gravels for modern cemetery may be damaging intact deposits.
invest: The fill covering the S wall of the pit needs to be removed to expose the old wall in order to verify the presence of any remaining intact deposits.  If materials can be locaterd in the gravel pit wall shovel tests and 1 by 1 m. test pits should be excavated to determine the site limits.  This will be awkward because of the current usage of the surrounding area as a cemetery.

sitename: No Data; Gary L. Burton Site; Update
recname: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Fort Worth, Texas SWFOD-0  76102
test_meth: Random; Select, with an emphasis on diagnostics and representatives of site activities
exca_meth: Enormous subsurface exposures from channeling through deposits

permhouse: 612 Phillips Dr. Coppell, Texas  75019; USACE, Fort Worth, Texas  76102-SWFOD-0
mapname: Grapevine; Grapevine 1981 revisited; Grapevine, TX 7.5 minute
desc_loc: Heading W on Highway 121 past the bridge that crosses Denton Creek to dirt road located 0.65 miles from bridge. Take dirt road 1 mile N to gravel pit. Site is on cut bank on S side of creek. Located along the entire W bank.; The site is located adjacent to the Tarrant County line in Dallas County. It is approximately 0.3 km S of the Denton, Tarrant, Dallas County boundary. Access to the site is travelling NE from the intersection of Highway 360 and SH 121, on SH 121, about 3 km. The site is exposed in an overflow channel adjacent to Denton Creek (SE side), WNW of SH 121. Current development of the area may soon restrict access. See enclosed 7.5 minute copy for location detail.
water: 150 yards W; Denton Creek, 20 m WNW; Elm Fork, Trinity River
drain_name: Elm Fork of Trinity River; Riverine
soil_desc: Clay and silty clay; Trinity-Frio sand
visible: 100 percent in channel cut; Overgrown with vegetation- 50 percent
env_desc: 25 percent slope- at top of bank you can see Highway 121 to the SE, a cement plant to the W. To the N is a cut into the S bank of Denton Creek to allow drainage for flood control  [      ].; DL 270 is sandwhiched between Denton Creek and high gravel knolls. It appears to be a prime ecotone offering easy access to bottom land, riverine, slope, and upland resources,. Sedimants containing the site are the W Fork paleosol (Yates and Ferring 1986), an easily recognizable, well developed soil usually containing Late Prehistoric to Late Archaic cultural materials. The terrace under DL270 may be a stable T-2 with possible extensive depth of cultural debris. A assesment of the culturla resources in the Trinity River Basin of Dallas, Tarant, and Denton Counties- report on file SWFOD-O/COE.
time_desc: Late Archaic-Late Prehistoric  -- possible older depths; Multiple, Late Archaic W fork paleosol reportd in earlier report
basis: Artifacts and features; Hearths appear at different levels in cut bank.
cult_desc: Numerous burned rock hearths, mussel shell clusters, discrete butchering (bone boiling) areas, at least 12 hearths were exposed in the channel cuts. Clusters of bone, FCR, and mussel shell were (generally) in the upper 1.5 to 2.0 m of the deposits. Erosion (slopes were cut at 30 degree) had altered some contexts, especially the bone and thre artifacts collected.; Shallow, saucer shpaed hearths uncovered. Charcoal fragments in one hearth. Scattered, burned rock suggests there were numerous hearths. Hearths uncovered were approximately 32 inches in diameter. Some evidence of burned clay. Simialr to site 41DL252, 295, 296, 297, 299. Culturla layer is approximately six feet - 1.83 m below the present surface with indications it was 9 feet below original surface 2.75 m.
site_size: 500 m SW/NE by 100 m NW/SE; Extensive visibility; Actual measurement of area, some estimated due to water in overflow channel
basis_thk: Depth of exposure in channel walls; Observation
artifact: Gary point, 3 unidentified Late Archaic looking points manos, and numerous flakes and chips material is scattered across entire site with concentrations in some areas. Biface fragmetns similar to those found at other sites in the area.; One Gary dart point, one broken arrow point blank, one pecked stone, bird bone, lots of deer bone, bison bone, bison mandible (left over 8 years of age). One discreet component is apparently a bone boiling location with numerous impact fractured and burned fragments of bone. It erosion is not responsible, the Gary point was 2 m deep and the arrow point plan 1 m deep. One pecked, shaped and ground stone was collected. One bone, possibly a human radius, was also recovered. The site was once very extensive and intact.  Approximately 1/2 has been removed by channel excavation. Ultimate disposition and protection of the site does not appear to be predictable in light of private ownership lacking any Federal protection.
landuse: Mixed grasses and weeds, hickory, elm, black walnut, pecan, burr oak and cottonwood. Trees on the edge of creek bank.; Pecan, hackberry, and elm along Denton Creek, mesquite grasslands on slopes (buffalo grass, blue stem, bermuda)
natural: Cut bank is eroding badly. Much material has been washed away.; Erosion and drying cracks are currently damaging surface and shallow contexts.
artificial: Construction, gravel pits, fish hatcheried in past.
future: Development; Possibility of effects from construction of Highway 121
invest: Current action depends on landowner. Preservation of the remaining site area should be the primary action. Mapping, if permissible would help. Potential testing/ excavation should not be ruled out.; Excavation of site before all material lost to collectors and erosion. Original report shows 50 percent of site intact. This will not remin true when construction associated with major highway occurs.

materials: Litjic debris, core fragment, retouched flakes. White chert, Tan chert, reddish quartz
desc_loc: Approx. 3 mi. w. ofI-35 E onBeltline rd, 1/4 mi. w. of Dallas ave.(hwy 342), site is directly w. of Deep Branch extending at least 30 - 50m into flood plain. SITE BEGINS AT BASE OF SLOPE 1/4 MI. S. of Belt Line rd.
visible: Moderate-poor, area was planted with corn
env_desc: Site begins at base of slope and extends 30-35m w. of Deep Branch in floodplain n. of Ten Mile Creek. Approx. midway(n-s) of site on eastern edge is sewer hole cover.
artifact: Varied lithic debris including flakes, chips,retouched pieces, cores and core fragments- White, Tan ,and Grey chert, grey and reddish quartzite.
circum: Area in corn field; part covered in thick brush
natural: Limited erosion, some washing due to gentle gradient of land; perhaps some flooding from Deep Branch close to drainage.
artificial: Has been plowed in modern times(currently planted in corn) Uncertain about s. portion; may have had some movement from early golf course construction.
future: At least n. portion of site lies w/in boudaries of a proposed municipal golf course.
invest:
Recommended land be cleared, mapped, and griddled for surface collection. This, combined with further testing could truly determine the depth, extent, distribution, and nature of preservation. At this point the site seems to extend for a great, but unknown distance. Very few sites have been documented as sites for further research in this area.
  The site may serve possibly to test hypotheses about the nature of secondary drainages in the UpperTrinity River region. Ten Mile cuold serve as a test vs. sites worked on at Mountain Creek and Walnut Creek to the West(Joe Pool Lake)

projname: John F. Kennedy Exhibit, Dallas County Administration Building
projfund: Dallas County; Nyfeler and Callaway; Dallas Historical Foundation
additional:
Site form generated from information provided in the following:
Jurney, David H., et al. (1994) Archaeological Investigations at 41DL279: Site of the John F. Kennedy Exhibit, Dallas County Administration Building, Dallas, Texas. Archaeology Research Program, Mercyhurst Archaeological Institute.
surf_tech: identification of cultural features exposed on the mechanically scraped ca. 1882 surface
map_meth: hand drawn maps, transcribed digitally through Adobe Illustrator and AutoCAD for the project report
test_meth: geotechnical coring; mechanical stripping of the upper ca. 1.5m; hand excavation of 13 0.5x0.5m, seven 1.0x0.5m, and one 1.0x1.0m units
exca_meth: hand excavation of 262 units, units were of varying sizes and configuration, predominate unit size was 0.5x0.5m (n=215); bucket augers
materials: faunal remains; ironstone/whiteware; stoneware; porcelain; bottle glass; table/lamp glass; machine-cut nails; wire nails; window glass; handmade brick; buttons; shoe parts; ferrous metal; slag; asphalt; miscellaneous; other personal items; kitchen items; horse/stable items; debitage; tested, bipolar, and bifacial cores; modified flakes; preforms; refined bifaces; projectile points
time_occ: Prehistoric; Early Statehood (1845-1860); Civil War; Late Statehood (1865-1900); Modern (1901-present);
desc_loc: The site is located in the Central Business District of Dallas, Texas, southwest of the intersection of Houston Street and Pacific Avenue at the Dallas County Administration Building (411 Elm Street, Dallas, TX 75202).
soil_desc: Silstid-Urban land complex, 0 to 6 percent slopes
env_desc: The site is located on the Western Point Bar of the Union Terminal Terrace adjacent to the historic floodplain of the Trinity River. Since the beginning of the Historic period, the presettlement ecosystems and plant communities within and around the site have been altered by numerous human activities. At the time of excavation, no vegetation was present within the site due to development. The site is located directly adjacent to the former Texas School Book Depository Building (Historical Marker Number 6895).
time_desc: archival research; informant reports; landowner interviews; artifacts
basis: GLO land patent; Dallas County Deed records; Dallas City Directory census data; Brosius bird's eye map of Dallas; Dallas Public Works Department files; Dallas City Council minutes; Sanborn Fire Insurance maps
cult_desc: Several features associated with three dwellings were identified as foundation piers, a well, post molds, boundary ditches, foundations and chimneys, an unlined cellar, posts, an ash deposit, fence posts, plow scars, an artifact concentration, and a privy. Features related to post-occupational use or penetrations of the sealed historic deposits include an unlined privy pit, post holes, pier footing, a railroad grade, an oily stain, and a privy and associated post. One prehistoric , Archaic period feature was documented.
site_size: 16 m (52 ft; N/S) by 25 m (82 ft; E/W)
basis_size: extent of impact zone for the project
basis_top: mechanical stripping of the asphalt surface and fill; exposed historic deposits
basis_thk: extent of historic and prehistoric deposits
artifact: faunal remains; ironstone/whiteware; stoneware; porcelain; bottle glass; table/lamp glass; machine-cut nails; wire nails; window glass; handmade brick; buttons; shoe parts; ferrous metal; slag; asphalt; miscellaneous; other personal items; kitchen items; horse/stable items; debitage; tested, bipolar, and bifacial cores; modified flakes; preforms; refined bifaces; projectile points
value: These archeological investigations at 41DL279, which are the first to be conducted within the Central Business District of Dallas, Texas, indicate that significant historic and prehistoric archaeological deposits are preserved under urban fills in portions of the city (Jurney et al. 1994).
invest: no further investigations are recommended (Jurney et al. 1994)
disc_desc:
The John F. Kennedy Sixth Floor Exhibit Building occupies a large part of the northeastern quarter and a small part of the northwestern quarter of Block 10/13, Dallas Texas. It is located on a low sandy landform which is a point bar deposit of the Trinity River and part of the alluvial fill of the Union Terminal Terrace. The project area is located in the present-day Central Business District of Dallas. It was part of the original Dallas townsite sold by John Neely Bryan in the late 1840s and early 1850s.
The Dallas County Historical Foundation (DCHF) proposed the construction of the exhibit building as an addition to the School Book Depository Building (i.e., Dallas county Administration Building [DCAB]) from which United States President John F. Kennedy is alleged to have been assassinated by Lee Harvey Oswald in November 1963. The DCHF apprised the Dallas Landmark Commission of this proposal, as the DCAB was listed as a contributing element to the West End National Historic District. The Texas Antiquities Committee determined that investigations were necessary prior to planned construction in accordance with State regulations.
The late 1840s/early 1850s to 1880s landscape of Block 10/13 was rapidly buried ca. 1882, when the first railroad spur was emplaced across the block. Standing dwellings, fences, and support outbuildings were razed, clipping fenceposts and foundations at the ground surface. A well investigated during the course of the present archaeological project was deliberately filled at that time. A stoneworks operating in this area during the 1890s produced sediments and debris which contributed to the burial of the earlier occupied landscape. The entire block was covered in 1901, when the Southern Rock Island Plow Building burned and the present School Book depository or DCAB was constructed. Rail yard fill was placed above the extensive stoneworks sediments, and this surface was paved in the 1920s.
The first phase of the 41DL279 archaeological project involved cutting the "footprint" of the John F. Kennedy Exhibit Building into the asphalt covering Block 10/13. At this time, the fill from the rail yard and most of that relating to the 1890s stoneworks was removed, exposing the ca. 1882 land surface. Test excavation, the second phase of archaeological work at the site, indicated that significant historic and prehistoric material cultural deposits and cultural features were buried intact below these fills. A third mitigation or data-recovery phase of investigations was recommended, and commenced immediately after testing.
All phases of work at the site were conducted from late December 1987 to February 1988 and involved excavation of a total area of 90.13 square meters (969.8 square feet). Twenty depositional units or archaeological Strata were identified, and a total of 32 cultural features were identified and examined. In total, 15,697 artifacts were recovered, excluding faunal material (Jurney et al. 1994).

disc_desc:
Site 41DL284 was recorded in 1989 as the remains of a historic farmstead, that consisted of only a surficial scatter of sparse historic artifacts and a filled-in brick-lined well (Skinner 1989: 9). Oral history work conducted during the original recording demonstrated that the house was built in 1952 and replaced an older house (Skinner 1989: 10). Historic aerials show the house from 1952 through 1979. The house was no longer present in 1989 as observed during the original survey and shown on the aerial. The park facilities are built in the location of the former home and consist of a playground, gazebo with picnic tables, and a small basketball court.

All 10 shovel tests excavated at the presumed site core were negative and contained a higher mixture of construction gravels than the other 10. Shovel tests were purposefully pre-plotted around the house structure shown on the 1968 aerial while avoiding modern features. ST1 was placed close the south side of the structure and then ST2-10 were all placed radially from ST1 in 15 m intervals. All were negative and contained construction fill.

disc_desc: The site's boundary encompasses a residential and recreational development that was constructed around the late-2000s. An artificial pond feature, homes and terraformed park grounds now occupy the entire site area. The surveyed/revisited area consisted of a section of the APE that overlaps with the easternmost portion of the site. Pedestrian reconnaissance and shovel testing in this area of the site and along the southern edge of the pond adjacent to the site revealed no cultural materials and a low potential for intact deposits elsewhere within the site.  Given the now-destroyed condition of the site and lack of archeological materials, the portion of site 41DL297 that was revisited for the current project is recommended ineligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places and State Antiquities Landmark designation. In addition, the remainder of the site's original mapped boundary lacks integrity warranting eligibility consideration given the residential, park, and pond developments that occurred following the original site documentation in 1988. In all, no further work is recommended at the site given its poor integrity and low research value.

desc_loc: 0.25 mi. E of Denton tap Rd. on S bank of flood control ditch on N side of Denton Creek.  Measured 90 feet (27.5 m.) N of Denton Creek, 9.5 feet (3 m.) below present surface.  Accesss control can be viewed on opposite bank to the W and N.  1.75 mi. W of 41DL295.
visible: Now overgrown because of controlled seeding.  At time of survey was bare.
env_desc: Denton Tap Rd. is visible  downstream of bridge crossing the creek.  Full view of flood control ditch to the E.  Slope of cutbank measured.  It is determined to be about 1 to 3.  Located on S edge of Visyta Ridge development.  Now zoned for light indiustrial and commercial general business.  Not developed at this time.
time_desc: Single component, no diagnostics.  Cmpared to other sites in the area at this depth we believe it is Late Archaic.
basis: This was the only strata of cultural material observed in the cut bank.
cult_desc: Burned rock hearths.  T3wo hearths about 0.5 meters in diameter surrounded by mussel shell; a grinding stone was close by.  Both hearths were in the same strata about 11.25 meters apart.  Unable to correlate to 41DL295 based upon stratigraphic level.  Current surface level is 3 meters above hearth location.
artifact: Grinding stone near hearths.  Flake anbd chip concentration about 19 m. E of hearth 1; shell concentrations W of hearth 2.
landuse: Mixed grass, oak, hickory, elm, bois d'arc, cottonwood, walnut, briars.
natural: Possible future erosion if lengthy drought destroys grass cover.
invest: We usually survey and observe all known sites on a regular basis.  If any of our sites is in danger we will notify THC, the Corps, or whoever may be in authority for the project.

additional: Ron Emrich, Dallas Landmark Commission 214/670-4121; Dr. Mamie Mcknight, Black Dallas Remembered, Dallas, Tx
exca_meth: Graves will be disinterred archaeologically and einterred in a protected area within the same cemetery.
permhouse: SDHPT; Museum of African-American Life and Culture, Dallas, Tx.
desc_loc: The historic cemetery is presently known as Freedmen's Park, a city park on the SW corner of the intersecitonof Lemmon Ave and N Central Expressway in Dallas, Tx
ownerinfo: Dallas Park Board, Dallas, Tx; State Dept. of Hwys and Public Transportation, 11th and Brazos Streets;  >> cont .
visible: Entire park is covered by urban fill.
env_desc: The site was originally a slave and freedslave burial ground dating from pre-1861 to 1920, situated in a rural Dallas nineteenth and twentieth century economy.  In the 1920's and again in 1965 it was modified into a public park and all evidence of the grave locaitons was destroyed.  today the cemetery exists as a public park in an urban setting, on the SW corenr of Lemmon Ave and Central Expressway in Dallas, Tx
time_desc: Mid to late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries
cult_desc: Over 1,000 burials have been identified in rows aligned N to S with individual graves oriented E to W.  Human remains-both adults and children-are contained in fragmentary caskets, with additional grave offerings placed within and atop the caskets.
artifact: Casket hardware, jewelry, glass, ceramics, metal (jewelry box, pocket watch, diaper pins), sea shell.
circum: Cemetery is defined on city maps and boundaries  >> cont .
landuse: currently an urban park planted in Bermuda grass amid a stand of post oak trees.
artificial: City streets, office buildings, residences, other cemeteries, and a public park have encroached upon Freedmen's Cemetery from all sides until its original 4 acres have been reduced to 1.22 acres.  The original surface has been enti4rely obliterated.
future: Roadway construciton along Lemmon Ave and S bound frontage road of Central Expressway.
invest: SDHPT is coordinating with the Dallas Park Board, the Dallas Landmark Commission, Black Dallas Remembered, living descendants of the interred, the federal govenment, and other interested parties to arrive at a reburial plan that will be inoffensive to all.  We plan to disinter by hand, perform minimal skeletal analysis, retain a representative sample of artifacts, and reinter in modern caskets within the boundary of the same cemetery.  Ca. 600 graves are expected to be moved in this manner.
ce: NRHP does not normally register cemeteries.

invest: This site should be tested to determine both the size and the possibility of intact features.  For a variety of reasons, this site could be destroyed in the near future.

disc_desc:
The newly discovered historic component of site 41DL396 consists of a low-density surface and subsurface scatter of mid-20th century Historic-era artifacts observed in the southwestern portion of John Paul Jones Park.  No trace of the Prehistoric component reported in 1991 for this area was found in this investigation.  This site is comprised of a surface and a subsurface expression.  Because of limited visibility due to thick turf covering the grounds of John Paul Jones Park there were observed relatively few cultural objects on the ground surface.  The Historic-era component of site 41DL396 runs to the northwest edge of Zion Road.  With five of the site's eight positive shovel tests situated within four to eight meters from the road.  These units are situated along the highest elevated land area in the area of this site.  It was along this trajectory that two mobile homes appear on a topographic map and aerial image from 1968 oriented parallel with Zion Road.

A total of 73 cultural objects were collected from the site (Appendix A: Table 2; Appendix B: Photographs 26 û 32).  Objects recovered that may relate to the mid-20th century context of the two mobile homes consist of one piece of whiteware, colorless glass, concrete, asphalt shingles, metal wire, one wire nail, and animal bone.  Among the collection are numerous pieces of asphalt likely relating to the construction and/or repair/degradation of Zion Road.  Several pieces of modern trash likely from park visitors were also recovered including a tie-wrap, Styrofoam, a plastic easting utensil fragment, and an aluminum foil food wrapper.  Amber glass was commonly used in historic times; however, judging from the shape, thickness, and lack of patina, the amber glass shards found at the site are likely shards from modern beers bottles.  Three fragments of charcoal, one shard of amber glass, and one piece of asphalt were recovered from highly disturbed fill encountered in shovel test S6 excavated along the paved entryway to the park parking lot.  Due to the disturbance and lack of any unequivocally cultural objects greater than 50 years of age, this shovel test was not considered positive.

The most potentially problematic cultural objects found in two of these six shovel tests were a single bone fragment in shovel tests S3 and 9 bone fragments in shovel test M38.  Regarding the latter, most of the breaks reflect 'new breaks' fractured during the excavation of this unit.  Since the Prehistoric component featured three human burials, it was necessary to have these bone fragments professionally evaluated.  Accordingly, they were personally brought to the Center for Archaeological Studies (CAS) at Texas State University, San Marcos.  On April 21, Jodi Jacobson, Ph.D. assessed the small bone fragment from ST S3 as '...the distal posterior segment of a medium-large sized artiodactyl humerus.  Most specifically the radial fossa tends to form a somewhat inverse Y at the base of the diaphysis and it was completely consistent with that portion.  Given size it compared well with both deer and pig, but was not discernable between the two.'  The multiple bone fragments from shovel test M38 were evaluated as '...all large mammal bone, most likely cow for most though there were a couple of bones that may have been in pig range.'

None of the Historic-era component of site 41DL396 is found intact.  With such poor integrity, this site holds limited research value.  The absence of any Prehistoric or Historic-era artifacts earlier than middle 20th century further reduces the potential for productive research.  This site presents almost no research value with respect to Historic-era cultural and historical studies.  Therefore, the portion of site 41DL396 that was surveyed within the project boundaries is recommended as not eligible for inclusion in the NRHP or for listing as a SAL.  The uninvestigated areas of site 41DL396 located that may be found outside of the project area, as found to the immediate southeast of the site under and across Zion Road and, to the north, into land area inundated by Lake Ray Hubbard, remain unevaluated.
attachmem: Shapefiles and site map.; ection of 7.5' USGS Mesquite quad showingte locationketch of burial (artist's rendition)ketch map
Concat_site_variables:
No Data; burial site; occupation. No Data; CH5DA; Site 1. 3/13/2024 and 3/19/2024; August 13 1991. 3/13/2024 and 3/19/2024; 8/13/1991. Amber/colorless glass, asphalt road fragments, modern tie-wrap, whiteware, asphalt shingles, concrete, modern Styrofoam, modern plastic wrapper, animal bones, metal wire, charcoal fragment, wire nail, modern plastic fragment, and rubber fragment.; True. In John Paul Jones park (City of Garland), off Zion Road, north of IH 30. It is on the edge of Lake Ray Hubbard.; Site is in John Paul Jones Park on the bank of Lake Ray Hubbard in Garland, Texas.. Altoga silty clay, 5 to 12 percent slopes, eroded. Rowlett road bridge over Lake Ray Hubbard can be seen to the WNW. A small tree-lined drainage is 50 m SW of the site. Vegetation includes grass and young trees.; The site is situated on a toe slope descending into Lake Ray Hubbard.  Vegetation consists of short, manicured grasses and scattered hardwood trees.. Topographic and aerial maps. Burial (bones eroding from lake edge); Three skeletons, heads to the north, facing east. Apparently were on back or on left side. Tightly flexed.; No historic cultural features.  A parking lot and walking trail cross through the site.. The newly discovered historic component of site 41DL396 consists of a low-density surface and subsurface scatter of mid-20th century Historic-era artifacts observed in the southwestern portion of John Paul Jones Park.  No trace of the Prehistoric component reported in 1991 for this area was found in this investigation.  This site is comprised of a surface and a subsurface expression.  Because of limited visibility due to thick turf covering the grounds of John Paul Jones Park there were observed relatively few cultural objects on the ground surface.  The Historic-era component of site 41DL396 runs to the northwest edge of Zion Road.  With five of the site's eight positive shovel tests situated within four to eight meters from the road.  These units are situated along the highest elevated land area in the area of this site.  It was along this trajectory that two mobile homes appear on a topographic map and aerial image from 1968 oriented parallel with Zion Road.

A total of 73 cultural objects were collected from the site (Appendix A: Table 2; Appendix B: Photographs 26 û 32).  Objects recovered that may relate to the mid-20th century context of the two mobile homes consist of one piece of whiteware, colorless glass, concrete, asphalt shingles, metal wire, one wire nail, and animal bone.  Among the collection are numerous pieces of asphalt likely relating to the construction and/or repair/degradation of Zion Road.  Several pieces of modern trash likely from park visitors were also recovered including a tie-wrap, Styrofoam, a plastic easting utensil fragment, and an aluminum foil food wrapper.  Amber glass was commonly used in historic times; however, judging from the shape, thickness, and lack of patina, the amber glass shards found at the site are likely shards from modern beers bottles.  Three fragments of charcoal, one shard of amber glass, and one piece of asphalt were recovered from highly disturbed fill encountered in shovel test S6 excavated along the paved entryway to the park parking lot.  Due to the disturbance and lack of any unequivocally cultural objects greater than 50 years of age, this shovel test was not considered positive.

The most potentially problematic cultural objects found in two of these six shovel tests were a single bone fragment in shovel tests S3 and 9 bone fragments in shovel test M38.  Regarding the latter, most of the breaks reflect 'new breaks' fractured during the excavation of this unit.  Since the Prehistoric component featured three human burials, it was necessary to have these bone fragments professionally evaluated.  Accordingly, they were personally brought to the Center for Archaeological Studies (CAS) at Texas State University, San Marcos.  On April 21, Jodi Jacobson, Ph.D. assessed the small bone fragment from ST S3 as '...the distal posterior segment of a medium-large sized artiodactyl humerus.  Most specifically the radial fossa tends to form a somewhat inverse Y at the base of the diaphysis and it was completely consistent with that portion.  Given size it compared well with both deer and pig, but was not discernable between the two.'  The multiple bone fragments from shovel test M38 were evaluated as '...all large mammal bone, most likely cow for most though there were a couple of bones that may have been in pig range.'

None of the Historic-era component of site 41DL396 is found intact.  With such poor integrity, this site holds limited research value.  The absence of any Prehistoric or Historic-era artifacts earlier than middle 20th century further reduces the potential for productive research.  This site presents almost no research value with respect to Historic-era cultural and historical studies.  Therefore, the portion of site 41DL396 that was surveyed within the project boundaries is recommended as not eligible for inclusion in the NRHP or for listing as a SAL.  The uninvestigated areas of site 41DL396 located that may be found outside of the project area, as found to the immediate southeast of the site under and across Zion Road and, to the north, into land area inundated by Lake Ray Hubbard, remain unevaluated.. desc_loc: At bend of the Trinity river.  1500 ft W of Hwy 35E, 400 ft W of powerline going NW to SE.  200 ft N of Furneaux Cr. 1800 deg N of E-W power lines.; The site is found in the Elm Fork channel and consists of three metal caissons.  It is ca. 400 m WSW of the Mills 2 benchmark, 1.8 km SE of where I-35 crosses the Elm Fork, and 1.9 km NNE of the Carrolton Dam.
water: In river and river bank; The site is in the Elm Fork Channel
drainage: Elm Fork of the Trinity River; Riverine
env_desc: On the river floodplain and typical river terrain.; The site is found in the channel of the Elm Fork and on the adjacent alluvial surface.  Vegetation consists of a thin band of mature trees along the river channel and grassy pastures beyond.
time_desc: Records at Cty Comm. Ct puts date built as 1890 by Missouri Valley Bridge and iron works.; Type of property
basis: Records at Cty Comm. Ct puts date built as 1890 by Missouri Valley Bridge and iron works.; Type of property represented
cult_desc:
One metal caisson in midriver ca. 3 ft in diameter with 20 ft showing above water, filled with concrete.  Two metal caissons on the bank ca. 20 ft from the river.  The diameter is the same with aobut 9 ft showing above ground.  About 40 ft between caisson in river and two caissons on the bank.; The Lorrains found three metal caissons, one in the river channel and two on the west bank of the river.  The caissons are about 3 ft wide, with the one in the river about 20 ft tall and the two on the west bank an estimated 9 ft tall.  The Lorrains found a timber ramp south of the bridge, but this was apparently not considered part of the bridge property.  Finally, the Lorrains found several wood pilings on the east bank of the Elm Fork, outside of our impact area.

During the current investigation, the two metal caissons, measuring 90 cm (3 ft) in diameter, were relocated on the west bank of the Elm Fork, while the third was observed in the center of the river.  A large wooden bridge footer and a portion of the old road was found on the banks of the river just south of the metal caissons. The footer, located at the channel edge, is constructed of four large wooden pillars with railroad ties as cross beams.  An approximate 30-m (100-ft) section of the old road remains but is heavily overgrown with grasses and small trees.  The berm is approximately 3 m (10 ft) high on the eastern end, and the other end is at ground level.  The eastern edge of the road is located approximately 20 m (66 ft) from the bridge footer.  A large pile of wooden debris was observed on the opposite bank of the river, which may represent the fallen remains of the bridge.
artifact: No artifacts observed; Refer to attached drawings for detail.
landuse: Hackberry, lots of brush and vines, Elm, Hickory dense thicket; Pasture/field
natural: Erosion, rust; Flood, natural weathering of metal.
artificial: Demolition of the structure ca. 1939; May be affected by construction of future hwy 190.
future: Construction of State Highway 190; Flood, natural weathering of metal.  May be affected by construction of future hwy 190.
value: As an archeological site, there are no significant cultural deposits associated with the bridge, while as an architectural property, too little of it remains to be considered significant.  Consequently, site 41DL231 is considered ineligible for inclusion in the NRHP.
disc_desc: Site 41DL320 consists of the remains of a historic bridge built by Dallas County in 1890.  Archival research was conducted by Paul and Jan Lorrain as part of the initial site recordation.  During the current investigation, site conditions appear to be the same as when recorded by the Lorrains.  As an archeological site, 41DL231 has no cultural deposits associated with it, while as architectural property too little of the property remains for it to be considered significant.

recname: Anne Gibson; Dallas Cty Archeological Society

desc_loc: In the city of Coppell at the S end fo Park Rd, one block S of Bethel Rd.  See attachment.; The site is located 0.11-miles south of the intersection of Park St. and W. Bethel Rd and 0.42-miles northeast of the intersection of S. Denton Tap Rd and Southwestern Blvd in the City of Coppell.
water: Grapevine Creek, 0m, north and south; Springs are 15 m from creek
ownerinfo: Dallas County; Dallas Cty. Park and Open Space; Mary B. Phinex, Administrator; 411 Elm St, 3rd floor; Dallas, Tx 75202
soil_desc: Axtell fine sandy loam, 1 to 3 percent slopes; Burleson clay, 0 to 1 percent slopes; Burleson clay, 1 to 3 percent slopes; Ferris-Heiden complex, 5 to 12 percent slopes; Silawa fine sandy loam, 3 to 8 percent slopes; Wilson clay loam, 1 to 3 percent slopes; Clay loam-blackland prairie
env_desc: The area  was developed by the WPA in the late 1930's as a public park.  The land surface is rolling and scenic.  The waling paths were lined with rock and many rock walls were built to provide stability to the sloping hills.  The coppell water tower is visible to the W.  The St Louis and SWestern RR tracks form a southern boundry to the park.; The site is located within the margins of a gently sloping upland setting that is dissected by Grapevine Creek.
time_desc: Pre-historic to present; Previous archeological investigations recovered prehistoric materials around the park.  In the early 1840s, Sam Houston encamped near the springs.  In the late 1930s, the WPA built several stone features for the creation of Grapevine Springs Park.
basis: Past archeological surveys recovered both prehistoric and historic-period artifacts.
cult_desc: Grapevine Springs Park was created in 1936 as a Works Progress Administration (WPA) project.  The park consists of numerous stone works by the WPA, which include: four cooking grills with centralized chimneys, a well covering the natural springs for which the park is named after, several drainage channels or basins, three sets of stone pillars that support wooden bridges, several sets of stairs, stone pillars marking the northern entrance to the park, a small paved area with borders for a garden, stone-lined walking paths, terraces retained by an extensive system of walls, and a canal along part of Grapevine Creek.  Except for the partial destruction of one cooking grill,  damage to a drainage channel by erosion, and deteriorated sections of the canal walls, all features appear to be well maintained and are in good condition.; Rock walls, pillars, fireplaces, stonelined well at springhead and rocklined channels for Grapevine Creek.  (See attached overall plan of rock work #1).  Most of the rock work is in place and in very good condition.  At the SW area of the old park was a baseball field and bleachers.  The metalwork for the backstop still remains.
basis_size: Original boundaries of the 12 acre park as seen in a 1958 aerial photograph
artifact: Ceramics nails and glass were found in the test pits and surface colleciton.  Due to the limited testing at this time, there is little material upon which to base a conclusion as to occupaiton.; The only subsurface material observed below WPA fill were two small, non-descript bone fragments, which could not be identified as cultural due to a lack of provenance.
intact: All; The majority of the WPA features within the site are in good condition.
landuse: Cedar, oak, pecan, briars, cactus mesquirte, grasses; Urban park
natural: Eroison, ewathering of rock work; Flooding of Grapevine Creek, erosion, overgrowth of vegetation
artificial: Heavy foot traffic, addition of modern park modifications (picnic tables, trash cans, hand rails, etc.); Used for grazing.
future: Half the park has been preserved, the remainder is on sale for commercial development.; The canal is going to be dredged and seven sections of the WPA canal walls will be repaired.
value: The site has low to moderate archeological research value based on the diffuse accumulation of subsurface cultural materials, yet the site retains the integrity and uniqueness of the WPA era stone features located throughout the park. It is assumed that the WPA construction has severely impacted or nearly destroyed any prehistoric or historic-period deposits located at Grapevine Springs prior to the WPA activities.
invest: The county is currently restoring the park and the rock work.  Half the original 12 acres has been donated to the city.  To preserve the entire park we will need to raise the funds for 6 more acres.  There will be further testing in the surrounding areas which have been less disturbed.
regist: WPA features are eligible for NRHP and SAL designation
disc_desc: Grapevine Springs Park is famously reported to have once contained the encampment of Sam Houston during his 1843 visit to North-Central Texas as part of treaty negotiations with Native American tribes at Bird's Fort.  During the late 1930s, the Works Progress Administration (WPA) was allotted $25,000 to develop a 12-acre park.  Construction utilized native stone to construct rock walls, a canal, a dam, outdoor cooking grills, rock well house, rock-lined walkways, and three wooden bridges spanning Grapevine Creek.  The first archeological investigation at Grapevine Springs Park was conducted by the Dallas Archeological Society (DAS) in 1992.  During the survey, the DAS conducted a survey of 640 acres and mapped all above ground features within the park.  Through the DAS' efforts, 20 surficial features and a variety of historic-aged artifacts were documented within 6 acres of the original park.  However, only one artifact potentially dating to the mid-1800s, when Sam Houston reportedly camped within the park, was identified during the survey.  In addition, a low-density accumulation of subsurface prehistoric lithic debris was recorded within and adjacent to the park.   In 2000, AR Consultants, Inc. (ARC) was contracted to survey approximately 40 acres, of which a three-acre portion of the survey area overlapped the park's northwestern corner.  During the survey, no prehistoric archeological sites were encountered in eleven shovel tests.  ARC observed the western stone pillar entrance, cattle guards, an area containing roses and a crape myrtle, a series of 15 wooden posts set into concrete, and the metal baseball backstop that was part of the original baseball diamond.   The third survey was conducted in 2007 by a combination of DAS, ARC, and volunteers as part of Texas Archeological Month.  The investigations focused primarily on identifying subsurface archeological deposits through the use of systematic pedestrian survey utilizing metal detectors and the excavation of four test units.  No artifacts greater than 50 years of age were documented during the survey.   During the IES investigation, only a 2.9-acre portion of the site near the canal was revisited for subsurface testing.  Auger tests instead of shovel tests were performed to reach possible deeply buried cultural deposits below WPA fill.  A total of eight auger tests were excavated to a depth of 80-90 cmbs.  In one auger test, two small, non-descript bone fragments were recovered at 20-60 cmbs.  No prehistoric or historical subsurface artifacts nor evidence of the Sam Houston encampment were identified during the survey.  As a part of the research plan for the project, the stone WPA features located throughout the park were examined and recorded in order to assess condition and potential for NRHP listing and SAL designation.  Site boundaries for 41DL329 created for the IES survey are based on the original 12-acre park boundaries georeferenced in a 1958 aerial photograph and property descriptions in Dallas County Deed Records Vol 2198, Pg. 496 and Vol 3212, Pg. 454.

sitename: No Data; NIBLO FARM SITE; Niblo Farm
projname: Archeological Investigations at Niblo Farm; THC-Stewardship Activities
additional:
Dan Potter--THC; Lorrain, Jan and Paul.  2002.  Site form for 41DL352.

James, F.  2004.   The Sharrock Family in Dallas County 1845-1854.  Dallas County Pioneer Association.  www.dallaspioneers.org/stories/historical/php?ID=277, accessed November 6, 2008.
recname: Jan and Paul Lorrain; Steven Hunt
address1: 2201 K Ave., Suite A2; 612 Phillips Dr.
surf_tech: Transects were done at 10 m intervals in the wooded area outside the chainlink fence to see if there were any features or dumps.
test_meth: 20 - 50x50 cm units were judgmentally placed among the outbuildings to determine if any pristine 19th century deposits remain

time_occ: Historic; Historic, Early Statehood, Middle Statehood
desc_loc: Intersection of 408 and I20.  Take Grady Niblo Exit and turn right. Follow Grady Nibly Rd. to Kiwannis (actually one road).  The address is 5429 Kiwanis.  There is a gate and gravel road leading to the site; The site is located on the edge of the White Rock Escarpment overlooking Spur 408.  The former farm is being actively developed, with the area to the east becoming a suburban housing development and the headquarters area becoming a City Park.
water: Artesian Creek 1/4 mile SW of site; Artesian Creek is ca. 300 m SW
ownerinfo: City of Dallas, Parks and Recreation, 1500 Marilla Avenue, Room 6F9, Dallas, TX  75201; Grady and Barbara Niblo, Jr.
soil_desc: Eddy clay loam, 1 to 3 percent slopes; Eddy clay loam, 5 to 8 percent slopes; Eddy-Stephen complex, 1 to 5 percent slopes; and Austin-Lewisville complex, 5 to 8 percent slopes, eroded; White Rock Escarpment
env_desc: The farm headquarters is surrounded by a dense hardwood forest that was recently cleared from around the outbuildings.  The site sits on the edge of the White Rock Escarpment overlooking Spur 408.
time_desc: Oral history interview; The site was first occupied around 1850 and is still occupied
basis: Oral History Interview; The farm was first occupied in the late 1840s or e
cult_desc:
Five extant buildings are present on site: the log cabin, timber barn, plank barn, tin coop, and house.  The plank barn was in poor condition and about to collapse.  The house is still occupied by Mrs. Niblo.  It is ca. 22-x-11 m in size and is sheathed in wide boards, probably to give it the appearance of a log cabin

A hand dug well is just north of the house - it is ca. 180 cm in diameter and at least 4.55 m deep.  Although the well shaft is round, a rectangular area has been cut into the bedrock near water table.  The well curb extends 35 cm above ground surface.  The well is constructed in three zones:  handmade and machine-made brick in the first 40 cm below the top of the well curb; dry-laid tabular stone from 40-80 cm below the top of the curb; and bedrock below 80 cm.  A concrete box 126-x-80 cm is immediately west of the well.  It contains a modern pump connected to the well with black PVC pipe.

There is also a root cellar about 3 m west of the log cabin.  It is covered with an earthen mound approximately 10 m in diameter.  The roof of the cellar has collapsed, dropping part of the mound into the cellar.  The cellar is 2.5-x-2.5 m in size and was excavated into bedrock.

The log cabin is 4.4-x-4.4 m in size and is built from square hewn logs.  It has doors in the center of the north and south walls.  A window was also placed in the north wall, just west of the door.  The window is now filled with wood and covered by asphalt shingles.  A dry-laid, stone chimney is present along the west wall.  It measures 180-x-90 cm.

The timber barn is downslope from the log cabin.  There are two log cribs approximately 3-x-4.6 m in size that are separated by a 2 m wide breezeway.  The eastern pen is in good shape, the western pen is collapsing.  Two timber-framed structures are immediately north of the log pens.  These are 2.8-x-3 m in size.  The timber framing is exposed on the exterior, while the interior is clad with wooden planks.  Small doors are present in the breezeway.  Finally, there is a shed roof in the southwest corner of the structures that measures 3-x-3 m in size.  It is made from milled lumber and doesn't look as old as the barn.  The rafters for the shed roof are mortised into a log of the adjoining log pen.  An unused mortise is also cut into the log, which also suggests that the shed roof is not original to the structure.

The plank barn is 6.4-x-6.1 m in size and is divided into two equal portions.  The western half has enclosed rooms built using milled lumber and wire nails, while the eastern half is an open shed roof.  The enclosed rooms have exterior studs and plank walls.  A door and window are present along the east wall, while two other openings, presumably windows, are cut into the west wall.  A collapsed row of rafters is present on the north side, indicating that there was a shed roof in this area.  The barn was originally roofed using wood shingles that were later covered with corrugated sheet metal.  An isolated water faucet was found protruding from the ground west of the plank barn.

The tin coop is a pole barn ca. 13-x-4.1 m in size. It seems to be made from salvaged materials.  Many of the supporting poles are round and creosote impregnated, suggesting that they were originally utility poles, while other poles seem to salvaged from previous structures.  It is clad with corrugated sheet metal which had many small holes (apparently nail holes), once again suggesting the use of salvaged material.

A tall berm is present east of the outbuildings, with a concrete foundation present at the south end of the berm.  Several fence remnants were noted in the wooded areas.  A small pond is present northwest of the tin coop, on the edge of the escarpment.  A large, recent dump area was found southwest of the house.  Finally, another isolated faucet was found at a fence corner southeast of the Niblo house.

An anomalous loamy surface deposit was found in Unit 9, north of the timber barn.  The area containing Unit 9 was slightly elevated above the surrounding landform and was surrounded by a fence.  These factors suggest that either the area was used as a garden and the loamy soil brought into the area or that the area was an animal pen and the loamy soil developed from the manure.; Log home, barns, hand dug well, old farm equipment, storm cellar
site_size: ca, 100-x-80 m, oriented north-south; one acre +
basis_size: Extent of surface material and standing structures; surface inspection
artifact: Handmade brick (n=1), machine-made brick (n=10), cement (n=2), concrete (n=1), ironstone (n=9), porcelain (n=2), Bristol exterior/natural clay slipped interior stoneware (n=1), Bristol interior/exterior stoneware (n=1), salt glazed exterior/natural clay slipped interior stoneware (n=1), blue tinted whiteware (n=3), light blue tinted whiteware (n=3), Pure white whiteware (n=10), amber brown bottle glass (n=11), aqua bottle glass (n=8), aqua lamp glass (n=1), aqua window glass (n=2), clear with ash tint bottle glass (n=11), clear bottle glass (n=94), clear lamp glass (n=3), clear table glass (n=1), clear window glass (n=4), dark green glass insulator (n=1), blue Depression glass (n=1), emerald green bottle glass (n=2), light green bottle glass (n=2), light green window glass (n=11), light tinted plate glass (n=1), light tinted window glass (n=1), manganese solarized bottle glass (n=6), manganese solarized table glass (n=1), burned managanese solarized glass (n=1), milk glass (n=1), .22 cartridge case (n=4), iron washer (n=1), crown cap (n=4), fence staple (n=7), horse shoe (n=1), possible machine parts (n=2), iron pin for hanging curtains (n=1), iron rivet head (n=1), cut nails (n=7), unidentified thin metal (n=2), tin can rim (n=2), wire (n=2) wire nails (n=36), battery core (n=1), rubber shoe heel (n=1), plastic (n=3) and charcoal (n=9).  The majority are twentieth century in age with only 25 artifacts dating to the nineteenth century.; Large farm equipment, no small artifacts noted
circum: Perfect conditions; The woods surounding the chainlink fence are very thick; current investigations were focused on the area surrounding the standing structures
intact: The site retains good contextual integrity; all
landuse: Occupation by Niblo family; The area is being developed as a City Park
natural: Erosion, bioturbation; structures degraded, no other impacts noted
artificial: Construction of the chain link fence; none
future: Development as a city park; development is all around this area.  a miracle the site is still present
value: Site appears to be a very well preserved and valuable farmstead, dating very early for this area.; The site is an example of an Antebellum farmstead; unfortunately the small size and shallow deposits mean that no unmixed 19th century deposits were encountered.  The project was limited in scope and concentrated on the area surrounding the standing structures.
invest: Architectural stabilization a first priority; The site is already going to be preserved as a city park.  Stabilization of the standing structures by Quimby McCoy Preservation Architecture, LLP, has already begun.  If further archeological investigation are desired, systematic excavations should be undertaken in the wooded areas surrounding the chainlink fence, especially at the northern edge of the site where deeper soils are thought to exist.
disc_desc:
The Niblo Farm was first occupied in the 1840s or early 1850sand remained in use until recently.  After Dr. Niblo died, the headquarters area of the farm was deeded to the City of Dallas as a park, while the remainder of the property was sold for development.  Mrs. Niblo is still living at the farm house (as of 2009).  All of the standing historic buildings except for the farm house are surrounded by a chainlink fence.

Five standing buildings are present at the site.  Two buildings (the log cabin and log barn) are of considerable age.  The plank barn and tin coop are much more recent in age, while the Niblo house is likely the most recent.  The tin coop appears to made from salvaged material.  The plank barn is in poor conditions.  Stabilization of the buildings has begun.

A total of 20 50-x-50 cm was judgmentally placed around the standing buildings in order to determine if any isolated 19th century deposits exist at the site.   Seventeen of the units were shallow and underlain by bedrock; only the northern-most three units (Units 9, 19, and 20) contained subsoil.  The 19th century materials found on site were all in mixed context with 20th century materials.  The only subsurface feature found in the units was the anomalous loamy topsoil found in Unit 9.

Surface inspection was conducted in the wooded areas surrounding the chainlink fence to see if any 19th century dump areas were present.  Although several more surface features were encountered, the only dump area found was recent in origin.; The site has been in continuous occupation since 1840, however the log cabin and barns have not been used for many years.  A 1936 tractor is present nearby.  Barns show wonderful construction details but are in poor shape.  Cabin is in better shape, but chimney is degrading badly. High potential for studying early farmsteads.

2.  Plan map of site
3.  Floor plan of log cabin
4.  Floor plan of timber barn
5.  Floor plan of plank barn
6.  Floor plan of tin coop; photos and quick hand sketch

Although several more surface features were encountered, the only dump area found was recent in origin.; The site has been in continuous occupation since 1840, however the log cabin and barns have not been used for many years.  A 1936 tractor is present nearby.  Barns show wonderful construction details but are in poor shape.  Cabin is in better shape, but chimney is degrading badly. High potential for studying early farmsteads.. No Data

projname: Proposed SH161 in Grand Prairie, Texas
surf_tech: On foot surface examination- no material collected; observation only
records: False; False; False; False; False; False; False; False; False; False; False; False; False
desc_loc: From the intersection of Belt Line Road and Crossland, go 350 to 400 m WSW. The site is in a pasture and appears as a scatter of 20th century trash, bricks, and tin sheet metal. A cluster of pecan trees is in the West central portion of the site. Power line cross the S part of the site and runs E-W. No structures are standing.
water: Fish Creek is about 250 m S of the site
drainage: W fork of the Trinity River
env_desc: N terrace of Fish Creek. The site is in a grassy pasture. Pecan trees are present in a cluster in the west-central portion of the site. Galleria forest occurs along Fish Creek, 150 to 200 m S of the site (Fish Creek is about 250 m to the S).
basis: Plentiful debris but lacking material that might be diagnostic of 19th century or earlier.
cult_desc: Because of the lack of pre-20th century material and the fact that the sites buildings appear on recent maps, there is no reason to believe it is older that early 20th century, and it was probably only recently abandoned.
artifact: Clear glass, window glass, 5 bricks (none with inscriptions)- most materila was found near the cluster of pecan trees , no purple glass was visible among the glass fragments.
circum: Weather was warm and sunny. Emphasis was placed on portion of the site within the right of way.
intact: 100 percent of deposits, but none of the structures
artificial: An alternative route for SH161 passes through the W portion of the site.
future: If this alternative route is selected, the W portion of the site deposits will be removed.
disc_desc: The structures, thoug no longer standing, appear on the 7.5 minute USGS Arlington quadrangle dated 1959 (revised 1981).

water: Furneaux Creek is about 200 m. S of the site
ownerinfo:
Lively-Stansbury Management Corporation, 4343
Shenendoah, Dallas, Texas
env_desc: Site F-1 is found at the edge of an upland rise overlooking the floodplain of Furneaux Creek.  Originally this was though to represent an upland remnant, but after consulting the Dallas County soil survey it was found that the area to the S has been mined for gravel.  Vegetation on the site was mainly short grasses, with tall reeds near the house foundation and hardwood trees near the foundation and along the fencelines.
artifact: Plastic strawa, plastic fragment, and cut bone were found through shovel testing.  Miscellaneous iron objects, an old battery, and assorted debris were also noted around the house.
circum: Mid morning, nice day, very sunny out
value: The site appears to have little research potential due to the relative lack of artifacts, the many 20th century sites already excavated around Dallas, and the late date of occupation; therefore, the site is considered to be ineligible for inclusion on the NRHP.
invest: No further work; Few cultural deposits, very recent occupation
disc_desc: Site F-1 is a historic occupation found in NW Dallas County.  The site is not shown on Sam Streets Map of Dallas County.  The site is not shown on the Sam Streets Map of Dallas County (1900), but is shown on the General Highway Map of Dallas County (1936) and the Carrollton Quad. (1959, photorevised 1981).  No structure is apparent on the aerial photographs included with the Dallas County Soil Survey (1980).  Based on the map information, the site was apparently first occupied early in the 20th century and was abandoned between 1959 and 1980.  Unfortunately, deed title and tax records were inconclusive, although the lack of data suggests that this was a tenant occupation.

disc_desc: This historic site is located in the floodplain of Spring Creek.  The site consisted of two historic artifact concentrations.  Concentration "A" consists of brick and melted glass in an open area between the fence and the RR tracks.  Concentration "B" is located in the woods next to an unnamed drainage.  This concentration consists of whiteware, various colors of glass bottoms and bottle necks (green, aqua, light blue, amethyst, and colorless), and some bricks.  The site represents the remains of a late 19th - early 20th century homestead.  Much of the site is in private hands and is not being impacted by the replacement of RR tracks or any other means.; This historic site is located on the floodplain of Spring Creek. desc_loc: No Data

env_desc: Ridge top with grassy with few mesquite saplings and juniper.
artifact: Bricks, square nails, window glass, bottle glass, and ceramics. Historic domestic debris, spent ammunition, lip and broken neck of a clear glass prescription bottle with hand turned applied lip that is flat rimmed, window glass, cut nails, wire nails, hand-made bricks and brick fragments (Floyd and Skinner 1998, 14).
artificial: Evidence of vegetation removal/plowing due to young tree growth
disc_desc: Based on the correlation between the dates in the late 1800s indicated by the artifacts described above, and the presence of a  renter house  in the corresponding location on the Sam Street s map, we have concluded that site 41DL378 is the location of this house. The absence of any structural features and the disturbance [erosion, plowing] that the land has endured since the house was present, indicates that the historic value of the site has been fulfilled by recording the site. No other evidence of historic utilization of the Preserve was found, but this is to be expected if the lower area was farmed and the slopes and upland were used to graze cattle (Floyd and Skinner 1998, 15).
