explain: No Data; late 19th to early 20th century farmstead
additional:
Site form generated from information provided in the following:
Hunt, Steven M., Maynard B. Cliff, and Melissa M. Green (1998) Intensive Pedestrian Survey at the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department s 178-acre Pelton Tract, City of Rowlett, Dallas County, Texas.
records: digital map; digital photos; photo logs; project report; shapefile; shovel test notes
permhouse: Texas Archeological Research Laboratory, The University of Texas at Austin
desc_loc: Site 41DL379 is located northwest of the northern terminus of Hickox Road, City of Rowlett, Dallas County, Texas.
soil_desc: Houston Black clay, 1 to 3 percent slopes
env_desc: Upland ridge above the Muddy Creek floodplain.
cult_desc:
The main feature was a standing structure, likely an old garage, measuring about 4 by 6 m. It was built with a board-and-batten technique, had a gable-ended design, and a sheet-metal roof. The southeast side had a large opening, probably a garage door, and five small (20 by 20 cm) openings in the northeast wall, which were not filled with window glass. A 2 m wide lean-to had been added to the northeast side, with rafters tacked over the roof, indicating it was a later addition.

A second feature was the presumed house location, covering about 8 by 10 m. This area contained cast-iron sewer pipe, concrete fragments, brick fragments, and a small mound of debris, possibly bulldozed. Sections of the water plumbing system were on the ground, and a dead tree was located southeast of the site. A grounding stake was found on the southwest side, and an iris bed was along the southwest fence. Gravel between the house and Hickox Road was thought to be for a driveway.

Other smaller features included an upturned section of corrugated metal culvert (160 by 140 cm), likely buried near or under the house, with an unclear function. A large pile of lumber (10 by 2 m) was found against a hog wire fence northwest of the house, possibly from a collapsed structure or salvaged material (Hunt et al. 1998).
artifact: sheet metal, bottle glass, stoneware, whiteware, brick, nail, window glass (Hunt et al. 1998).
value: Site 41DL379 is considered ineligible for nomination to the NRHP or as a SAL  (Hunt et al. 1998, 31).
invest: No further work recommended.  (Hunt et al. 1998).
disc_desc: The occupation at site 41DL379 appears to have begun in the late nineteenth century and continued until at least the 1960s. No isolation was observed between the late-nineteenth century and late twentieth-century components, while the latter is felt to have adversely impacted upon the earlier component (Hunt et al. 1998).
Concat_site_variables:
No Data; farmstead. No Data. September 1-3, 1998. September 1-3, 1998. n/a. Site 41DL379 is located northwest of the northern terminus of Hickox Road, City of Rowlett, Dallas County, Texas.. Houston Black clay, 1 to 3 percent slopes. Upland ridge above the Muddy Creek floodplain.. archival research; artifacts. The main feature was a standing structure, likely an old garage, measuring about 4 by 6 m. It was built with a board-and-batten technique, had a gable-ended design, and a sheet-metal roof. The southeast side had a large opening, probably a garage door, and five small (20 by 20 cm) openings in the northeast wall, which were not filled with window glass. A 2 m wide lean-to had been added to the northeast side, with rafters tacked over the roof, indicating it was a later addition.

A second feature was the presumed house location, covering about 8 by 10 m. This area contained cast-iron sewer pipe, concrete fragments, brick fragments, and a small mound of debris, possibly bulldozed. Sections of the water plumbing system were on the ground, and a dead tree was located southeast of the site. A grounding stake was found on the southwest side, and an iris bed was along the southwest fence. Gravel between the house and Hickox Road was thought to be for a driveway.

Other smaller features included an upturned section of corrugated metal culvert (160 by 140 cm), likely buried near or under the house, with an unclear function. A large pile of lumber (10 by 2 m) was found against a hog wire fence northwest of the house, possibly from a collapsed structure or salvaged material (Hunt et al. 1998).. The occupation at site 41DL379 appears to have begun in the late nineteenth century and continued until at least the 1960s. No isolation was observed between the late-nineteenth century and late twentieth-century components, while the latter is felt to have adversely impacted upon the earlier component (Hunt et al. 1998).. 0

records: digital map; digital photos; photo logs; shapefile; shovel test notes
permhouse: Texas Archeological Research Laboratory, The University of Texas at Austin
desc_loc: Site 41DL380 is located in the median of the President George Bush Turnpike between the exits for Merritt Road, Dity of Rowlett, Dallas County, Texas.
soil_desc: Ferris Heiden complex, 5 to 12 percent slopes
env_desc: Sloping upland terrace overlooking the Muddy Creek floodplain, with grass cover.
cult_desc: One potential feature was observed at the site, a well/cistern. Curved sections of bricks (still mortared together) from the casing of a well/cistern were found dumped in the bottom of the gully north of the site. These materials are obviously no longer in situ. A concentration of bricks was nearby on the surface at the south edge of the gully. The concentration was rounded and about 1.5 min diameter. Although impacted by bulldozing, the brick concentration seems the most likely location for the well/cistern (Hunt et al. 1998).
artifact: glass, ceramics
value: Given the lack of any subsurface deposits and the extensive disturbance observed at the site, it is considered to have no research potential. Consequently, site 41DL380 is considered ineligible for nomination to the NRHP or designation as a SAL (Hunt et al. 1998).
invest: No further work is required at the site (Hunt et al. 1998).
disc_desc: Site 41DL380 is a large, low density historic artifact scatter. No subsurface materials were recovered from the site. Based on the artifacts recovered, the site occupation began in the late nineteenth or early twentieth century and may have continued until the mid-twentieth century. However, the low density of the artifact scatter suggests that this was a short-term occupation  (Hunt et al. 1998).
Concat_site_variables: No Data; occupation. No Data. September 1-3, 1998. September 1-3, 1998. n/a. env_desc: House was on a low ridge that extends from the base of the upland into the Rowlett Creek floodplain.
cult_desc: Two story house with shed rooted living addition. Recent well house is immediately to the south of the house which is 12 ft square in outside dimensions.
artifact: novelty siding ca 1910, wire nails ca. 20th century, portland cement holding commercial brick ca. 20th century.
circum: When first visited, the east side of the house was covered with Viginia Creeper.
value: Only photographs of the house exist now. Structure has been demolished.
regist: The house had (emphysis on had) potential.
disc_desc: The building is covered with horizontal novelty siding that was nailed in place with wire nails. The roof is gabled and has an unusually wide overhang. It is estimated that the original two-story structure was constructed about 1910 and that the downstairs room served as the kitchen/dining/living room and the upstairs was a bedroom. Access to the second story was by way of an exterior stairway that is on the south side of the structure. A free-standing exterior chimney was added to the structure in the 1920s, based on the commercial bricks and the Portland cement used.The chimney is mounted on a cement pad and is connected to the house with horizontal brick extensions into which the flue pipe from a metal cook/heating stove was placed in order to effectively remove the smoke generated by burning. The chimney has been constructed through the roof overhang. A living room addition with a shed roof was attached to the east side of the original structure within the past 50 years. The house has been crudely plumbed and has been wired for electricty. The downstairs floor is made of 3 1/4" pine flooring, which has been covered with linoleum in the past. Windows are present in the north and west walls, but no evidence of a window is present in the east wall. The door is in the center of the south wall. The bathroom was apparently added to the interior of the structure, possibly at the same time that the living room addition was constructed. The walls fo the original room were pine boards that were covered with cheese cloth over which several layers of floral patterened wallpaper were added. Subsequently, the wall was covered with plasterboard. The north and south exterior walls of the living room are covered with wide horizontal siding, and the novelty siding from the east wall of the original building was recycled onto the east end of the addition. The ceiling is barely six feet high, and appeared to be original. The original two-story house with two small rooms stacked on top of each other is an unusual structure for north-central Texas. Unfortunately, the City of Garland bulldozed the house and surrounding area before other options for preserving the house could be investigated.
Concat_site_variables: No Data; historic. No Data; Ganze Ranch. 04/281999. 28-Apr-99. No Data. explain: No Data; Lithics exposed on surface within housing development.
additional: Archaeological Survey of the Firewheel Golf Course Expansion Garland, Texas. ARC cultural resources report 99-27.
desc_loc: At Loop 190 (George Bush Tollway) and Brand road, turn right (north) onto Brand road. At Canterbury turn right. At the next street, Firewheel, turn right and continue on Firewheel until you pass Shinnecock Hills Circle. The site is "under" the houses that are on the east side of Shinnecock and Firewheel. Artifacts on surface are also behind the houses, on the west and east side of a black metal fence.
water: Spring Creek, perennial, ~300 m to the east.
env_desc: Site is situated on a terrace remnant or resistant bedrock of limestone that overlooks Spring Creek and its floodplain to the east.
artifact: lithics of chert and quartzite and FCR.
circum: Cloudy, 40 mph gusts, dense grass with some bare ground in places.
artificial: more construction for houses and golf course work.
value: recordation only as site is likely destroyed by now.
disc_desc: Site was exposed during house pad preparation for a housing development. Artifacts scattered on the "surface" but their actual placement was unknown. Site could have been partially buried before pad preparation.

explain: No Data; subsurface deposit of large mammal bone, polished bone, and a chert flake

additional:
Current project report is
Cultural Resources Survey of the Proposed Environmental Restoration Areas Along the Old West Fork of the Trinity River, Dallas County, Texas,

by Elizabeth Burson, for Geo-Marine, Inc., September 1999
surf_tech: intensive pedestrian survey, 30 meter transects, 3 shovel tests, no artifacts observed
test_meth: 3 50-60 cm shovel tests, showing no cultural resources, then 5 backhoe test trenches, 120 cm deep, one revealing cultural deposit
exca_meth: backhoe geoarcheological trenches, as mentioned above
records: prints, testing/unit/square records, stratigraphic profiles, slides, maps/drawings, shovel test records, daily journal, field catalog
desc_loc: From intersection of Bickers and Furey in southwest Dallas continue into undeveloped field along unpaved Bickers extension.  Site is at the intersection of this extension and the channelized drainage running N-S.
water: West Fork of the Trinity River, 1000 meters north
env_desc: Trinity River flood plain, behind a natural levee along the channel, very level.
time_desc: depth (West Fork Paleosol), assemblage (lithic debitage and dietary bone)
cult_desc: One concentration of large mammal bone and a chert flake were discovered at 1 meter in depth, just under the surface of the West Fork Paleosol.  The concentration was small (<1 meter in diameter), but was not investigated extensively.  Additional test trenches 15 and 20 meters on either side were negative, but may be a function of the sparse nature of flood plain deposits
basis_size: negative test units 15 and 20 meters on either side, channel to the west.
artifact:
a handfull of dietary large mammal bone fragments
a few fragments of highly polished large mammal bone
one large chert flake, possibly utilized

all artifacts were found in a single concentration
circum: deposit is subsurface, only 5 test trenches were excavated.
value: The site is unique in that it is a flood plain deposit containing lithics.
invest: Additional testing should the land be planned for excavation.
disc_desc: No Data

type_site: No Data; unknown prehistoric, game procurement, lithic scatter
explain: No Data; This site was encountered in a backhoe trench.  The remains of a probable hearth with associated bivalves and faunal elements was encountered.  No artifacts were recovered.
additional:
David Shanabrook - geoarcheologist

Draft Report

S. Hunt, D.C. Shanabrook, F. B. Largent, Jr., D.E. Peter, M. Goelz, and K.A. Krapf
1999   Cultural Resources Survey and Geoarcheological Investigations for the Proposed State Highway 190 Project between IH35E and IH-635, Dallas County, Texas.  Miscellaneous Reports of Investigations Number 171. Geo-Marine, Inc., Plano, Texas.
surf_tech: Site deposit encountered while conducting geoarcheological trenching in flood plain of Elm Fork of Trinity River.  Samples collected from backhoe trench wall.
records: prints, stratigraphic profiles, slides, maps/drawings, slide log, special samples inventory, print log, daily journal
samples: Soil samples for humate dating and charcoal from hearth feature matrix were collected.  Large chunks of soil matrix containing burned earth, charcoal, and bivalves were collected from the trench wall.  Vertical locations of all samples were carefully recorded.
desc_loc: The site is 388 meters WSW of the junction of the Elm Fork of the Trinity and Furneaux Creek; 1,700 meters NNE of the Carrollton Dam; and 1,650 meters SSE on the intersection of the Elm Fork Channel and IH35E.
water: Elm Fork of the Trinity River, 145 meters north
ownerinfo: Lively Stansbury Management Corporation8325 Douglas Ave., Suite 1223DallasTX75225
env_desc: Site is within flood plain deposits of Elm Fork of the Trinity River.  An abandoned channel scar of the Trinity lies immediately to the west while the active channel of the Trinity River curves eastward just north of the site and then curves south and back west.  Vegetation of the immediate site area is pasture.  Trees line the abandoned channel scar and the Elm Fork channel.  A powerline right-of-way is located just west  of the site area.
time_desc: Radiocarbon date from charcoal associated with the feature. Measured C14 age is 700 +/- 90 BP (Beta-122992)
basis: Limited view from backhoe trench did not allow an accurate assessment of components represented; however, two separate occupations may be represented.
cult_desc: At a depth of 3.4 meters, the trackhoe cut through a concentration of well-preserved, large mussel shells up to 8 cm in diameter.  The remains, as observed in the trench wall, appeared in a lens-shaped concentration measuring 75 cm across and 20 cm thick.  It is possible, although unlikely, that the shell was concentrated by natural means.  Sixty cm below the shell lens, the trackhoe encountered a concentration of burned earth in association with abundant charcoal and shell.  This concentration is at least 30 cm thick.  The charcoal yielded a radiocarbon date of 700 +/- 90 B. P.  It appears that this feature was constructed on a bench within the cut-and-fill deposits related to the former channel that is still evident ot the west.;
site_size: Five meters in diameter; otherwise unknown
basis_size: Length of trench exposure and negative findings in a trench excavated nearby
thickness: 3.4 meters below surface to 4.3 meters below surface
artifact: Burned soil matrix, charcoal, and bivalves.  No lithic or ceramic artifacts were located.
circum: Geoarcheological trenching only; determining limits of site were not part of scope of work
future: Potential use of area for a borrow pit for State Highway 190 construction.  Borro activities would reach a depth of 8 feet.
value: Potentially represents a short-term hunting camp or extraction site of the Late Prehistoric period.  Potential of single occupational component is good.
invest: Test excavations would be necessary to document the extent of the site and whether it contains data important to the understanding of prehistoric settlement/subsistenc patterns in the region.
disc_desc: Site will only have value if significant subsistence data and a tool assemblage are present.
attachmem: U.S.G.S. quad map showing location of siteProfile drawing

projname: EA for proposed International Commerce Park at DFW
additional:
Sam Street's Map of Dallas County (1900)
Soil Survey of Dallas County, Texas (1924)
Grapevine quadrangle (photorevised 1973)
Grapevine quadrangle (photorevised 1981)
records: daily journal, field catalog, print log, prints, shovel test records, slide logs, slides, slides
desc_loc: The site is located SE of the intersection of County Line and Cotton roads.  It is also ca. 1.2 km E of the intersection of Cottonwood Creek and the St. Louis Southwestern railroad, 1.2 km north of the intersection of County Line Road and Grapevine Creek, and 700 m WSW of the intersection of Radio Road and Cotton Road.
soil_desc: Crockett fine sandy loam, 1-3% slopes; Wilson clay loam, 1-3% slopes; Normangee clay loam, 1-3& slopes
env_desc: The site is located on the crest and northern slope of an upland ridge system.  It is primarily covered with grasses and weeds, with many mesquite saplings near the eastern fence line. Mature hardwood trees are concentrated along the east and west fence lines, with more trees scattered across the remaining site area.  Very large (ca. 1- 1.5 m diameter) hardwood trees are concentrated near the house mound, as is a very large cedar tree.  Many of the very large trees appear to be dead.
time_desc: Historic maps, extant features, shovel testing
basis: historic maps, extant features, shovel testing
cult_desc:
Ten features were identified at site DFW-1.  Feature 1 is a concrete slab measuring 20 m E-W- x-6 m N-S.  The feature is found along the north slope of the ridge system.  The slab had been cut into the slope somewhat, so that the SW corner is ca. 10 cm below ground surface and the NE corner is ca. 20 cm above ground surface.  Much of the slab is covered with soil (colluvium?).  Foundation walls with protruding bolts were noted in the NE corner.

Feature 2 is a large depression, ca. 6 m in diameter and 1.2 m deep, that is filled with tires, car and machine parts, concrete and concrete block fragments.  This is interpreted as a possible cistern or root cellar.

Feature 3 is a well head, consisting of two concentric metal pipes 12 cm and 15 cm in diameter.  The intervening void space appears to filled with cement.

Feature 4 is a house mound on top of a concrete slab measuring 13 m E-W x 22 m N-S.  Much of the slab is covered with up to 30 cm of soil, so that much of the delineation was done using a steel tile probe.  The one shovel test that was excavated in the house mound encountered a tile floor ca. 20 cm below surface.

Feature 5 consists of a ceramic pipe ca. 10 cm in diameter with a 15 cm diameter flange at the top.  The pipe descends to NNW at an estimated 20 degree angle.  This is interpreted as a possible sewer pipe.

Feature 6 is a circular depression, about 6 m in diameter and 50-60 cm deep, that is located about 10 m NE of the house mound.  This is interpreted as a possible root cellar/cistern.

Feature 7 is another metal well head, this time found on the opposite side of a barbed wire fence from the main site area.  It consists of a 15 cm diameter metal pipe about 30 m tall, placed within a 20 cm metal pipe only 8 cm tall.  Four concrete fragments and a 2.5 cm diameter, threaded, metal pipe fragment were found on the surface nearby.

Feature 8 is an oblong depression measuring 6 m SW-NE and 4 m SE-NW.  It is interpreted as a possible root cellar/cistern.

Feature 9 consists of a hand-dug well surmounted by a windmill.  The hand-dug well is oblong, measuring 70 cm NW-SE x 45 cm NE-SW (interior diameter).  The well is lined with large sandstone slabs with water table an estimated 5-6 m below surface.  The mouth of the well is covered with a concrete foundation 175 cm square and 35 cm wide.  Along the interior edge there is a depressed area, similar to a rabbet joint, to support a well cover.  The concrete foundation supports a metal windmill frame that is an estimated 6 m tall. The windmill is no longer functional since it has lost all of its blades.

Feature 10 consists of a round depression about 10 m in diameter that appears to be in the location of a building on the Grapevine quadrangle (photorevised 1973).  In the center of the depression there is a very regular, rectangular area of raised soil measuring 3.5 m E-W x 2 m N-S that is assumed to represent the footprint of the structure.  This area rises an estimated 10 to 15 cm above the surrounding ground surface.  Only one artifact was found in association with Feature 10, a piece of smooth sheet metal 45 cm wide and 250 cm long.
basis_size: Distribution of surface features, buildings shown on Grapevine topo (PR 1973)
artifact: Relatively small quantities of concrete fragments and metal were found on the surface, sometimes clustered into small scatters and sometimes as isolated pieces.  However, the site area is much cleaner than that observed at some of the other nearby sites.  Artifacts were found in only two of the eight shovel tests dug at the site.  These were the units nearest the house mound.  The other six shovel tests were dug near  Fea. 9 (the hand-dug well) to determine if an isolable, early component was present.  Unfortunately, all of these ST's were sterile.
circum: Warm, sunny, early morning; no ground surface visibility
artificial: Demolition of structures; some bulldozing in SE corner
future: Construction of the International Commerce Park at DFW
value: The site appears to have been occupied throughout most of the 20th century and probably earlier.  No isolable 19th century component was identified, while the length of the occupation suggests that any early deposits will be heavily mixed with the later deposits. Consequently, site DFW-1 is considered to have little or no research potential; consequently, the site is recommended as ineligible for inclusion in the NRHP.
disc_desc: Site DFW-1 is a large, low density historic site.  It was occupied from at least the late 19th to late 20th centuries based on the historic maps of the area.  However, the 1973 photorevision of the Grapevine quadrangle shows five structures at the site, while the 1981 photorevision shows only three.  This may indicate that the site had changed function and some outbuildings were no longer needed, or that the site had been abandoned and these structures destroyed.
attachmem:
1.  Plan map of site
2.  Copy of topo map showing site location
